summary:
Paul Merson and Andros Townsend’s dispute has flared up again.  
• Last week Merson wrote in his Sky Sports column that Townsend’s England call‑up showed “if Andros Townsend can get in then it opens it up to anybody.”  
• Townsend responded on Twitter after scoring England’s equaliser against Italy, reminding Merson of his criticism.  
• Merson admitted he had been proved wrong by the goal but maintained it was only his opinion.  
• Despite the apparent truce, Merson tweeted another jibe on Sunday after Tottenham’s 0‑0 draw at Burnley, mocking Townsend for coming on with just seven minutes left.

Chelsea have submitted a formal summer bid—reported at about £4 million—for FC Tokyo’s 22‑year‑old striker Yoshinori Muto, club president Naoki Ogane confirmed. If the move goes through Muto would:  
• become Chelsea’s first Japanese player  
• spend next season on loan at partner club Vitesse Arnhem.

Ogane insists the approach is unrelated to Chelsea’s new five‑year, £200 million shirt‑sponsorship deal with Japan’s Yokohama Rubber.  

Muto, an economics graduate from Keio University, has 37 club appearances (16 goals), 11 Japan caps (1 goal), scored 13 league goals in his 2014 debut season and has three in four games this year. He says it is an honour to receive Chelsea’s offer but has not yet decided to accept. Chelsea are considering a pre‑season tour of Japan.

Large‑scale Finnish research on more than 12,000 healthy two‑year‑olds shows a link between early antibiotic use and later weight gain. Infants given antibiotics within their first six months—and those who received several courses before age two—were significantly more likely to be overweight or obese at two years old, with boys especially affected and also slightly taller. The study, reported in Pediatrics, does not prove causation but suggests antibiotics may disrupt gut bacteria that normally limit calorie absorption or curb appetite, echoing the drugs’ growth‑promoting effect in farm animals. The authors warn that such exposure could be contributing to the global childhood‑obesity epidemic and stress the need for judicious antibiotic prescribing in infancy amid broader concerns about overuse.

During last week’s Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace, a young member of the Queen’s Guard slipped on a manhole cover as he took position in his sentry box, knocking his bearskin, dropping his rifle and briefly falling to the ground. The mishap, believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on his boots, was filmed by tourist David Meadwell, 50, who was visiting from Newcastle‑upon‑Tyne. The guard quickly regained his feet while his colleagues continued marching, but appeared visibly embarrassed before the crowd of hundreds. Changing of the Guard draws thousands of visitors (daily in summer, every other day in winter); the guards are fully operational soldiers, not solely ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks (A&E, Lifetime and History) will simulcast a new, “original” and “contemporary” remake of the landmark 1977 miniseries “Roots” in 2016. The eight‑part drama again follows African captive Kunta Kinte and his American descendants, will lean more heavily on Alex Haley’s book, and will use African‑American scholars for authenticity. LeVar Burton (the original Kunta Kinte) is a co‑executive producer, and Mark Wolper (son of the initial producer) also oversees the project. The goal is to introduce the story—which once drew over 100 million viewers—to a new generation that has experienced events such as Barack Obama’s presidency, the film “12 Years a Slave,” and recent racial unrest.

• Former royal footman Christopher Lawler, now 64, says that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978 he was pinned to a chair, groped and pressured to join an orgy by four male staff members, one described as senior.  
• He escaped, was threatened to stay silent and quit the job that same day; the incident has “haunted” him since.  
• After decades of silence, Lawler renewed his complaint in 2014 when wider investigations into historical VIP child‑sex abuse began.  
• The Palace twice rebuffed his approaches before finally passing the allegation to Scotland Yard; police are now investigating.  
• A retired royal aide in his 80s has been interviewed and denies involvement; Clarence House says it will cooperate fully while inquiries continue.

Jesse and Melissa Meek of Happy Valley, Oregon revealed Melissa’s pregnancy by posting a parody of “The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air” theme in which they rap while driving, ending with a sonogram image. Created in five takes to inform far‑flung relatives, the YouTube clip has topped 1.7 million views—far more attention than they expected. The Meeks note that conception happened in just two months and say they might film another video after learning the baby’s gender. Jesse, a great‑great‑grandson of pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, had earlier learned the news from a message on their dog recorded by Melissa. A different Pennsylvania couple made a similar Fresh Prince pregnancy video the previous year.

• Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills sold more than 150 “Gone With the Wind” items from collector James Tumblin’s archive.

• Top lot: the gray jacket‑and‑skirt outfit Vivien Leigh (Scarlett O’Hara) wears in several key 1939 scenes; purchased by Tumblin for $20 in the 1960s, it realized $137,000 despite fading from its original slate blue‑gray.

• Other notable sales:
  – Leigh’s straw hat: $52,500  
  – Clark Gable’s (Rhett Butler) trousers and jacket: $55,000  
  – Black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland: $30,000

• Tumblin, former Universal Studios hair‑and‑makeup head, has toured his 300,000‑piece collection nationwide.

• “Gone With the Wind,” adapted from Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, marked its 75th anniversary last year; cast member Hattie McDaniel became the first African‑American to win an Academy Award.

A two‑year‑old boy slipped and fell 10–12 ft into the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo cheetah exhibit around 3 p.m. Saturday after his mother allegedly dangled him over the railing while holding another child. His parents quickly retrieved him before emergency crews arrived. The toddler suffered minor bumps, bruises and a leg injury, was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center, and is in stable condition; the cheetahs never approached. Eyewitnesses support claims that he was dangled, and the zoo intends to seek child‑endangerment charges against the mother. The exhibit was closed after the incident.

A de‑commissioned speed camera on Wellington Road, Handsworth, Birmingham—one of about 300 West Midlands fixed cameras switched off in March 2013 because of obsolete technology—has been mysteriously turned to face a nearby house. Although no longer operational, its new aim has drawn attention; Birmingham City Council says an engineer will inspect it and it may be removed, and it will not be included in the region’s planned digital‑camera pilot. Current speed enforcement in the area relies on mobile units, motorway cameras and patrol officers. The house owners have not commented.

Usain Bolt has been selected for Jamaica’s squad at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on 2–3 May. The six‑time Olympic champion says he is fit, healthy and eager to compete, noting Jamaica’s proud relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle welcomed his availability and promised “sprint magic.” The rest of the Jamaican team will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves underlined their Barcelona loyalty by attending the club’s Euro‑League basketball “El Clasico” with Neymar’s sister Rafaella, where Barça edged Real Madrid 85‑80, though Madrid stay top on points difference. Days earlier Neymar captained Brazil to a bruising 1‑0 win over Chile at the Emirates. Before the international break Barcelona’s football side won their own El Clasico to lead La Liga by four points and resume on Sunday against Celta Vigo as they chase a treble.

Italy is facing a surge in Mediterranean crossings from Africa and the Middle East. Between Friday and Monday, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 people and fielded SOS calls from 20 boats on Monday alone. Survivors say a vessel carrying 550 migrants capsized about 80 miles off Libya, with 145 rescued and up to 400 feared missing, but the coast guard has found no evidence of the incident so far. More than 10,000 migrants reached Italy in the first three months of 2015; at least 480 have died this year, often due to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler boats, and crews abandoning ships. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point.

• Alexis Sanchez, pursued by several clubs after leaving Barcelona, opted for Arsenal rather than Liverpool, a decision manager Arsène Wenger welcomes but cannot fully explain.  
• Wenger suspects Liverpool’s interest in Sanchez was tied to using him as part‑exchange when Barcelona bought Luis Suárez.  
• Sanchez has adapted quickly, scoring 19 goals and showing high work‑rate, fighting spirit and the ability to lift the team.  
• Ahead of Arsenal’s league match with Liverpool, Wenger praised Brendan Rodgers’ rebuilding job after Suárez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, while dismissing talk of a summer move for Liverpool’s Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, 2012 Tour de France winner and four‑time Olympic champion, will attempt to break cycling’s UCI Hour Record on 7 June at London’s Lee Valley VeloPark. He must surpass the current mark of 52.491 km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, following earlier efforts by Jens Voigt, Matthias Brändle and the unsuccessful Jack Bobridge; fellow Briton Alex Dowsett will also try on 2 May in Manchester. The 35‑year‑old, who has just ended his Team Sky road career and will ride the Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on the track, hopes a capacity 6,000 crowd—and live Sky Sports coverage—will spur him on as he pursues an eighth Olympic medal at Rio 2016. Tickets go on online sale through Sky Tickets on 19 April, priced £49, £39 and £29.

Serena Williams needed three sets to edge Sara Errani 4‑6 7‑6(3) 6‑3 in Sunday’s Fed Cup play‑off but called the clay‑court struggle an “eye‑opener,” admitting she is still playing as if on hard courts and must prepare for longer rallies. In the deciding doubles, Williams and Alison Riske were routed 6‑0 6‑3 by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, giving Italy a 3‑2 victory and relegating the United States to World Group II. Captain Mary Joe Fernandez vowed the U.S. would “keep plugging away” to return to the top tier. Williams, 33, owns 19 Grand Slam singles titles, including French Open crowns in 2002 and 2013, but clay remains her toughest surface.

River Plate have declared their interest in re‑signing Radamel Falcao, with vice‑president Matias Patanian saying they “dream of Falcao” and that “the doors are open,” although he concedes any deal would be complicated. The 29‑year‑old striker, on a season‑long loan at Manchester United where he has scored only four Premier League goals, could return to parent club Monaco if United decline their purchase option. This week he scored three goals in two internationals to equal Colombia’s national scoring record (24). Falcao previously spent 2001‑09 with River Plate, netting 34 goals in 90 first‑team games.

Ella Henderson, the 19‑year‑old platinum‑selling X‑Factor 2012 finalist, has landed her first brand deal, becoming the face of Batiste’s 2015 “Ready For It” dry‑shampoo campaign. Shot against a blurred city backdrop, the ads show her sporting several hairstyles, and a TV commercial features her single “Mirror Man.” The partnership was arranged by the MILES agency; her management CEO, Mark Hargreaves, calls it a natural fit between the popular U.K. singer and the country’s leading dry‑shampoo brand.

After Kenosha officer Pablo Torres fatally shot 26‑year‑old Aaron Siler on March 14 following a car and foot chase in which police say Siler armed himself, Torres was placed on leave while state investigators review the killing. The Kenosha Professional Police Association then put up a billboard with a photo of Torres and his dog reading “Thank you for your support, Kenosha.” Siler’s family and friends call the sign disrespectful and want it removed, saying it feels like praise for the shooting. The police union says it only meant to thank the community. Ten days before shooting Siler, Torres wounded 66‑year‑old Terry Knight, a knife‑wielding suicidal man; that earlier shooting has already been ruled justified. The probe into Siler’s death is still pending.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed Monday in Negur, near the Pakistan frontier, during clashes with militants who had crossed from Pakistan. Iranian forces killed three attackers; others escaped back across the border. The Sunni militant group Jaish al Adal, active in Pakistan’s Balochistan province and opposed to Iranian influence, claimed responsibility. Iran has urged Pakistan to capture the surviving assailants, criticizing Islamabad’s past failure to curb such militants. Pakistan condemned the attack, pledged cooperation, and said it would pursue any perpetrators on its soil.

In Japan’s parliament, wrestler‑turned‑lawmaker Antonio Inoki asked Defense Minister Gen Nakatani whether the Air Self‑Defense Force had ever scrambled jets against extraterrestrial UFOs and if any alien research was underway. Nakatani replied that while fighters are launched whenever unidentified objects approach Japanese airspace, they have never encountered anything originating beyond Earth—only birds or other earthly items. Inoki, who claims to have once seen a UFO, is a colorful figure best known for his pro‑wrestling career, a 1976 bout with Muhammad Ali, and assorted diplomatic ventures. The exchange echoes a 2007 Diet discussion, when another defense minister mused about how Japan’s pacifist constitution would apply to a space invasion.

At Hefei Xinqiao International Airport (Hefei, Anhui, China) 35‑year‑old passenger Jin Pai stood on a toilet rim to avoid sitting on what he thought was an unclean seat. The porcelain fixture toppled and shattered, leaving him with serious cuts to his left leg and buttocks that required dozens of stitches. Embarrassed, he phoned friends rather than call out for help, then later told police he had been sitting, apparently to dodge compensation. Authorities deemed the event an accident and warned travelers that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, PA, was arrested after a 15‑year‑old girl discovered a hidden bathroom camera that authorities traced to him. Police say Rebbie had secretly filmed the girl and others for three to four years and had molested the girl from ages 9 to 13. Investigators recovered 41 videos—34 showing victims showering—which Rebbie had stored on his computer. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, child sexual abuse and invasion of privacy. Rebbie is held on $500,000 bail pending a May 1 preliminary hearing.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama, 37, has released a photo series (for a book tentatively titled “Daughter and Salary Man”) that pairs unsmiling, casually dressed teenage daughters with their suit‑clad fathers caught mid‑air in exuberant jumps. Intended to let normally serious “salary‑man” dads show a playful, heroic side, the portraits are shot before various Japanese landmarks and vary from subtle hops to ambitious leaps—some leaving older fathers visibly strained. Although details are scarce, the quirky images are attracting considerable online attention.

With Paul Downton sacked as England’s managing director, attention has shifted to the county season and a possible England recall for Kevin Pietersen. At Surrey’s team photo at the Kia Oval, the 34‑year‑old batsman sat pensively at the end of the front row yet joked with team‑mates and photographers, even taking his own pictures. Pietersen has re‑joined Surrey—who face Oxford MCCU on Sunday and start their Championship campaign at Glamorgan on 19 April—in an effort to force his way back into the Test side for this summer’s Ashes after being dropped following the 2013‑14 whitewash in Australia.

Romanian strugglers Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt have dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired on Wednesday and briefly reinstated, the 41‑year‑old former Brazil, Inter Milan and Parma defender was finally removed after a 2‑0 loss to FC Botosani left the club 16th, six points from safety. Hired in January as Ceahlaul’s third coach of the season, Ze Maria will now be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar says Radamel Falcao likely regrets leaving Monaco for his season‑long loan at Manchester United. Although unhappy in France, Falcao has scored just four goals after his knee injury, making it improbable United will pay the £46 million fee to sign him permanently. Dirar believes Falcao would have played regularly and appeared in the Champions League had he stayed at Monaco.

A very tall man in a distinctive cartoon mask and fluoro‑orange sweatshirt robbed the Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30 pm Saturday. He threw the cash register on the floor, took the till drawer, and escaped with up to $1,500. No weapon was seen. Police are appealing for public help to identify him; tips can be given to Crimestoppers on 0800 555 111 or online.

Kaitlyn Granado, 24, a math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was twice arrested for alleged sexual misconduct with two 15‑year‑old male students. 

• First arrest: March 19, after admitting she kissed a student and let him touch her breasts (incident occurred April of the previous year).  
• Second arrest: April 6 (Monday), after another 15‑year‑old reported having sex with her in her car on January 18 and 19.  

She was jailed both times and released the second time on $50,000 bail. Granado has been suspended and placed on administrative leave; her plea to the new charges is not yet known.

A viral video (500,000+ views) shows a large American crocodile swimming through the marina at Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a black, red‑collared dog—owned by the local bike‑shop proprietor—dead in its jaws. Tourist Tim Weston, visiting from New Zealand, filmed the scene and said the croc held the dog for hours before disappearing. Puerto Vallarta sits amid mangroves and a nearby crocodile sanctuary, so the reptiles are regularly seen in the marina and on local golf courses; urbanisation has brought them closer to people. Online viewers reacted with shock and revulsion to the incident.

Hull City’s 2‑0 loss at Southampton left them just two points above the Premier League relegation zone with six matches remaining, four of them against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United. Manager Steve Bruce, originally aiming for 10 wins, believes eight or nine victories will now be enough and insists his side can still stay up, despite having only six wins to date and suffering long‑term injuries to key players Diame, Chester, Dawson, Jelavic and Snodgrass. At St Mary’s, Hull were superior in the first half but fell to a James Ward‑Prowse penalty and a late Graziano Pellè goal that lifted Southampton to fifth. Saints boss Ronald Koeman will reprimand Sadio Mané for trying to take the penalty meant for Ward‑Prowse.

Teacher Ian Guffick, 31, of Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, let pupils—and personally—alter completed SATs papers for 11‑year‑olds after the exam session ended. A local authority investigation confirmed the rule breach, leading the Department for Education to annul all of the school’s 2014 SATs results. Found guilty of unacceptable professional conduct, Guffick was banned from teaching for a minimum of two years (with 28 days to appeal). He expressed remorse, but officials judged the prohibition “appropriate and proportionate.”

Manchester United reserve goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, who joined from Aalesunds in 2010 and has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons, is now third‑choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdés and has been told he can leave, though a January move to FC Midtjylland collapsed. Off the field he is enjoying life with Swedish‑Albanian model Misse Beqiri: the couple have dated since 2012, married in a beach ceremony in Mauritius last year, share a young son, and frequently post about their life together on Instagram, where Beqiri has over 17,000 followers.

Thirteen 10‑foot‑tall blue letters that spelled “Yankee Stadium,” installed on the ballpark roof in 1976 and removed in 2008, were put up for sale by their current owner, Yankee Hall‑of‑Famer Reggie Jackson, at a Sotheby’s auction. Although estimated to fetch $300,000–$600,000, the lot drew no real bids—only a $260,000 house bid from a Sotheby’s employee—so the letters went unsold. Jackson had originally bought the signage after the stadium’s final game in 2008 and hoped a new generation would own it. In the same sale, a late‑1960s New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000–$30,000, surprisingly sold for $112,500.

Liverpool boss Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after images surfaced of Sterling using nitrous oxide and both players smoking shisha pipes. He reminded them of their professional responsibilities but will not discipline either and now wants to put the issue behind the team. Sterling, covering for the injured Daniel Sturridge, is set to lead the attack in Sunday’s FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa. Steven Gerrard returns from a three‑match ban and may feature as Rodgers seeks his first FA Cup final after previous near‑misses.

Mesut Özil shared a “Home Sweet Home” photo relaxing with his dog after returning to London from international duty. The Arsenal midfielder impressed for Germany in their 2‑0 Euro 2016 qualifier win over Georgia and now prepares for Arsenal’s weekend match against Liverpool. Although illness kept him out of the Gunners’ last game against Newcastle—and nightclub rumors were dismissed by Arsène Wenger—Özil is expected to start. Since returning from injury in January, he has produced four assists and three goals and says the busy English schedule suits him perfectly.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu says the club is “very happy” with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him. Enrique, who signed a two‑year deal when he took charge last summer, has Barcelona six matches from the La Liga title and still competing for a possible treble. Bartomeu highlighted Enrique’s hard work preparing for recent games, including the 2‑0 win over Valencia in which Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi scored, and noted the coach is under contract until 2016, with any extension talks to come later.

Liverpool vice‑captain Jordan Henderson, 24, has agreed a new deal worth about £100,000 a week that extends his contract to 2020, giving the club a boost after their FA Cup semi‑final defeat. He is the third key player—after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho—to commit long‑term under Brendan Rodgers. Henderson’s strong season (13 assists, seven goals) makes him a leading candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as captain when Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy this summer. Talks on Raheem Sterling’s future have been put off until season’s end, though Liverpool still expect him to remain at Anfield.

• Filipe Luis says he intends to honour the full three‑year deal he signed with Chelsea last July, despite Atletico Madrid’s interest in re‑signing him.  
• The left‑back has not established himself as first choice at Stamford Bridge but states: “I’m happy at Chelsea. I want to stay until the end of my contract.”  
• After appearing for Brazil in friendly wins over France and Chile, his focus returns to Chelsea’s Premier League title push.  
• Manager José Mourinho is demanding total concentration for the nine challenging league games remaining.

• On 27 March, Wasps No 8 Nathan Hughes’s knee accidentally struck George North’s head as the Northampton wing scored at Franklin’s Gardens, leaving North unconscious—his third knockout in two months; doctors told North to rest at least a month.  

• Hughes was shown a red card and given a three‑match suspension for “reckless” play, causing him to miss Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter‑final defeat by Toulon.  

• The ban provoked widespread criticism from team‑mates and other players, who insisted there was no intent.  

• On appeal, heard with new evidence, the panel ruled the collision accidental, found no foul play, rescinded the red card and overturned the suspension.  

• Hughes is immediately eligible to play, though he will sit out Wasps’ trip to London Welsh and is expected to return on 26 April against Exeter.

Wildfires ignited by field‑burning farmers in southeastern Siberia on April 14 spread rapidly in strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. Smoke from the fires was lofted into the atmosphere, carried across the Pacific, and reached the Pacific Northwest. In Washington, Oregon and British Columbia the smoke particles filtered out shorter‑wavelength light, producing striking red‑orange sunrises and sunsets, one of which Seattle photographer Tim Durkan captured and shared on CNN iReport. The vivid colors will fade as the smoke disperses and air quality improves.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. Police recovered it on April 1 after tipster Mick Sexton recognized the car. The thieves had altered it—red‑spray‑painted rims, red side stripes, and orange steering‑wheel accents—and left a strong cigarette and marijuana odor. Schoenig jokingly thanked the thieves on Facebook for “pimping” her car, is having it professionally cleaned, and is honoring Sexton with a new smoothie called “Sexton on Wheels” at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. Friend Marlene Trice says Schoenig loves making people laugh.

Manchester City’s stars are on heavily‑incentivised deals that pay each player about £500,000 if the club reaches the Champions League group stage; failure to qualify would cost the squad roughly £12 million in total. After a 4‑2 derby defeat at Old Trafford, City sit fourth, only four points ahead of Liverpool (who have a game in hand). The top three Premier League teams qualify automatically, while fourth place must survive a play‑off, leaving City’s bonus – and next season’s recruitment plans – in jeopardy. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admits the campaign has “disintegrated,” with seven defeats and early FA Cup and Champions League exits. City’s remaining fixtures are West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea and Southampton. United, meanwhile, are confident of attracting elite signings.

Manchester United’s Under‑18s beat Manchester City 1‑0 in the “mini‑derby” at Altrincham’s 6,000‑seat Moss Lane on Saturday. Admission was free and about 1,000 fans attended. The sides featured 13 English players (10 from Manchester). United coach Paul McGuinness deployed a three‑at‑the‑back system; Callum Gribbin earned and converted the decisive free‑kick just before the hour. United also hit the woodwork, while City threatened through Marcus Wood, Aaron Nemane and Javairo Dilrosun. The win keeps United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand; injury‑hit City have lost both of their Under‑18 Premier League play‑off fixtures. The match highlighted several promising local talents.

After England’s 1‑1 draw with Italy, England and Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart, celebrating his 50th international appearance, praised 37‑year‑old Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon, who reached 147 caps that night. Hart called Buffon “a legend of the game,” said he studies Buffon’s example, and expressed his own desire to continue improving and accumulating more caps for club and country.

Chipotle will begin offering delivery in 67 U.S. cities through the Postmates app, entering the $70 billion food‑delivery market. Customers ordering online or via mobile will pay Postmates’ variable fee (starting around $5) plus a 9 percent Chipotle service charge. Chipotle had previously avoided third‑party delivery tie‑ups but now joins other chains—Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s and Burger King—testing delivery programs. The service uses Postmates’ network of independent drivers, and the move comes as Chipotle’s profile rises, recently drawing visits from presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio.

Bill and Denise Richard, whose 8‑year‑old son Martin was the youngest person killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings and whose daughter Jane was badly hurt, have written a front‑page Boston Globe column asking federal prosecutors to drop the death‑penalty pursuit against bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. Tsarnaev was found guilty last week on all 30 charges; the penalty phase begins Tuesday and could last four weeks. The Richards say a life‑without‑parole sentence, with Tsarnaev waiving all appeals, would spare their family—and the public—years of painful legal proceedings. They emphasize they speak only for themselves and hope ending the death‑penalty push will help “turn the page” for Boston and the country.

A mystery billionaire has turned a Boeing 747‑8 into one of the world’s most lavish private jets. The £400 million, three‑year conversion replaces the normal 600‑seat layout with hotel‑style luxury for the owner and several dozen guests. On board are multiple lounges, a large dining room linked to a full kitchen, a conference room, a “state room,” an office/guest bedroom, and an upper‑deck “aeroloft” holding eight beds. The master suite features a king‑size bed, sofa and armchair, creating a residence‑like atmosphere throughout the aircraft.

SpaceX successfully launched an uncrewed Dragon cargo ship atop a Falcon 9 from Cape Canaveral toward the International Space Station, but its first‑stage booster’s attempt to land upright on an ocean “droneship” failed when the rocket touched down too hard and toppled. The mission, SpaceX’s sixth ISS resupply flight (after a weather‑scrubbed try the day before), is ferrying more than 4,300 lb of supplies—including research gear and an espresso machine—and will return with over 3,000 lb of experiments and waste after about five weeks docked to the station. Reusing boosters, which normally burn up or splash down, is central to Elon Musk’s plan to slash launch costs by up to 100‑fold, so the company will keep retrying sea and, eventually, land recoveries.

Priscilla Presley is partnering with NBC’s Today show to give one Elvis‑fan couple the “ultimate wedding.” Contest entrants submit photos or a video explaining why they should win. The chosen pair (to be announced next Monday) will:

• Marry on Thursday, April 23, in the brand‑new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel inside Las Vegas’s Westgate Hotel (the former Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis gave 830 sold‑out shows).  
• Have Priscilla Presley serve as their official witness.  
• Receive a free two‑night hotel suite, wedding reception, round‑trip airfare and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show.

Priscilla, who helped design the chapel, insists on a classy ceremony—no Elvis impersonators. The venue forms part of the first permanent Graceland exhibition outside Memphis.

Liverpool beat Newcastle 2‑0 at Anfield thanks to goals from Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen, giving vice‑captain Jordan Henderson belief that they can still overhaul faltering Manchester City in the Premier League’s race for a Champions League spot. The victory leaves Liverpool four points behind City, who recently lost 4‑2 to Manchester United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet each made their 47th appearance of the season, matching the highest total in Europe’s top five leagues. Allen, who acknowledged Newcastle might have been due a penalty for a Dejan Lovren challenge, said the win was vital after recent defeats to United and Arsenal.

Roma beat Napoli 1‑0 at the Stadio Olimpico, ending a four‑month, seven‑game home winless run and strengthening their push for a Champions League spot.  
• Goal: Miralem Pjanić finished a swift counter‑attack in the 25th minute.  
• Key performer: 38‑year‑old keeper Morgan De Sanctis produced multiple second‑half saves, notably against Dries Mertens and Manolo Gabbiadini.  
• Table impact: Roma, still second in Serie A, moved four points clear of Lazio; Napoli’s winless streak grew to five games and they stayed fifth.  
• Context: Tight security accompanied Napoli’s first trip to Rome since a fan’s death last season; Campania residents were barred from buying tickets, but no incidents occurred.  
• Absentees/returns: Roma lacked injured Francesco Totti and Gervinho; Napoli’s Lorenzo Insigne made his first appearance since a November knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers’ dull 0‑0 home draw with Fleetwood Town epitomised their mediocre League One season. With virtually no notable action to show, the club’s media team uploaded a “highlights” video lasting just 27 seconds—14 seconds of which were match footage featuring the kick‑off, a single goal‑kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has formed an unusual bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid cichlid first bred in Taiwan in 1986. After removing two aggressive tank‑mates, he began hand‑feeding the fish frozen blood worms, which made it increasingly sociable. Now the cichlid voluntarily swims into Giroux’s submerged hand for daily 15‑minute sessions of stroking and massage, remaining still, circling his fingers and even following his hand to the water’s surface when he leaves. Giroux documents these interactions on his YouTube channel.

Ben Stokes, back with England at the Kensington Oval where he once broke his wrist punching a locker, remains a fiery, highly‑skilled all‑rounder whose aggression can inspire runs and wickets but needs careful control. Coach Peter Moores’ recent talk with him after the Marlon Samuels clash showed the value of firm but supportive man‑management: keep Stokes’ natural exuberance without letting it boil over. A minor back niggle is his only fitness concern, and despite debate over picking a second spinner (Adil Rashid) England are keen for Stokes—as well as Chris Jordan—to play regularly, believing the experience will unlock their full potential.

All 33,000 tickets for Wales’ Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium at Cardiff City Stadium on 12 June have been sold. Wales and Belgium share the Group B lead on 11 points, with Belgium ahead only on goal difference. Wales’ recent 3‑0 win in Israel has fueled optimism about securing a first major‑tournament place since 1958, prompting heavy ticket demand noted by the FAW. Despite speculation, the match will remain at the smaller Cardiff City Stadium—preferred by the players—because UEFA rules block a late switch to the larger Millennium Stadium.

England U‑17 coach John Peacock has announced an 18‑man squad for the UEFA European Under‑17 Championship in Bulgaria next month. 

Key points:
• England are the reigning champions and qualified with a perfect record.  
• They are in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland; matches: Italy (7 May, Burgas), Holland (10 May) and Ireland (13 May).  
• Squad:  
  – Goalkeepers: Paul Woolston, Will Huffer  
  – Defenders: Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva, Tayo Edun  
  – Midfielders: Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland, Chris Willock  
  – Forwards: Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi, Ike Ugbo  
• First call‑up: Arsenal striker Stephy Mavididi.  
• Liverpool duo Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the last qualifying round.

Manchester City are negotiating with Anderlecht to sign 14‑year‑old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, a highly rated product of the Belgian club’s academy. The youngster, who previously turned down Barcelona to continue his studies and is also on Arsenal’s radar, is the subject of compensation discussions between City and Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as Manuel Pellegrini seeks to secure the promising talent for the future.

Transgender escort Vanessa Santillan, a 33‑year‑old Mexican national, was found beaten and strangled on 28 March in a £400,000 flat in Romily Court, Fulham, south‑west London. A 23‑year‑old man has been arrested in connection with her death and released on bail, pending further questioning. Scotland Yard, led by Detective Chief Inspector Rebecca Reeves, is appealing for anyone who saw or contacted Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward. Santillan, who recently moved to London, advertised herself as an escort working in London, Paris and Miami and had expressed her affection for London and Paris online in the weeks before she was killed.

Dawn, a woman who has endured seven miscarriages and buried one baby, Daniel James, had saved £207 toward a £500 headstone for his grave. While appearing on ITV’s The Jeremy Kyle Show she accused her long‑time friend and house‑mate Jamie—a convicted burglar—of stealing the money. A lie‑detector test confirmed Jamie had taken it, and a Facebook message he sent en route to the show admitted the theft while shifting blame to his girlfriend Carol. On learning the results Dawn broke down in tears, saying she felt betrayed after trying to honor her son’s memory.

ISIS has freed just over 200 Yazidis (reports range from 217‑228) who were in the group’s custody since its 2014 takeover of Yazidi towns in northern Iraq. Most of those released were women, children, the elderly or the ill. Arab tribal leaders reportedly helped broker the hand‑over to Kurdish Peshmerga forces, who transported the Yazidis to the regional capital, Irbil. The motive for the release is unknown.

Background:
• ISIS seized Yazidi areas such as Sinjar last summer, killing hundreds and forcing thousands to flee; some were trapped in nearby mountains without food or water.  
• Survivors recount mass killings, rape and enslavement of Yazidi women and girls.  
• A U.S.‑led coalition later airdropped aid, carried out rescues and began air‑strikes against ISIS.  

About the Yazidis:
• A Kurdish‑speaking, pre‑Islamic religious minority that combines elements of Christianity, Judaism and Zoroastrianism.  
• Long persecuted—often mislabeled “devil‑worshipers”—they number roughly 500,000 in Iraq, less than 1 % of the population.

Wednesday’s release follows earlier ISIS releases of mainly elderly and child captives but leaves many Yazidis still unaccounted for.

Tottenham striker Harry Kane has enjoyed a breakthrough season, earning nominations for both the PFA Player of the Year and Young Player of the Year awards after scoring 20 Premier League goals and debut‑scoring for England. To mark his success, Copa90 released a stop‑motion style animation titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?” that strings together still photos to showcase highlights such as his long‑range goal against Chelsea, header versus Arsenal, and England debut strike. The film appears ahead of Sunday’s awards ceremony, where Kane competes with players including Eden Hazard and Alexis Sánchez.

Jamie Carragher, speaking after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work, backed Brendan Rodgers to remain Liverpool’s manager despite a third successive trophy‑less season and a probable finish outside the Premier League’s top four (currently seven points adrift of fourth‑placed Manchester City with a game in hand). Carragher said one game should not decide Rodgers’ future, acknowledged that many of last summer’s signings have yet to settle, and stressed that correct recruitment this off‑season is vital for winning silverware and regaining Champions League qualification next year. The ex‑defender also outlined his 23 Foundation’s coaching programmes in eight Merseyside schools, aiming to inspire youngsters from deprived areas like his native Bootle.

At East Midlands Airport security staff confiscated four‑year‑old James Hayward’s brightly coloured Nerf‑style toy gun, judging it to breach rules that ban items resembling real weapons. James was frisked and the family, hurrying for a flight to Lanzarote, surrendered the £6 plastic dart gun. Father Phil Hayward called the action “ludicrous”; the airport apologised but said government regulations left them no choice and they had offered to post the toy home. After the holiday the family bought James a replacement gun online.

A 31‑year‑old man calling himself “Rich” from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted a Gumtree ad seeking a girlfriend or wife.  

What he offers:  
• Accommodation and possibly a company car, phone, laptop and gym membership.  
• “Lots of benefits,” saying he is “not shy of blowin’ cash on my woman.”  

His requirements for the “successful candidate”:  
• Preferably a non‑drinker and non‑smoker who is fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, handy, a good cook, great in bed, enjoys the outdoors yet can be “a princess.”  
• Must love pets; former partners are excluded.  

About himself:  
• Athletic, white, heavily tattooed, 175 cm tall, “well endowed,” brown hair and eyes.  
• Does not drink, smoke or use drugs; likes travelling, sports, fishing, camping, cars and bikes.  
• Owns property, earns “great money,” and is very independent.  

He invites “all reasonable offers.” Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

FA chairman Greg Dyke is pressing for reforms that would:
• Raise the quota of home‑grown players in Premier League 25‑man squads from 8 to 12.  
• Redefine “home‑grown” as three years’ training in England before age 18 (currently before 21).

His plan faces Premier League resistance, but five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven‑Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren—have written to support him. They argue that with only 81 of 220 recent Premier League starters (36.8%) eligible for England, the shrinking talent pool harms the national team and threatens future World Cup success. While young talents like Harry Kane, Raheem Sterling and Ross Barkley show England can still produce quality players, the managers say they need more first‑team opportunities, so the game should “get behind” Dyke’s proposals quickly.

In the upcoming episode of Poldark, Demelza (Eleanor Tomlinson) astonishingly advances from announcing her pregnancy to being eight‑months along and then giving birth, all within minutes of screen time. Viewers will quickly see Ross Poldark (Aidan Turner) doting on their new baby daughter. This sudden timeline jump echoes an earlier storyline in which Elizabeth’s entire pregnancy elapsed between episodes. Fans have remarked on Twitter about how swiftly pregnancies progress in the series, even as Ross’s popularity with female viewers remains high and his devotion to Demelza is affirmed.

Leicester City, bottom of the Premier League but just three points from safety after consecutive wins, face Swansea on Saturday. Manager Nigel Pearson credits the 3‑2 victory at West Brom—sealed by Jamie Vardy’s stoppage‑time goal—for reviving their survival hopes, yet stresses that the team must stay calm, ignore other relegation battles, and focus solely on winning their remaining games to keep their fate in their own hands.

Varvara, a North Pacific gray whale tracked by Oregon State University scientists, set a new mammalian migration record by swimming about 14,000 miles (22,500 km). She left her feeding grounds near Russia’s Sakhalin Island, crossed the Pacific, and traveled down the U.S. West Coast to Baja, Mexico—surpassing the previous 10,190‑mile whale record. During the trip she stopped at three breeding sites typical of eastern gray whales, hinting that some whales classed as the critically small western gray population (estimated at 150) may actually belong to the eastern group.

Overnight, a section of seabed along Hokkaido’s Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu abruptly lifted 30–50 ft, forming a new coastal strip about 1,000–1,640 ft long and 100 ft wide. Geologists say a nearby landslide—caused by melting snow and ice that let land slump and tilt the seabed upward—likely triggered the rise. Residents reported neither tremors nor noise, and officials consider the event unrelated to recent earthquakes and unlikely to expand further. Exposed marine life such as seaweed and sea urchins confirms the former seafloor origin.

PSG full‑back Gregory van der Wiel says he has no intention of leaving the club this summer despite rumors and a recent dispute with coach Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Chelsea Champions League match. Declaring his love for the club, city and teammates, he wants to sign a new contract and remains ready to play when selected. PSG are nevertheless being linked with Barcelona right‑back Dani Alves, which could still influence Van der Wiel’s future.

Carlos Tevez, 31, has told Juventus he wants to leave a year early and re‑join his boyhood club Boca Juniors. Boca president Daniel Angelici says the transfer will be completed once Tevez terminates his Juve contract, which runs until 2016. Juventus, although reluctant to lose Serie A’s top scorer (17 goals this season), are searching for replacements. Argentina coach Tata Martino insists a return to Boca would not affect Tevez’s national‑team prospects and would not be a step down from Juventus.

Bayern Munich overturned Porto’s 3‑1 first‑leg advantage by thrashing them 6‑1 at the Allianz Arena, leading 5‑0 by half‑time and reaching the Champions League semi‑finals. The goals came from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and a Robert Lewandowski brace. During the jubilant match, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola tore the left leg of his grey trousers, revealing his underwear; he joked afterward that he would need a new pair.

Three cars collided on the Brisbane Valley Highway about 2 km south of Fernvale on Wednesday afternoon, injuring ten people—four of them children.  
• Four patients (a 40‑year‑old man, a 5‑year‑old boy, a 27‑year‑old woman and a 6‑year‑old girl) were air‑lifted by Rescue 500 helicopter—two already to Brisbane’s Princess Alexandra Hospital—after suffering chest, shoulder, arm and abdominal injuries.  
• Six others, including an infant, two young girls and a man with hand lacerations, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for checks; two females were unhurt.  
• One person had to be cut free from a vehicle.  
• The crash forced the closure of the highway, with diversions expected for several hours.

• Arsenal host league‑leaders Chelsea on Sunday; kick‑off is 4 pm.  
• Mesut Özil, 26, showed off a newly‑bought Apple Watch on Instagram, likening it to Michael Knight’s gadget from “Knight Rider”; he is expected to start the match (4 goals in 25 games this season).  
• Arsenal sit 10 points behind Chelsea with six Premier League fixtures left.  
• Jack Wilshere has returned from five months out and was on the bench for the recent FA Cup semi‑final; club great Ray Parlour says Wilshere can be the club’s future if he can stay fit.

Referee Mark Clattenburg, regarded as one of the Premier League’s leading officials, will oversee Sunday’s Manchester derby at Old Trafford. This season he has brandished only two Premier League red cards, both to United players (Tyler Blackett vs Leicester and Luke Shaw vs West Ham), and he also dismissed City captain Vincent Kompany while refereeing Belgium’s Euro‑2016 qualifier against Israel. Kompany’s sending‑off rules him out of Belgium’s June match with Wales. Clattenburg’s assistants for the derby are Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as fourth official. The game carries extra weight: City’s recent 2‑1 loss to Crystal Palace left them a point behind United, who have won five consecutive league games. The result could be pivotal in deciding who finishes second behind Chelsea.

Federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of expecting embattled Indigenous MP Billy Gordon to resign, saying they viewed him as “a little black puppet on a string.” Gordon had left the Labor Party after domestic‑violence allegations and disclosure of a past criminal record but chose to stay in parliament as an independent, endangering the government’s slim majority. Katter, himself of Lebanese heritage, said his remark was intended to expose what he sees as racial overtones; however, the phrase drew widespread social‑media criticism. He contrasted Gordon with past independents whom he believes became government “puppets,” vowing this would not happen in Gordon’s case.

Dayna Dobias, a 19‑year‑old from Downers Grove, Illinois, was born with cerebral palsy but refuses to be limited by it. She creates upbeat dance videos—one earlier featured Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to counter stereotypes, discourage bullying and change how disability is portrayed in TV, film and fashion. Despite doctors once predicting she might never walk, Dayna now dances, drives, attends college and has started motivational speaking at Chicago‑area schools. Her message: she does some things differently, but she is “pretty much just the same as everyone else,” and people should look past her disability before judging.

• Orlando City have enquired about signing Manchester United striker Javier Hernandez, seeing the Mexico star as a major commercial draw for their large Latin‑American fanbase.  
• While Orlando are keen, eight European clubs are also in the hunt: Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton (Premier League) and Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, Inter Milan. United are prepared to sell for about £8 million.  
• Hernandez, 26, has endured a frustrating season on loan at Real Madrid.  
• Separately, United have tabled an improved contract offer to 19‑year‑old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has interest from PSG, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord after rejecting the club’s initial proposal.

Around 12:15 a.m. Saturday at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles, at least three would‑be carjackers argued with a man fueling his white Dodge Charger, pulled a gun, and, when he fled, doused the car with gasoline and set it ablaze while two passengers were inside. No one was injured, but the car’s front end was destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is treating the case as arson, using surveillance footage to search for the suspects, who remain at large.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting that he:

• Bartered sex with some patients in exchange for treatment.  
• Performed exorcisms on certain patients.  
• Told patients to stop taking medication he had prescribed.

Under the agreement with the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, Manuel:

• Cannot seek license reinstatement for at least 10 years.  
• Must prove the cited misconduct no longer exists before re‑applying.

Despite the violations, Manuel’s three patient reviews on HealthGrades.com give him perfect satisfaction scores. His listed clinic address is a residential home, and individuals reached by the media declined to comment.

On Tuesday, a Russian SU‑27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC‑135U reconnaissance plane flying in international airspace over the Baltic Sea north of Poland. The U.S. calls the jet’s close, high‑speed maneuvers “unsafe and unprofessional” and will lodge a formal diplomatic complaint. Russia claims the U.S. aircraft neared its border with its transponder off, a charge the U.S. denies. A similar complaint arose last year when another SU‑27 flew within 100 feet of an RC‑135U over the Sea of Okhotsk. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are frequent in both Northern Europe and the Far East/Alaska region.

Just days before President Obama’s early‑April visit to Utah, a thief stole an FBI agent’s sniper rifle from the agent’s parked vehicle at the Marriott SpringHill Suites near Salt Lake City’s airport.  

Key points  
• The rifle, in a hard case padlocked and chained to a truck safe, was taken overnight on March 27 after the rear passenger window was shattered.  
• Police believe a rope was tied to the case or its cable lock and yanked loose with another vehicle; the car’s window frame was pulled out, and skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken case handle were left behind.  
• The agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also taken; most bags and clothing were later found at a nearby Residence Inn, but the rifle remains missing.  
• The hotel had no surveillance cameras. The rifle’s serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was alerted before the President’s visit.  
• Investigators do not know whether the agent’s car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is on trial for the July 2012 murder of his neighbour Terrence Freebody in Red Hill, Canberra, where he allegedly stomped on Freebody’s head, cut his throat and stabbed him repeatedly. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen told the jury that Costa’s mental state had been deteriorating due to dementia and alcohol abuse, citing erratic triple‑0 calls and a trail of faeces at the scene as signs of severe confusion. Mullen maintains Costa likely did not grasp his actions or their consequences, rejecting a prosecutor’s claim that Costa faked memory loss. Costa’s mental condition is pivotal; if the jury accepts he was mentally impaired, it could deliver a not‑guilty verdict.

In Everton’s 1‑0 win over Burnley, Ross Barkley took – and missed – a 10th‑minute penalty that regular taker Leighton Baines normally would have taken, echoing January’s Mirallas–Baines incident. Manager Roberto Martinez defended the decision, saying Barkley was entitled to step up and that several players are allowed to take spot‑kicks depending on how they feel; Lukaku would have taken it had he been on the field. The miss did not matter as Kevin Mirallas scored later to secure the victory.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom aboard Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam at 11:30 a.m. Thursday while the ship was docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico. The cruise line says the deaths appear to be a murder‑suicide. Cleaning staff discovered the bodies, the cabin was secured, and authorities—including the FBI—are investigating. The ship had departed Tampa on March 29 for a 14‑day Southern Caribbean cruise.

Patrick Kluivert’s first matches as Curacao coach ended in success: after a 2‑1 home win over Montserrat, a 2‑2 away draw (sealed by an 87th‑minute Charlton Vicento goal) gave Curacao a 4‑3 aggregate victory and passage to CONCACAF’s second 2018 World Cup qualifying round. They will meet Cuba on 8 and 16 June. Kluivert, a former Netherlands striker and 2014 World Cup assistant to Louis van Gaal, has Curacao roots through his mother and was a World Cup semi‑finalist as both player (1998) and coach (2014).

Esteban Cambiasso, a 15‑time trophy winner with Inter Milan and former champion with River Plate and Real Madrid, says keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would feel “like another cup.” Leicester sit bottom, seven points from safety with eight games left, but the Argentine midfielder insists survival is still possible. Cambiasso, who joined the Foxes last summer on a one‑year deal, has become a key player, is happy in the East Midlands and may extend his stay if the club stays up.

Gemma, a 23‑year‑old unemployed mother of two children under five, handed each baby to her 52‑year‑old mother Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie has raised the children ever since social services threatened to remove them and says the youngsters now call her “mum.” Gemma continues heavy drinking, partying and using the legal high MKat, and has admitted to past thefts from Debbie; a lie‑detector test showed she also stole one child’s iPad to fund her lifestyle. Concluding Gemma is unfit and cannot be trusted around the children or their possessions, Debbie is prepared to bar her daughter from the house and stop all contact unless Gemma quits alcohol, drugs and partying.

Eden Hazard’s goal that put Chelsea 1‑0 up on Manchester United began when John Terry lunged from behind, elbowing Radamel Falcao off the ball near halfway; Cesc Fabregas gathered the loose ball, Oscar back‑heeled, and Hazard scored. During Sky Sports’ half‑time analysis, pundits Graeme Souness, Thierry Henry and Jamie Redknapp unanimously said play should have been stopped because Terry’s challenge was a clear foul, with Souness calling it “a forearm smash,” Henry insisting he would want the free‑kick “all day long,” and Redknapp adding that, even if Falcao might have stayed up, the tackle “shouldn’t have gone unpunished.”

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver escaped unharmed after the group’s tour bus caught fire Thursday morning on Interstate 30 near Dallas. The blaze, apparently triggered when a rear tire blew, was filmed by passer‑by Michael Barnett and later doused by responders. Scott posted photos on Instagram showing the heavily damaged bus—everything in the rear lounge was lost except her Bible—and thanked those who helped. Bandmates Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not aboard. Lady Antebellum is still slated to play the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing orbiting satellites covered in mirrors that convert sunlight into low‑power laser beams, which are then aimed at ground‑based solar panels to boost their output. Early tests in Scotland succeeded and further trials are planned in Portugal; the system could make solar power practical even in cloudy regions and provide rapid energy to disaster zones. The lasers are far weaker than science‑fiction weapons—“not powerful enough to blind a pigeon”—though Quarterman notes control of the satellites would still need oversight. Separately, Japanese researchers have proposed fitting the ISS with a similarly low‑power laser to nudge small pieces of space debris into Earth’s atmosphere.

• Stephen Munden, 54, a convicted paedophile with learning difficulties and an obsessive sexual interest in young girls, absconded from a psychiatric hospital in Winchfield, near Hook, Hampshire, at 6:15 pm on Tuesday.  
• He is 5 ft 8 in tall, heavily built, with dark hair; police believe he may have recently shaved his beard. Photos with and without facial hair have been released.  
• Munden was being held under a hospital order imposed last August after he sat next to a three‑year‑old on a bus and sexually touched her hand; he has previous convictions for possessing indecent images of children and kept children’s items at home.  
• Consultant psychiatrist John O’Shea said Munden is autistic, has mild learning difficulties and struggles to control his attraction to small children.  
• Detective Chief Inspector Tim Rowlandson has urged the public to report any sightings immediately, stressing the urgency of locating Munden.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano, Donald Sterling’s former companion, to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts—luxury cars, a $1.8 million duplex and other items—after Sterling’s wife, Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling, sued her for using the couple’s money. Shelly Sterling’s lawyer called the ruling a precedent for spouses to recover such assets. Stiviano maintained the gifts were legitimate. The lawsuit follows Donald Sterling’s 2014 downfall and lifetime NBA ban after racist remarks he made to Stiviano became public.

Thierry Henry says Arsenal cannot win the Premier League without major reinforcement. Speaking after the 0‑0 draw with Chelsea, he urged Arsène Wenger to buy four “spine” players this summer—a goalkeeper, centre‑back, holding midfielder and a “top, top quality” striker. Citing Chelsea’s additions of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas and Costa, he argued that similar calibre signings are needed and questioned whether current No 9 Olivier Giroud, despite 14 league goals, is good enough to lead a title challenge. Arsenal sit third, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand.

Maurice Van Ryn, wealthy head of Bega Cheese in NSW, has pleaded guilty to 12 sexual‑offence charges, the most serious being persistent sexual abuse of a child. In a victim‑impact statement to Sydney’s District Court, one of his female victims explained that the years of abuse left her depressed, fearful of future relationships, and driven to self‑harm and suicide attempts. She kept the abuse secret until learning of Van Ryn’s arrest, now worries about his eventual release, and testified that as a child she did not realise the acts were illegal. The hearing is ongoing.

Arsenal’s 19‑year‑old midfielder Serge Gnabry, sidelined since March 2014 with a serious knee injury, has now completed two full 90‑minute matches for the club’s Under‑21 side, most recently a 1‑0 loss to Reading. Feeling “better and better,” the Germany U‑21 international says he is over the injury and is looking forward to returning to first‑team action.

Jacob Phillips, a 23‑year‑old accountancy graduate who worked for Liam Gallagher’s clothing label Pretty Green, took a taxi home from a night out in Cardiff on a December night. Lacking the cash to pay, he and two friends jumped out in Penarth, South Wales, intending to “dodge” the fare. While running off in the dark, Phillips vaulted a fence on the disused Northern Promenade and, unaware of the danger, fell about 70 feet from the cliff edge. His body was found the next morning by a dog walker. An inquest at Cardiff Coroner’s Court ruled the death accidental, noting that Phillips was disoriented and could not have seen the sheer drop ahead.

Last summer HM Passport Office was swamped by 3.6 million applications, leaving more than 500,000 passports stuck in the system and forcing thousands of holidaymakers to pay £30 fast‑track fees or miss their trips. Despite the disruption:

• Only 2,191 compensation claims were approved (about the same as the previous year), paying out £203,066 in total—an average of £92.  
• Ministers rejected a Home Affairs Committee call for blanket refunds, arguing it would “create a precedent,” and the agency says it cannot even state how many claims were refused because its complaints database failed.  
• The Passport Office still recorded a £42.3 million surplus between April and October, while managers shared £1.8 million in bonuses, the highest individual award being £3,500.  

Consequently, most affected travellers received no reimbursement, even those—like one couple who lost £1,500 on a missed Morocco trip—who applied in good time and paid extra for upgrades.

A three‑bedroom, semi‑detached house in Horfield, Bristol is being auctioned on 30 April (County Ground, Bristol) with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. Internally it has remained virtually unchanged since its 1930s construction, retaining:

• Original mint‑green‑and‑black bathroom, kitchen cupboards, wood‑panelled hallway and brick open‑fire  
• Stained‑glass windows (ships in the hall, coats of arms in the living room)  
• Oil‑fired central heating and retro jars/tins of period food stored on a hall shelf  

Although now double‑glazed, most fixtures are untouched; auctioneer David Beddoe notes restoration costs may deter developers but sees it as ideal for collectors or antique enthusiasts.

Colin Kaepernick, initially the backup to Alex Smith, became the 49ers’ starting quarterback mid‑2012 after Smith’s concussion. He stayed starter, leading San Francisco to its first Super Bowl since 1994, where they were defeated by the Baltimore Ravens.
“Soul Food” is a 1997 American comedy‑drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent her early years there, and later lived in Texas and San Francisco.  
Route 495 is a 3.45‑mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, linking the New Jersey Turnpike (I‑95, exits 16E–17) in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 within the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, giving access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish‑language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal’s Telemundo Enterprises division.

Damon Albarn grew up in Leytonstone, East London, and Colchester, Essex. At Stanway School he met Graham Coxon, and together they formed Blur, whose first album, Leisure, came out in 1991 to mixed reviews. A decade later a different Albarn-led group issued a self‑titled debut album (2001) that achieved global success, drawing on alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop influences. Albarn’s own solo debut, Everyday Robots, was released on 28 April 2014, co‑produced by Richard Russell and featuring Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples of Lord Buckley.
Mogadishu, also called Muqdisho or locally Hamar, is Somalia’s capital and most populous city, housing many of the country’s key national institutions.
“Happiness in Slavery” is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, included on their 1992 debut EP, Broken.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has received a BAFTA nomination.

“Shooter” exists as both a 2007 film and a later TV series. 

• Film (2007): Stars Mark Wahlberg as Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, who is framed for murder by a rogue private‑military unit.  
• TV series: Stars Ryan Phillippe as expert marksman Bob Lee Swagger, living in exile until he is drawn back to prevent an assassination attempt on the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first‑degree murder and conspiracy for directing his followers to kill seven people—Abigail Folger, Wojciech Frykowski, Steven Parent, Sharon Tate, Jay Sebring, and Leno and Rosemary LaBianca—with Sharon Tate the most prominent victim. He also received first‑degree murder convictions for the separate killings of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea. Following his arrest, songs he had written and performed were issued commercially.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker and political activist. He debuted on television with a 1974 Little House on the Prairie episode directed by his father, then made his film debut in Taps (1981). After 1980s roles such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High, he gained critical notice in At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990) and Carlito’s Way (1993). Dead Man Walking (1995) established him as a leading actor, earning his first Oscar nomination and Berlin Film Festival Best Actor. Further Oscar nominations followed for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and he won Best Actor Academy Awards for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice. He entered Plato’s Academy in Athens at about 17–18 and studied there until age 37 (c. 347 BC). Tenacious D is an American comedy‑rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black (lead vocalist/guitarist) and Kyle Gass (lead guitarist/vocalist). James VI of Scotland (r. 1567–1625) became James I of England and Ireland in 1603, uniting the crowns but not the separate governments of the two realms. Saxony (the Free State of Saxony) is a land‑locked federal state in eastern Germany. Covering 18,413 km², it is Germany’s 10th‑largest state and, with about 4 million inhabitants, the 6th most populous. Saxony’s history stretches back over a thousand years. The state also contains the Saxony wine region, which, together with Saale‑Unstrut, is one of Europe’s northernmost wine areas and one of only two German wine regions located in the former East Germany.

A working animal is a generally domesticated creature that humans train to carry out tasks. Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, starring Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, was released on 20 October 1995 and was filmed in India, London, and Switzerland between September 1994 and August 1995.

The passage identifies two different people named Tim(othy) Roth:  
1. Timothy Simon Roth (born 14 May 1961) is an English actor and director.  
2. Tim Roth (born 6 December 1975) is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and sole remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic/progressive death‑metal band Into Eternity.
Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe in 1986, and the couple had three children.

Sean Penn, who debuted in Taps (1981), gained early notice with films such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High (1982), At Close Range (1986), State of Grace (1990) and Carlito’s Way (1993). His breakthrough as a leading actor came with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and Berlin’s Best Actor award. Subsequent Academy Award nominations followed for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001). Penn won the Best Actor Oscar twice: for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008). His fourth feature film, Into the Wild (2007), received critical acclaim and two Oscar nominations.

Early volcanic outgassing produced Earth’s first atmosphere and the oceans, but this atmosphere lacked oxygen and was inhospitable to today’s life. As Earth cooled, a solid crust formed and liquid water became stable on the surface. Ongoing plate tectonics keeps reshaping oceans, continents, and the life they support. Human‑dominated biological activity now strongly modifies the atmosphere and surface systems—affecting the ozone layer, greenhouse‑gas levels, soil fertility, and air and water quality. Overall, water presently covers 71 % of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk (Godthåb) is Greenland’s capital and largest city, situated within the municipality of Sermersooq.

“How to Train Your Dragon 2” is written and directed by Dean DeBlois. Its voice cast includes all the main actors from the first film—Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz‑Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig—plus new additions Cate Blanchett (as Valka), Djimon Hounsou (as Drago), and Kit Harington.

“Down with Love” refers to two works:

1. A 2003 romantic‑comedy film directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson and David Hyde Pierce. The movie is a stylistic homage to 1959–1964 Doris Day/Rock Hudson sex comedies such as “Pillow Talk,” “Lover Come Back” and “Send Me No Flowers.”

2. A Taiwanese TV series first aired on free‑to‑air China Television (CTV) from 31 Jan 2010 to 23 May 2010, Sundays 22:00–23:30, and on cable Gala Television (GTV) Channel 28 from 2 Feb 2010 to 30 May 2010, Sundays 20:00–21:30.
“Paris,” the album by Paris Hilton, blends various genres in its production, incorporating reggae, soul, and pop‑rock elements.

“Stripes” is a 1981 American buddy military comedy directed by Ivan Reitman. It stars Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy, and marks early significant film roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, with early appearances by Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and to Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer noted for her song “Love or Lust,” featured in the film Deep Cover, and for providing choruses on landmark West Coast rap tracks, including Snoop Dogg’s “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

At the University of Mississippi, about 55 % of undergraduates and 60 % of all students are from Mississippi, 23 % of the student body are minorities, and international students come from 90 different countries.
“The Mighty Ducks” was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet–Kerner Productions, and it was distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy played:
• Jenny Matrix in the web series “Video Game High School” (2012–2014)
• Anna Martin in Lifetime’s dark comedy‑drama “Unreal” (2015)
• Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller “Quantico” (current role)

Martin Van Buren (1782–1862) was a Democratic politician who became the 8th U.S. President (1837–1841). Earlier he served under Andrew Jackson as the 10th Secretary of State (1829–1831) and the 8th Vice President (1833–1837). A key organizer of Jackson’s 1828 campaign, Van Buren briefly held the governorship of New York before joining Jackson’s cabinet. After resigning as Secretary of State—helping defuse the Petticoat affair—he received a recess appointment as U.S. minister to Britain.

Camden, New Jersey hosts two higher‑education institutions:  
1. Rutgers University–Camden, established in 1926 as the South Jersey Law School.  
2. Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, opened in 2012.

Michigan is a U.S. state located in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions. It ranks 10th in population and 11th in total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River. Uniquely composed of two peninsulas, Michigan is also a leading state for recreational boating.

In the 1930s Penguin Books transformed publishing by selling high‑quality fiction and non‑fiction paperbacks for sixpence through Woolworths and other high‑street shops, making literature affordable for the mass market.
The 2008 film "Australia" was produced at four locations: Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country singer‑songwriter, actor and philanthropist credited with popularizing country music globally.  
“Excuse My French” is:  
1. The debut studio album of American rapper French Montana.  
2. A 2014 Egyptian comedy film by Amr Salama, drawn from his own middle‑school experiences after returning from Saudi Arabia; initially labeled “too sensitive” by censors, the script was revised while retaining its focus on religious discrimination.
In 2013, Derek Hough starred in "Make Your Move," a South Korean‑American independent dance film inspired by Romeo and Juliet.

“Bad Romance” is a single by Lady Gaga from her 2009 EP The Fame Monster. After an early demo leaked, Gaga debuted the finished track at Alexander McQueen’s Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009, then issued the single’s cover art. The song topped charts worldwide, selling about 12 million copies and ranking among the best‑selling singles ever. The title “Bad Romance” is also used for a separate work: Les Mauvais Romans, a 2011 independent drama film.

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, including the franchises Shrek (plus its prequel‑spinoff Puss in Boots), Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls, as well as stand‑alone hits like Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013), and Home (2015). Additionally, DreamWorks co‑produces Trollhunters, a computer‑animated fantasy TV series for Netflix, created by Guillermo del Toro with Double Dare You.

Chris Eubank (born 8 Aug 1966) is a British former professional boxer who fought from 1985–1998.  
His son, Chris Eubank Jr. (born 18 Sep 1989), is an active British boxer. He has held the IBO super‑middleweight title since Feb 2017, previously held the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016. As of May 2017 he is ranked 5th at super‑middleweight by BoxRec, 7th at middleweight by The Ring, and 8th by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush (born July 8, 1982) is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist, recognized for her roles in the films John Tucker Must Die (2006), The Hitcher (2007), and The Narrows (2008).

Rupert Murdoch is the current chairman and acting CEO of Fox News and, following the 28 June 2013 split of News Corporation, retained full control as chairman and CEO of its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox—the world’s second‑largest media conglomerate.  
His younger son, James Rupert Jacob Murdoch (born 13 December 1972), an Australian‑British‑American businessman, is the CEO of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was Israel’s second‑highest‑earning actress/model, earning mainly from acting; she trailed only Bar Refaeli and out‑earned Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR) was an American rock band active during the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually identified by a radiographic examination (an x‑ray).
The South Wales Coalfield (Welsh: Maes glo De Cymru) is a large area in south Wales noted for its abundant coal deposits, particularly in the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental club football competition for leading teams from North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, run by CONCACAF. It began in 1962 under the name CONCACAF Champions' Cup.

Mary of Teck became queen mother when her eldest son Edward took the throne in 1936, but he abdicated that same year to marry Wallis Simpson. She then supported her second son, Albert (George VI), who reigned until his death in 1952. Mary died in 1953 during the early reign of her granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II, before Elizabeth’s coronation.
The film “Poseidon” earned approximately $181.7 million worldwide on a production budget of $160 million.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series began in 1996; Omar Epps and Joe Morton share the record for most wins, with three apiece.

Human trafficking involves trading people for forced labor, sexual slavery, or other commercial exploitation. The ILO estimates that forced labor alone generates about $150 billion annually (2014). Among trafficked victims, 68 %—14.2 million—are exploited for labor, 22 %—4.5 million—for sexual purposes, and 10 %—2.2 million—under state‑imposed forced labor.
“Rio” is a 2011 film whose sequel, “Rio 2,” was released on April 11, 2014.

The passage discusses two different rulers named Francis I.

1. Francis I (Franz Stefan, François‑Étienne, 1708–1765) was Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, although his wife exercised the real authority.

2. Francis I of France (François Ier, 1494–1547) was the first Valois‑Angoulême king, ruling from 1515 to 1547. Nicknamed “Francis of the Large Nose,” “the Grand Colas,” and the “Knight‑King,” he personally led wars against his rival Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain. After failing to defeat Charles V, he forged the controversial Franco‑Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent. One of their confrontations was the Italian War of 1536–1538 between Francis I and Charles V.

Peking University (PKU/Beida) is a leading research university in Beijing. Founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the ancient Imperial Academy, it was China’s first modern national university and initially acted as the nation’s education ministry. A member of the C9 League, it is consistently ranked as the top higher‑education institution in mainland China.
Lemmy was noted for his striking look—particularly his mutton‑chop sideburns—as well as his gravelly voice and distinctive bass‑playing style.
Global warming threatens human food security by reducing crop yields and may force people to abandon populated areas as sea levels rise.
“Australia” is a 2008 Australian‑American‑British epic romantic historical adventure drama directed by Baz Luhrmann and starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
