Michael Dwayne Vick (born June 26, 1980) is a former American football quarterback who spent 13 NFL seasons, chiefly with the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a wide range of traditional expressions and practices: songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and activities like traditional food‑ and craft‑making. Its oral traditions specifically feature tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit created over 400 informative yet entertaining propaganda and training films and additionally trained combat cameramen.

• Author James Jones won the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel “From Here to Eternity,” which was soon adapted into a film and, decades later, a television series.

• Basketball player James Jones averaged 25 points per game as a high‑school senior (Class 6A Player of the Year, First‑Team All‑State), won three NBA titles (two with the Miami Heat, one with the Cleveland Cavaliers), reached seven straight NBA Finals with LeBron James by 2017, ranked third in league three‑point percentage in 2007‑08, and captured the 2011 NBA Three‑Point Contest crown.
In 1999, the American Film Institute named Humphrey Bogart the greatest male star of Classic American cinema.

Computer animation creates animated images; an example is “Trollhunters,” an American computer‑animated fantasy TV series for Netflix, created by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced in 2009 that he was resigning from WWE, with the resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor best known for playing the Fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974–1981—the longest run in the role—and for narrating the comedy series Little Britain. Beyond acting, he has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and other TV series.
Angelsberg is a small town within the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

Hanford Site is not only undergoing cleanup; it also contains the Columbia Generating Station nuclear power plant and hosts research facilities like the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a prominent, non‑Cabinet senior official appointed directly by the President to serve as the administration’s chief spokesperson, briefing the media and public on the President, senior executives, and policies; the post does not require Senate confirmation and is held at the President’s pleasure.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State” for the bluegrass in its fertile pastures, includes a central Bluegrass Region that contains Louisville and Lexington. The state is noted for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
“Broken Bridges” is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston. Kelly Preston’s other noted films include “The Cat in the Hat” and “Old Dogs.”
Kesha Rose Sebert (born March 1, 1987), formerly known as Ke$ha, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper.
On May 5, 2017, two new versions of “Despacito” were released: an electronic remix by Major Lazer and DJ MOSKA, and an urban remix produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional‑wrestling super‑card run by the NWA and later WCW from 1983‑2000.  
• 1983‑1986 shows ran on closed‑circuit TV; Starrcade 1985 is one example.  
• After the WWF scheduled Survivor Series in 1987 and demanded cable exclusivity, Starrcade also moved to pay‑per‑view, becoming the NWA’s first PPV event.  
• Starrcade 1997 marked the 15th edition of the PPV.  
• In 2014 the WWE Network added the 1983‑1986 closed‑circuit events to its PPV library and labeled them TV‑MA for violence, noting the harsh “I Quit” match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum T.A.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian Bollywood stunt and action choreographer as well as a film director.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first show created expressly for the referenced service and the franchise’s first new television series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.
Terry Crews was an NFL defensive end/linebacker for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also played in the World League of American Football for the Rhein Fire.

“Excuse My French” is both the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana and the title of a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, drawn from his own middle‑school experiences after returning from Saudi Arabia. In addition, the passage notes that Benjamin Paul Ballance‑Drew (Plan B/Ben Drew, born 22 October 1983) is a British hip‑hop recording artist who is also an actor, film director and producer.
A floppy disk (or diskette) is a disk storage medium made of a thin, flexible magnetic disk enclosed in a rectangular plastic case lined with dust‑removing fabric.

Guatemala faced chronic instability and civil strife in the mid‑to‑late 19th century, and from 1960–1996 it endured a brutal civil war between a U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military carried out genocidal massacres of the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments designed for grasping and holding objects; outside of medical contexts they are commonly known as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
“The Closer” launched its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after its sixth season concluded as the highest‑rated drama on cable.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the protagonist of the ABC drama series “Lost.” The show aired on ABC from September 22, 2004 to May 23, 2010, running six seasons with 121 episodes, and its first season averaged about 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who, beginning in 2011, shifted toward dramatic roles. His credits since then include The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe (all 2011); The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike (all 2012); The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club (2013); Interstellar (2014); and The Sea of Trees and Free State of Jones (both 2016). The 2012 film Mud, in which he stars, also features Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is a writer and musician noted for:
• Authoring books, notably “Deep Blues.”
• Writing music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone.
• Producing blues recordings and the “Deep Blues” film soundtrack.
• Playing clarinet in the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912‑1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who became head of the Mount Rushmore project after his father, sculptor Gutzon Borglum—who designed and directed the monument from 1927 until his death in March 1941—passed away.

“Underdog” is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau, written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

“The 100” is a TV series about a group of teen survivors—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first people sent from the space habitat “The Ark” back to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The story also highlights figures still on the Ark: Clarke’s mother Dr. Abby Griffin, council member Marcus Kane, and Chancellor Thelonious Jaha (Wells’s father).

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering humanitarian aid project that, despite later financial difficulties, proved highly successful and influential by raising significant awareness and funds and by inspiring later efforts such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is an influential Indian filmmaker credited by the media with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and reshaping Indian cinema as a whole.

On August 27, 1858, during the second of the seven Lincoln‑Douglas debates in Freeport, Illinois, Senator Stephen A. Douglas set out what became known as the Freeport Doctrine. The Lincoln‑Douglas debates pitted Republican challenger Abraham Lincoln against Democratic incumbent Douglas for the Illinois U.S. Senate seat. The debates at Freeport, Quincy, and Alton attracted particularly large crowds from surrounding states, reflecting the national urgency of the slavery question.

“Easy A” is a 2010 American teen comedy directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and features Emma Stone alongside Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O’Brien, October 4, 1941) is an American writer of gothic fiction, Christian literature and erotica. She launched her career with “Interview with the Vampire” in 1976 while in California and produced sequels during the 1980s; initial reviews were mixed but wider acclaim followed in that decade. Rice was married to poet‑painter Stan Rice from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey. It had 77,344 residents at the 2010 U.S. Census, making it the state’s 12th most populous municipality. Around the start of the 20th century its population was largely European immigrants. A city is defined here as a large, permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the original screenplay for The Canyons, a critically derided 2013 American erotic thriller‑drama directed by Paul Schrader.

The passage explains that the Lincoln–Douglas Debates, called the Great Debates of 1858, consisted of seven public debates in seven Illinois towns between Republican Senate challenger Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas.

Homer is the name given by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, the two foundational epics of Greek literature. Additionally, “The Thicket” is a mystery/suspense novel by American writer Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a U.S. Navy SEAL sniper who was shot and killed by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four‑member rock band featuring Soundgarden’s Chris Cornell (vocals/rhythm guitar) and Rage Against the Machine’s Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass, backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums).

Brad Wilk, originally the drummer for Greta (1990), co‑founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. He drummed for Rage (1991–2000, 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007) and, as of 2016, plays in Prophets of Rage alongside Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B‑Real, and DJ Lord.

Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, comprises vocalist Zack de la Rocha, bassist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, in partnership with Atlantic Records. In 2010 she issued her critically acclaimed debut full‑length studio album, “The ArchAndroid,” a concept‑album sequel to her first EP, released through Bad Boy Records.
“Winter’s Tale” is a novel written by Mark Helprin and first published in 1983.

Lake Providence is the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana. At the University of Mississippi, about 55 % of undergraduates and 60 % of all students are from Mississippi, 23 % are minorities, and international students come from 90 different countries.
The series “Flaked” was renewed in July 2016 for a six‑episode second season, scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr twice served in the New York State Assembly (1784–1785, 1798–1799), was New York State Attorney General (1789–1791), represented New York as a U.S. senator (1791–1797), and ultimately became vice president.

Soyuz is a series of Soviet spacecraft, designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia), originally for the nation’s manned lunar programs. Launched by the Soyuz rocket, it flew 8 unmanned test missions followed by 19 manned flights, succeeded the Voskhod craft, and is still in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Tensions led vocalist Zack de la Rocha to leave Rage Against the Machine, causing the band to split. De la Rocha pursued a modest solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with ex‑Soundgarden singer Chris Cornell; Audioslave released three albums before breaking up in 2007. That same year Rage Against the Machine reunited, playing Coachella in April 2007. Rage’s fourth studio album, “Renegades,” had previously been released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX—also known as the BSE 30—is a free‑float, market‑weighted index comprising 30 financially robust companies on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one of these constituents; it is traded on the BSE, the National Stock Exchange of India, and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost nation on Southeast Asia's Indochina Peninsula. Home to about 92.7 million people, it ranks 14th in global population and 9th in Asia. The country borders China (north), Laos (north‑west), Cambodia (south‑west), and, across adjacent seas, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia. Since 2000 it has recorded some of the world’s fastest economic growth—topping the Global Growth Generators Index in 2011—and remains one of only four one‑party socialist states that formally uphold communism.
“Dreamer” is a 2005 American sports‑drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh (executed 23 March 1931) was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic violent actions against British rule and subsequent execution at age 23 turned him into a celebrated folk hero of the Indian independence movement.
Aparshakti Khurana entered Bollywood with Aamir Khan’s 2016 Hindi‑language biographical sports drama “Dangal,” directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (James Stuart, 19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own parliaments, laws and judiciaries, they were united under his personal rule. James strongly promoted creating a single Anglo‑Scottish parliament and frequently clashed with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. An original core cast member of the soap Shortland Street, she is also known for playing Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, and Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, as well as appearing in the film Separation City (2009) and the series Rake. Her most notable recent role was Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, where she starred for four years before leaving in 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who starred in Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

“Artpop” earned mixed critical reviews but was a commercial success: it debuted at No. 1 on the US Billboard 200 with 258 000 first‑week sales, became Lady Gaga’s second straight US chart‑topper, has sold 757 000 copies in the US, and, with 2.3 million worldwide sales, was the ninth best‑selling album of 2013.
Stadium Arcadium, released in 2006, was John Frusciante’s fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers and the band’s last record to feature him; he confirmed his departure in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, introduced policies called Thatcherism; though controversial, she is still regarded as one of Britain’s most influential leaders, with debates over her policies ongoing.
Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who also writes weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who, besides his acting roles, has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia (officially València) is the capital of the Valencian Community in Spain. It is the country’s third‑largest city, housing about 800,000 people in its urban core, and forms Spain’s third‑largest metropolitan area with 1.7–2.5 million residents.
Buffy Summers is a character who was played by Kristy Swanson in the original film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the later television series.
“Make It or Break It” ended with its third and final season; the cancellation was announced on April 26, 2012, and the series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a branch of computational linguistics that turns spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science and electrical engineering. Its applications range from voice dialing, call routing and home‑automation control to search, data entry, document preparation, speech‑to‑text tools and aircraft voice input. Recent progress, driven by deep‑learning techniques, has led to widespread industry adoption; companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek and CDAC base their systems on these methods.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and comic‑book store owner who co‑founded the event originally called the Golden State Comic Book Convention (later San Diego Comic‑Con) and became its chairman in 1970. The convention began in 1970 in San Diego, organized by Shel Dorf, Richard Alf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, before adopting the name San Diego Comic Book Convention (now San Diego Comic‑Con International).
“Fist of Legend” is a remake of the 1972 film “Fist of Fury,” which originally starred Bruce Lee.

France’s Victor Dubuisson and South Africa’s Jaco Van Zyl share the lead on 16‑under after both shot 67s. One stroke behind are Rory McIlroy—who recorded a third consecutive 67 that featured an eagle at the 13th—and Thailand’s Kiradech Aphibarnrat on 15‑under. McIlroy, seeking his first win since May and a third Race to Dubai crown, feels a lower round is possible despite two earlier three‑putt bogeys. The Northern Irishman recently returned from an ankle‑ligament rupture suffered in July. England’s Chris Wood is two further back at –13, with compatriot Richard Bland on –12. McIlroy currently leads Danny Willett in the Race to Dubai standings by 271,214 points, with three tournaments left after this event.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of Bahrain’s main opposition group al‑Wefaq, says national dialogue will only work if the government offers “concrete solutions” and allows reform‑minded Crown Prince Salman al‑Khalifa to negotiate. Hard‑liners around long‑serving Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al‑Khalifa resist concessions, fearing greater opposition demands. Salman recalls that a 2011 seven‑point reform deal reached with the crown prince collapsed when GCC troops entered Bahrain hours later. He urges the U.S.—hoping new Secretary of State John Kerry will press harder—and the U.K. to apply open, stronger pressure for human‑rights and democratic reforms instead of private appeals. Despite a ban on public gatherings, al‑Wefaq will continue peaceful protests and insists that 13 jailed opposition leaders be freed, warning dialogue will fail without their participation.

Christopher Hogwood, pioneering conductor and scholar of the early‑music movement, has died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. His funeral will be private, with a public memorial to follow.  

Key achievements  
• Founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973, directing it for about 30 years, touring six continents and making 200‑plus recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments.  
• Produced landmark recordings such as the 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson, later ranked among BBC Music Magazine’s top 20 of all time.  

Career and teaching  
• Studied keyboard at Cambridge University and with Zuzana Růžičková and Gustav Leonhardt.  
• Early roles: keyboard player/musicologist with the Academy of St Martin in the Fields and founder member of the Early Music Consort of London.  
• Held posts as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge and Cornell universities.  

Tributes from colleagues highlight his generosity, scholarship and lasting influence on historically informed performance.

• Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims in the year to 31 March 2016, five fewer than the previous year, the lowest annual total since 1976 and half the level of nine years ago.  
• Only one 2015‑16 case remains unsolved.  
• Sharp instruments were used in 51 % of killings (29 cases), almost all involving knives (26).  
• Police identified 31 % of accused persons as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol plus drugs.  
• Justice Secretary Michael Matheson welcomed the decline but stressed continued education, enforcement, community support and action on alcohol misuse; the government will keep funding prevention projects and law‑enforcement resources.  
• Labour justice spokeswoman Claire Baker urged caution, noting past upward revisions of homicide figures, record‑high sexual crime and a 27 % rise in attempted murder/serious assault.  
• The 2014‑15 homicide total was revised from 59 to 62 after three deaths were reclassified.

Bournemouth lost 2‑1 away to Sunderland, handing the Black Cats their first Premier League win of the season. Dan Gosling put the Cherries ahead—their first goal in three games—but Sunderland hit back through Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and held on despite Steven Pienaar’s red card. Manager Eddie Howe said the defeat was not due to a lack of confidence, noting the chances created and recalling the six goals scored against Hull, and stressed the need to move on.

Australian PM Tony Abbott defended Australia’s policy of intercepting and detaining boat‑arriving migrants offshore, arguing that stopping the boats is the only way to prevent deaths at sea. A New York Times editorial labelled the policy “brutal,” “inhumane,” and of “dubious legality,” warning Europe not to copy it. Abbott, reacting to the image of drowned Syrian child Alan Kurdi, repeated that Australia had halted “illegal boats.” He also sparked criticism from Australian Jewish groups by stating that Islamic State is worse than the Nazis; they called the comparison “injudicious,” noting the Holocaust’s unique, state‑planned genocide. Abbott later affirmed his remarks while saying he was not “ranking evil.”

The United States has suspended the bilateral talks with Russia that were meant to uphold last month’s Syrian ceasefire. Washington says Moscow and Syrian government forces intensified strikes on Aleppo, hit hospitals, blocked aid, and likely bombed an aid convoy, killing hundreds of civilians and trapping about 250,000 people in the city’s rebel‑held east. Russia denies responsibility, regrets the U.S. move, and claims Washington failed to separate jihadist fighters from moderate rebels or improve Aleppo’s humanitarian situation. Planned U.S.–Russian coordination in Geneva has been canceled and American personnel withdrawn, though limited military “de‑confliction” contacts will continue.

Policy Exchange’s “Ending Expensive Social Tenancies” report proposes that councils routinely sell social‐housing properties worth more than the average home in their region when they fall vacant (about 3.5 % of stock each year, roughly 28,500 homes).  
Key figures:  
• 816,000 of the UK’s 3.78 million social homes (21.8 %) are above‑average in value; selling those that become empty could raise about £4.5 billion a year net (or up to £159 billion if all were sold).  
• The proceeds could finance construction of 80,000–170,000 new social homes annually and cut the 1.8 million‑strong waiting list by an estimated 500,000 households.  

Government response: Downing Street backs the idea, saying councils should already be maximising the value of their stock.  

Supporters’ argument: The policy would fund the largest council‑house building programme since the 1970s and be “fairer” than leaving a single “lucky family” in a high‑value property; 73 % of surveyed residents reportedly favour the principle.  

Opposition: Labour, some MPs and the National Housing Federation warn it could force low‑income families out of expensive areas, break up mixed communities and create segregation; Labour instead wants a bank‑bonus tax to fund 250,000 affordable homes.  

Context: The coalition cut previous Labour building budgets by 60 %, but claims new reforms and £19.5 billion of mixed funding will still deliver up to 170,000 affordable homes.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, was found dead at his Swansea home amid a local measles epidemic that has reached 942 cases and led to 83 hospitalizations since November. Although lab tests confirmed he had measles, an initial examination could not determine if it caused his death; an inquest and further tests are pending. Colfer‑Williams, recently treated for asthma, developed a full‑body rash after discharge and saw an out‑of‑hours GP on 17 April, the day before he died. His family, none of whom currently have measles (his three‑year‑old daughter is vaccinated), do not know how he contracted the infection.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical sexual offence against a boy under 16, allegedly committed in 2001. He is scheduled to appear later at North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

National League rivals Gateshead and Guiseley shared a 1‑1 draw that stretched the hosts’ unbeaten run to nine matches and the visitors’ to six. Guiseley struck first on 15 minutes when James Hurst’s throw reached Jake Lawlor to tap into an open goal. Gateshead pressed, Liam Hogan producing a vital block and keeper Jonny Maxted denying Wes York before the break. The equaliser arrived on 62 minutes: substitute Derek Asamoah slipped, allowing York to curl a shot into the top‑right corner. Yellow cards went to Simon Walton (Guiseley) and Gus Mafuta (Gateshead); several late substitutions were made by both sides.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to replace two stands at its football ground to boost capacity instead of building a new Ashton Vale stadium stalled by a town‑green bid. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown told a Tuesday shareholder meeting that, with Bristol City Council approval already secured (November), the Section 106 agreement will be signed shortly; after a six‑week judicial‑review window, work will start in May provided no review is lodged by March.

Cuadrilla has halted fracking at its Preese Hall, Lancashire, site after a 1.5‑magnitude earthquake—the second local tremor since March (the first was 2.3 on 1 April near Poulton‑le‑Fylde). The company will spend several weeks analysing British Geological Survey (BGS) data before deciding whether to restart. BGS instruments show both quakes occurred about 2 km deep and within 2 km of the drill site, suggesting a common cause; the latest was felt by at least one resident. BGS notes that injecting pressurised fluids, as in shale‑gas extraction, can trigger earthquakes and is monitoring the area. While U.S. fracking has faced environmental criticism, a recent UK Commons committee backed the practice, saying risks can be managed with strict regulation.

Angus Carpenter, a 62‑year‑old Liverpool bagpiper, was tried on three fraud charges after busking in April 2015 with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes. A jury found him guilty on one count—concluding he gave the impression he was collecting money for the charity—but cleared him of the other two. Carpenter said he was only busking and had previously piped for the campaign; the charity’s chairman confirmed he had permitted the banner’s design but not its use for fundraising. Sentencing is set for January.

Ipswich Town beat Queens Park Rangers 3‑0 in a Championship match at Portman Road.  

Key events  
1. Grant Ward’s scuffed effort opened the scoring.  
2. Luke Varney doubled the lead when QPR keeper Alex Smithies sliced a clearance straight to him, leaving an empty net.  
3. Cole Skuse’s long shot broke to Tom Lawrence, who finished calmly for the third.  
QPR’s best moment was substitute Sandro’s late header against the post.

Match context  
• Ipswich had struggled for goals recently (scoreless in 7 of previous 10) but created numerous chances, with Berra and Skuse going close.  
• QPR have now won only once in six away games and rarely threatened.  
• The result lifts Mick McCarthy’s side four places to 14th, pushing Ian Holloway’s Rangers down to 15th.

Manager reactions  
• McCarthy praised Varney’s work‑rate and said Smithies’ error “set us up to win.”  
• Holloway called the second goal a “calamity,” criticised his team’s reaction, and demanded greater mental toughness.

Wells, aged 23, made 373 runs in last season’s T20 Blast, averaging 28.69 with a 138.66 strike rate. He says the club’s coach‑led, elite‑performance environment shows it is moving in the right, exciting direction and motivating the players.

The Reds, fifth in National Two South, earned a second straight win by defeating third‑placed Chinnor 29‑12. Coach Steve Churcher credited front‑row trio Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams, noting the front five made over 70 tackles. With seven of their next eight matches against lower‑ranked opponents (the exception being leaders Old Elthamians), Churcher insists the side must improve on what he called a determined but incomplete display.

Police have arrested Nazrul (also known as Nazu), a 28‑year‑old Bangladeshi national, at a Kolkata railway station for the 14 March attack in Ranaghat where a 74‑year‑old nun was raped and a convent school robbed and ransacked. He is the sixth of eight identified suspects—the other five detainees all named him as the rapist, while two suspects remain at large. Nazrul allegedly fled to Bangladesh after being caught on CCTV and was captured on a tip‑off about his return. Earlier, police had arrested Milon Sarkar, said to be the gang’s leader, though his exact role is unclear. The crime sparked nationwide outrage and street protests across India.

The interactive video (best viewed full‑screen) features Robert Opie, founder of London’s Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, explaining why consumer buying habits change—highlighting the impact of domestic freezers, washing powder and cheaper imports on UK shopping trends. Interactive sections also examine shifts in the ownership and ranking of leading UK brands. Because some older browsers cannot run the interactive version, a non‑interactive version and supporting links (on China’s overseas ownership, food‑freezing tips, the BBC Good Food annual top‑20 UK brands survey and information on the Museum) are provided.

Two recent phone scams involved callers posing as BT technical support.  
1. On 15 September a 71‑year‑old Sandyhills woman was duped.  
2. Seven days later a Stranraer woman lost money the same way.  

In both cases the caller claimed to fix internet problems, obtained remote access to the victim’s computer and stole substantial sums. PC Siobhan Pellett warns the public to be extremely cautious of cold callers seeking remote access and to never disclose banking details, noting that legitimate banks and businesses do not request such information by phone.

• John Duffy, 37, has left Swinton Lions to become head coach of third‑placed Championship club Featherstone Rovers on a one‑year deal.  
• The Scotland assistant coach will take charge for Featherstone’s final league game against Toulouse on Saturday ahead of the Super 8 Qualifiers.  
• Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy for his “remarkable job” in tough circumstances at Swinton.  
• Swinton have promoted Duffy’s former assistant, Stuart Littler, to replace him.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, Porthcawl RNLI, a medic and a coastguard helicopter rescued an unconscious rider with head injuries and hypothermia from wet sand at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve; after treatment she was airlifted to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

At the UN‑run World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva, more than 160 countries agreed to reserve a specific radio frequency so satellites can pick up ADS‑B signals from aircraft. This will enable real‑time, worldwide flight tracking and close the 70 % coverage gaps of today’s ground‑radar system—shortcomings highlighted by the 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370. The International Telecommunication Union hailed the swift decision, while the International Civil Aviation Organisation has set November 2016 for airlines to begin sending position reports at least every 15 minutes (more frequently in emergencies).

Julian Hernandez, missing from Alabama since August 2002 when he was 5, has been found alive at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. A college‑application snag led to an FBI tip on 30 October; the FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing & Exploited Children confirmed his identity, and his mother has been notified. Bobby Hernandez, 53, long suspected in the abduction, is now jailed in Ohio on abduction and records‑tampering charges, held on $250,000 bail for obtaining a falsified driver’s licence in 2012.

A 2 March blaze at Recovered Fuels Shipping Ltd’s Duncan Street waste site kept firefighters on scene for several days, disrupting rail services. Although Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service, which had inspected the premises nine times in the past year, said the operator Asset and Land Group was “broadly compliant” with fire‑safety law, earlier GMFRS concerns about potential risks prompted joint inspections with the Environment Agency. The EA has now revoked the site’s environmental permit, barring further waste acceptance after 7 August unless the firm appeals, and ordering removal of all existing waste. The company could not be reached for comment and the fire’s cause is still unknown.

Pro‑Kremlin party “A Just Russia” has submitted two bills reacting to the Ukraine crisis, especially events in Crimea.

1. Territorial‑accession bill  
   • Would let Russia admit a foreign region if its leaders or a local referendum request it, without needing a treaty with the parent state.  
   • Justified as necessary when a neighbouring country is “disintegrating.”  
   • Targets Crimea, where many residents—especially in Sevastopol—already hold Russian passports.  
   • Mirrors Russia’s post‑2008 moves in Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

2. Fast‑track passport bill  
   • Removes fees, prior residence, financial‑support and citizenship‑renunciation requirements for Ukrainians.  
   • Applications could be filed at Russian missions until 1 August and passports issued within two months.  
   • Framed as protection for “Russian‑speaking” Ukrainians from a “brown threat.”

Party leader Sergei Mironov announced the passport plan in Sevastopol, and several Russian MPs and celebrities have travelled to Crimea in support.

McLaren, once among Formula 1’s dominant forces (182 wins, 12 drivers’ and 8 constructors’ titles), now regard a fourth‑row grid slot and a handful of points as success. Their decline began in 2013 when chassis design faltered; today the car is good but the returning Honda engine is weak. The team’s history has always swung between supremacy and slump: early 1970s titles were followed by a downturn that Ron Dennis reversed in the mid‑1980s (Honda era) and again with Mercedes in 1998‑99. Since their last constructors’ crown in 1998—and despite drivers like Alonso and Hamilton—titles have dried up and scandals hit (2007 ‘spygate’, 2009 ‘lie‑gate’). Dennis, back in charge, insists the slide is temporary and that McLaren‑Honda will be the next team to topple Mercedes, a belief that lured Fernando Alonso back. For now, belief is all they have; their reputation and Alonso’s hopes hinge on Honda delivering a competitive engine soon.

Tommy (Thomas) Baker, 44, was shot in the head and chest on 27 January outside Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market, Old Swan, Liverpool, and later died in hospital. Police believe the attackers had waited about an hour outside the gym before shooting him as he got into his car. Three Liverpool men (two aged 29, one aged 32) have been arrested and are being questioned. Detectives are still seeking a silver VW Polo that sped away via Balmoral, Molyneux and Queens Roads, and are urging people seen on nearby CCTV to come forward.

Five digital initiatives are helping people combine Christmas, technology and faith:

1. Everyday Church Online (UK) streams recorded services every Sunday. Viewers from 61 countries can chat during the broadcast. Its first Christmas series, “The Hope Awakens,” links Star Wars themes to the nativity.  

2. Guardians of Ancora is a free fantasy game for 8‑ to 11‑year‑olds (Android, iPhone, Kindle) in which “guardians” recover Bible stories; Christmas brings two new quests about Jesus’s birth. Forty‑five thousand players joined in the first four months.  

3. Viral nativity videos continue to attract viewers. “The Digital Story of Nativity” (2010) retells the story through social‑media updates and has nearly six million views, while the Churches Advertising Network’s “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle” sits at about 250,000 views but was refused UK cinema slots for being “too religious.”  

4. Next Manga has moved its widely distributed Bible‑based comics (e.g., “Manga Messiah”) to app and e‑book formats. The print version exists in 33 languages; 25,000 Arabic copies were recently sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees.  

5. Churches and Christian groups increasingly use Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to share short reflections and “lift people’s gaze,” with commentators suggesting that if Jesus were alive today, he’d be on Twitter.

An inquiry in Ebbw Vale is considering whether 250 ha (600 acres) of common land can be taken for a motor‑racing circuit, with supporters offering 320 ha (800 acres) of replacement land. Experts disagree on ecological impact: Natural Resources Wales questions whether the substitute land matches the original’s value but does not oppose the scheme outright, while developers claim a net biodiversity gain and Gwent Wildlife Trust disputes this. After the eight‑day hearing, the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will advise, and Welsh government ministers will decide the project’s fate.

• On 1 April, Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta reported that Chechen security forces had detained more than 100 men suspected of being gay, torturing them near Argun and killing at least three.

• The Russian LGBT Network, which is assisting victims, corroborated the account, saying detainees were beaten and given electric shocks; it warns that if Russia fails to act it will take the case to the International Criminal Court.

• Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied the allegations, asserting “there are no gay people in Chechnya.”

• In response to the article, Chechen Muslim clerics met on 3 April and adopted a resolution saying the report insulted their faith and Chechen men; they vowed “retribution” against the “instigators,” a statement Novaya Gazeta interprets as a threat to its journalists.

• Novaya Gazeta’s editor Dmitry Muratov rejected claims of insult and pledged to keep investigating human‑rights abuses.

• Past killings of Novaya Gazeta journalists Anna Politkovskaya and Natalia Estemirova, and of opposition figure Boris Nemtsov, have been linked to Chechen elements, heightening concerns for the paper’s staff.

• The newspaper urges Russian authorities to prevent violence against journalists, while the LGBT Network continues evacuating persecuted individuals from Chechnya.

Investing Solutions, a London lettings agency founded by Samir Patel, works hand‑in‑glove with Fresh Start Housing, a charity he later set up, to house single homeless men aged 35+.  Fresh Start refers clients it gets from other homeless groups; Investing Solutions then places several of them in one house and claims individual housing‑benefit payments.  Because benefit is paid per tenant, the sums it receives greatly exceed the single rent it passes to the private landlord, leaving large margins: in one example the firm drew £2,114 a month while the owner got £1,150, a £11,568 annual gross profit on that property alone.  Operating in seven London boroughs, it has become one of the UK’s biggest housing‑benefit recipients, taking more than £2.1 million from Wandsworth Council in the past two years.  

Tenants such as Nigel McCann report sub‑standard, unsafe conditions (no heating, rats, damp), prompting criticism from Crisis, which calls the charity–business set‑up “a new low.”  Patel says most rent is passed to landlords and Fresh Start is an independent charity that has housed 788 homeless people.  Local authorities insist they have teams to police private‑sector housing and safeguard public money.

Great Britain’s basketball team lost their final warm‑up game to the Netherlands despite leading for much of the night.  
Key facts:  
• Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon 13; Dutch guard Worthy De Jong had 18.  
• GB were up 35‑24 in Q2, fell behind early in Q3, regained the lead on three straight Gordon three‑pointers, but the Netherlands opened Q4 with a 10‑0 run to win 71‑60, holding off a late GB rally.  
• The match was Coach Joe Prunty’s last look at his full roster before he makes cuts for the six‑game EuroBasket qualifying campaign, which starts midweek in Hungary.  
• Prunty said GB must “compete on every play,” admitted the team “lost a little of our fire,” and praised Gordon for finding his rhythm in the third quarter.

Floyd Mayweather has now filed the required waiver asking the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) to let him and Conor McGregor wear 8‑ounce gloves for their 26 August bout at the 154‑lb limit, where rules normally mandate 10‑ounce gloves. The NAC will debate the request publicly on 16 August, with fighter safety its stated priority. 

The commission had already sanctioned the cross‑code fight—despite criticism from boxing figures—after executive director Bob Bennett reviewed McGregor’s record, sparring footage and factors such as his age (29 to Mayweather’s 40), size advantages and past knockdowns of noted boxer Nate Diaz. Bennett says McGregor is “good to go” and had the UFC star hire veteran referee Joe Cortez for acclimation to boxing rules.  

Cortez recently supervised a heated McGregor–Paulie Malignaggi spar that ended with the ex‑champion leaving camp amid leaked knock‑down images. A decision on glove size is still pending; lighter 8‑ounce gloves could make punches more damaging but cushion hands less.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, is losing its last two reporters as the Sunday Post shuts its London bureau on Friday. Reporters Gavin Sherriff (32 years on the street) and Darryl Smith (25 years) will leave, ending more than three centuries of newspaper activity that began with the Daily Courant in 1702. At its height the “Street of Shame” housed almost every national paper, thrived on smoky newsrooms and alcohol‑soaked pubs, and supplied about 85 % of the public’s news. Its decline started when Rupert Murdoch moved his titles to Wapping in 1986; by 1988 most papers had followed, adopting computerised printing and emptying Fleet Street’s offices, many of which are now shops and corporate headquarters. Sherriff plans to write memoirs and Smith will freelance, while veterans such as ex‑Sunday Express editor Robin Esser and author Liz Hodgkinson reflect that the celebrated, male‑dominated, hard‑drinking culture has finally reached its “last deadline.”

J.K. Rowling said that hostile tweets about her politics show her “personal line has been crossed,” but also remind her that most people are decent. She was heavily criticised on Twitter after giving £1 million to the anti‑independence campaign and, earlier, the same amount to Labour. Calling some abusers “bullies,” she blocked several she believed were SNP supporters, yet noted she’d had civil exchanges with other SNP backers. Rowling rejected any duty to shield a party’s image, laughed off a call to burn her books (“I’ll bring marshmallows”), and this all unfolded as the SNP won 56 of Scotland’s 59 Westminster seats, becoming the UK’s third‑largest party.

• University of Edinburgh has tracked 4,300 Edinburgh youngsters since 1998.  
• Poverty sharply increases youth crime and victimisation:
  – Deprived children are twice as likely as affluent peers to receive police action for the same offence and five times as likely to be placed on statutory supervision.  
  – Household poverty remains a strong predictor of offending even after other risk factors are controlled.  
  – Boys are three times more likely than girls to commit violence; poor girls are twice as likely as affluent girls.  
• Prior police contact is the best predictor of being out of education, work or training at 18, suggesting juvenile‑justice involvement deepens the poverty‑violence cycle.  
• Separate analysis shows Scotland’s overall crime drop has bypassed the most deprived areas, where high crime coincides with chronic ill‑health and unemployment.  
• Researchers question whether inequality is being tackled effectively; the Scottish government responds that recorded crime is at a 41‑year low and cites anti‑poverty initiatives.

Karl Haugh (25) died after being stabbed in the back during a fight in Kilkee’s Marian Estate shortly after 1 am on Sunday. Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush has been charged with assault causing serious harm and was remanded in custody until 14 August; two other arrested men were released pending DPP files. Gardaí allege Walsh and two companions entered the estate seeking Haugh, a brawl involving additional people erupted, and knives and golf clubs were used. A knife handle and blood‑stained blade were recovered at the scene. Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital around 6 am, and the incident has heightened local tension.

In May 2014 Sinn Féin MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted that former UDR soldier Tom Elliott had “harassed and shot” people, a claim he deleted within an hour. Elliott—now MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, with a clear Ministry of Defence record—sued for defamation. At the High Court Flanagan agreed to post a Twitter apology admitting the allegation was “untrue and wholly without foundation,” while Mr Justice Stevens reserved a decision on damages. The Assembly’s insurer has refused to cover Flanagan’s potential liability, a stance he is contesting separately. Elliott said the ruling vindicates him.

Hawick Knitwear, founded in 1874 and employing 230+ staff, has raised weekly sweater output from about 7,500 to 9,500 to meet stronger demand. Sales are being driven both by its new Hawick‑branded range, launched in January, and by growing private‑label orders. The firm—purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November—supplies customers across Europe (e.g., Sweden, Germany, Italy) and in the USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan. Hartop credits the production boost to rising domestic and overseas orders and expresses confidence in the company’s future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72‑year‑old lollipop lady, suffered severe head injuries last December when Brian Wright’s VW Golf hit her outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. At Luton Crown Court, Wright, 55, admitted striking her but denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, saying the low, setting sun had blinded him and he did not notice the red light. Prosecutors say other traffic had stopped while Blackburn, in high‑visibility clothing, was helping a mother and child cross. Wright apologised in court; Blackburn is now in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

NATO is staging exercise “Dynamic Mongoose” in the North Atlantic to sharpen anti‑submarine warfare skills amid increased Russian submarine patrols.  
• A German submarine, U‑33, plays the hostile target, trying to sink the command ship USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker while evading 10 NATO surface ships, helicopters and a French Atlantique maritime‑patrol aircraft.  
• New elements include a NATO research vessel deploying unmanned underwater drones for seabed scanning.  
• Russian submarine forces now total about 60 boats, are judged the world’s most advanced and quiet, and can remain undetected for months, heightening allied concern.  
• Britain’s elimination of its Nimrod fleet means the UK has no long‑range maritime‑patrol aircraft; it must call on allies for surveillance and is viewed as vulnerable—a gap likely to feature in the upcoming UK defence review.  
The exercise underlines both NATO’s determination to counter Russia’s growing under‑sea capability and the reliance of some members, notably Britain, on allied assets to do so.

UN officials warn that South Sudan’s escalating civil strife now risks “genocide” and “ethnic cleansing.” Since July fighting spread from Juba into the previously calm Equatoria region, prompting about 340,000 people—2,500 a day—to flee mainly to Uganda, the largest refugee out‑flow anywhere in 2016. Refugees describe Dinka soldiers and rival militias killing, raping and mutilating civilians along ethnic lines, with boys executed and women assaulted; entire communities such as Yei have emptied. Uganda grants each family land and shelter but is straining to serve nearly one million South Sudanese, including a quarter‑million in the new Bidi Bidi camp, while the UNHCR urges global pressure on South Sudan’s leaders.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super‑middleweight title. A former Norwich and Peterborough footballer, he turned professional boxer in 2013 and has eight wins and one draw from nine bouts. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, three‑time world champion Duke McKenzie.

Bridgwater Community Hospital will be replaced by a new £33 million facility, partly funded by £330 million of national NHS investment and the remainder by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. Planned for completion by autumn 2014 on Bowers Lane (subject to planning permission), the hospital will offer 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery‑led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X‑ray services and space for mobile scanners. The existing 1813 building is cramped, outdated and costly to maintain. The project follows the recent replacement of three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals and complements ongoing work at Musgrove Park Hospital’s Jubilee Building. Local clinicians say the new, modern environment will markedly improve patient care and service integration.

A man was shot near a black Mercedes outside a home on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, Sheffield, at about 13:35 GMT. He suffered a chest wound, was taken to Northern General Hospital, and died. The victim was believed to be part of a local family gathered for a celebration; relatives tried to help after the shot. Armed police cordoned off the scene. The killing follows several recent but previously north‑Sheffield shootings, including a 25‑year‑old wounded in Shiregreen, shots through an elderly couple’s window in Southey Green, and two January house shootings in High Green.

Three unaffiliated “hacktivist” movements dominate the cyber‑dimension of the Russia‑Ukraine conflict.

1. Ukrainian Cyber Troops  
   • Led from Kyiv by programmer Yevhen Dokukin.  
   • Operations: hack Russian interior‑ministry servers and police e‑mail, pass 35 GB of data to volunteers (Inform Napalm) who say it proves wounded Russian soldiers were evacuated from Ukraine; constant DDoS “artillery” that disables rebel websites; freezing rebels’ PayPal/WebMoney accounts; tapping public CCTV in separatist areas to watch troop movements; hijacking local network printers to spit out pro‑Ukrainian, anti‑Putin messages.  
   • Media allege their intelligence guides Ukrainian artillery, a claim the army denies.

2. Cyber Berkut (pro‑Russian/anti‑Western)  
   • Name taken from former Ukrainian riot police; mission is to obstruct Kyiv’s “genocide” and U.S. plans.  
   • Feats: defaced Ukrainian government sites during U.S. Vice‑President Joe Biden’s Kyiv visit (“Joseph Biden is the fascists’ master”); say they stole U.S. military‑aid documents from a Biden aide’s device; hacked Kyiv billboards to label Ukrainian leaders “war criminals”; claim to have sabotaged election vote‑counting, leaked defence data and Poroshenko’s website, and produced an unverified Facebook chat alleging Ukraine shot down MH17.

3. Anonymous International (a.k.a. b0ltai/Shaltay Boltay)  
   • Russian activist collective famed for publishing leaked Kremlin papers—source unknown (hacks or insiders).  
   • Posted a Russian fighter’s letter saying eastern Ukrainians don’t back the rebels and released e‑mails tied to ex‑FSB colonel Igor Girkin (Strelkov).  
   • Its website is now blocked in Russia.

Tactics shared across groups include leaking official documents, DDoS attacks, hijacking CCTV, billboards and printers, illustrating how cyberspace has become an extra battlefield alongside the shooting war.

At Holyrood’s final sitting before the 5 May election, several long‑serving MSPs gave valedictory speeches and announced they will not seek re‑election. Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears during farewells from Labour veteran Duncan McNeil, who urged the parliament to strengthen scrutiny by learning from Westminster, and from former first minister Alex Salmond. Salmond, stepping down after 17 years as an MSP, reiterated his view that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed new powers in the Scotland Bill while saying they fall short of referendum‑time promises, and signed off with “goodbye from me…for now,” lacing his remarks with trademark humour. Marwick praised his service “with distinction.” Former Conservative leader Annabel Goldie also made a light‑hearted farewell, saying she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

• Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care in Welsh residential homes.  
• She is gathering first‑hand evidence from residents, their relatives and friends, along with care staff, providers and public bodies.  
• The review will examine physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care‑home environment, aiming to spotlight good practice and expose poor care.  
• Findings will inform recommendations for care providers and authorities to improve residents’ lives.  
• Care Forum Wales backs the review’s goals but criticises the advisory panel for lacking anyone with direct residential‑care management or ownership experience.

Harbro Group, the Turriff‑based animal‑feed manufacturer and retailer, lifted pre‑tax profit by £0.8 m to £3.5 m in the year to June 2016, even though turnover slipped £1 m to just over £100 m. Growth was driven by rising international sales in Europe and new overseas markets. The firm also runs 19 Scottish Country Store outlets serving rural customers with feed, clothing, footwear and other supplies. While it notes recent volatility in agriculture and uncertainty over Brexit, the board believes the business is well placed to meet future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found murdered in a house on Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon; another man in his 80s was taken to hospital. Police are treating the death as murder and are urgently seeking 55‑year‑old Ian John McLoughlin (aka Ian John Baker), described as a 6 ft white male with greying collar‑length hair, last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three‑quarter trousers, and a dark‑ and light‑blue checked short‑sleeved shirt. The public is warned not to approach him and to contact police or Crimestoppers with information. Extra patrols have been deployed to reassure residents.

IMF Deputy Director David Lipton warned that the world economy is weakening, calling the situation “a delicate juncture.” His remarks followed data showing Chinese exports fell about 25% year‑on‑year. Reflecting these strains, the IMF expects to cut its current 3.4% global growth forecast in April, a blow to companies that have relied on continued Chinese expansion.

At a council scrutiny meeting about the troubled new Cowes chain ferry, leader Dave Stewart announced crossings will be free until 2 July and auditors will review the project. Since its 14 May launch the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended over training issues and damaged cars. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth warned businesses have lost nearly six months’ trade and asked for compensation; transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is negotiable, called the vessel a prototype with expected “teething problems,” noted electrical faults have been fixed, ramp extensions are being made to stop vehicle scraping, and grounding issues linked to seamanship have been resolved.

A multi‑vehicle crash on the A3 southbound near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT Thursday killed a 32‑year‑old man. A 33‑year‑old Waterlooville man was arrested on suspicion of causing death by careless driving. The road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening for police investigation.

London temp agency Matching Models, which supplies “beautiful and talented people,” posted a personal‑assistant advert specifying a “classic look, brown long hair with B–C cup.”  

Key points:  
• Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) branded the advert “appalling, unlawful and demeaning,” and will demand clarification of the firm’s hiring practices.  
• Women’s groups (Fawcett Society) say the ads are outdated and almost certainly breach equality law; employment lawyer James Lynas agrees they are “clearly unlawful” and could trigger unlimited discrimination claims.  
• Another agency advert seeks a “sexy female driver” for a wealthy client at £40‑50k, reinforcing concerns of sex discrimination and possible age bias.  
• Founder Nathalie Jansen defends the focus on appearance, citing client demands (e.g., specific cup size for a Dior outfit, blond‑blue‑eyed staff for an Indian businessman).  
• Under the UK Equality Act 2010 employers must not discriminate on sex, age, disability, etc.; specifying physical traits is only lawful if essential to the job, which critics say is not the case here.  
• EHRC warns the agency to modernize; failure could lead to legal action.

An office assistant named Mahesh opened fire in the hostel of Pragati Residential School, Bangalore, on Tuesday evening. He fatally shot 18‑year‑old student Gautami in the head and seriously wounded another student, Sirisha, who is now out of danger. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt and has been remanded in custody until 12 April. Such school shootings are extremely rare in India, which has strict gun‑control laws.

GLAAD’s “Where We Are on TV” report, examining scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series airing or cast between June 2016 and May 2017, tallied 278 regular or recurring LGBT characters, including 16 transgender characters (up from seven). While applauding record black representation on broadcast TV—boosted by shows such as Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder—the group criticized the deaths of more than 25 lesbian or bisexual female characters, among them Poussey Washington (Orange Is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth). GLAAD president Sarah Kate Ellis called the numerical gains encouraging but stressed they are only part of the overall picture.

Conservative MP David Mackintosh will not seek re‑election in Northampton South. His decision comes before a local party meeting where most officials intended to deselect him following BBC revelations that about £10.25 million loaned by the borough council—while he was its leader—to rebuild Northampton Town FC’s stadium has gone missing. The half‑built stand and the loan are under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities. Mackintosh denies any wrongdoing but says it is “the right time” for constituents to have a new MP.

Former Balch Springs, Texas police officer Roy Oliver, 37, was fired after shooting into a car of teens leaving a house party in April, killing 15‑year‑old Jordan Edwards and endangering four others. Video contradicted police claims that the car was reversing toward officers, showing it driving away. Oliver has been indicted for murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon; he faces 5–99 years in prison if convicted, which would mark the first Dallas‑county officer murder conviction since 1973. He is free on bail and no trial date has been set.

Melania Trump and 10‑year‑old Barron will remain in New York until Barron finishes the school year, a choice that has drawn both criticism and support on social media. Only two other First Ladies—Martha Washington (before the White House existed) and Anna Harrison (whose husband died quickly)—have not lived in the White House, though past presidents’ wives and children have sometimes delayed or limited their stays for schooling or personal reasons. Historians note such school‑related delays are not unprecedented: examples include the Clevelands, Tylers, Madisons, Clintons, and Obamas. Melania has long said Barron is her priority and may pursue a limited public role, possibly focusing on cyber‑bullying, while duties could be informally shared with daughter‑in‑law Ivanka Trump, echoing earlier instances where relatives like Martha Randolph, Angelica van Buren, or Chelsea Clinton helped with First‑Lady functions. Overall, each presidential family shapes White House life to fit its own needs.

A 72‑year‑old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Crown Office has directed the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, to examine Police Scotland’s initial response to a call made by the man. Police Scotland is cooperating, and PIRC will submit its report to the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service when finished.

A yellow wind warning has been issued, forecasting easterly gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h) that may disrupt road and sea travel. The warning covers Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys. Overnight winds already toppled a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, forcing the closure of Telford Road for most of Monday while crews clear the debris.

Belfast Giants beat Nottingham Panthers 4‑3.  
Scoring sequence: Derrick Walser (Giants) opened, Jeff Dimmen (Panthers) equalised; second period Mike Forney (Giants, PP) made it 2‑1, Andy Bohmbach levelled; Mike Radja and James Desmarais pushed Belfast to 4‑2 before David Ling cut it to 4‑3.  
The sides play again on Saturday in the double‑header’s second game. League standings: Nottingham 28 pts, Sheffield 27, Belfast 25.

• Chinese Grand Prix: Nico Rosberg emerged unchallenged after early chaos, taking his third win in as many races and moving 36 points clear of Mercedes team‑mate Lewis Hamilton in the championship.  

• Start‑line incidents: A first‑corner dive by Red Bull’s Daniil Kvyat forced Sebastian Vettel left into Ferrari partner Kimi Räikkönen; both cars needed new front wings and the safety car was deployed by lap four. Hamilton was also hit (by Felipe Nasr) and suffered wing damage.

• Key race turns:  
  – Daniel Ricciardo jumped Rosberg for the lead but a left‑rear puncture on lap three relinquished it.  
  – Mercedes left Rosberg out during the safety car; he then pulled away unopposed.  

• Final order (as stated): Rosberg first, Vettel second, Kvyat third, Ricciardo fourth, Räikkönen fifth; Felipe Massa finished ahead of Hamilton.

• Hamilton’s day: Started from the back, broke a wing on lap one, made five pit stops, drove most of the race with floor and barge‑board damage and could not overtake Massa late on.

• Aftermath: Vettel confronted Kvyat in the pre‑podium room over the opening‑lap dive; Kvyat defended the “risky” move. History shows no driver who wins the first three races has failed to secure that year’s title, underlining Hamilton’s uphill task.

Former Germany and Premier League midfielder Thomas Hitzlsperger has publicly come out as gay in Die Zeit, saying he wants to spark debate on a topic “simply ignored” in German football. He is the first high‑profile male footballer (and first to have played in the Premier League) to do so, and his announcement drew immediate praise from players such as Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, pundits like Gary Lineker, clubs including Bayern Munich, and senior football officials Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball. German politicians, including Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman and MP Volker Beck, also welcomed the “courageous step,” hoping it will erode the sport’s longstanding taboo on homosexuality. The move is viewed as a watershed in the fight against homophobia in German football, which until now had seen only lower‑league player Marcus Urban come out and where figures such as Philipp Lahm once advised gay athletes to stay silent.

Midfielder Steve Sidwell, 34, has played 32 league matches for Brighton this season, aiding their first promotion to the Premier League in 34 years. With his one‑year contract expiring, he wants a new deal, saying his performances show he merits another top‑flight chance and that the team can survive in the Premier League. Brighton clinched promotion by beating Wigan, hold a four‑point lead over Newcastle, and aim to secure the Championship title in their final two games. Sidwell previously had a 19‑game loan with Albion in 2015‑16 and has Premier League experience with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke.

Blackpool 1–1 Colchester United.

• 12' – Nathan Delfouneso crossed for Jamille Matt to tap in and give Blackpool the lead.  
• 17' – Kurtis Guthrie levelled from a corner after a scramble.  
• Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe kept the hosts in it with outstanding stops from Matthew Briggs and George Elokobi; Guthrie later hit the bar.  
• 75' – Tom Aldred missed a clear header that could have won it for Blackpool.  
• Stoppage time – Colchester substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a reckless tackle, leaving the visitors with ten men.  
• Yellow cards: Colin Daniel (BPL), Matthew Briggs, Tom Eastman (both COL), Andy Taylor (BPL).  
Result: honours even at Bloomfield Road.

29‑year‑old Reid, after 37 outings for the Sky Blues in their relegation season, has joined Colchester United. Having previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston, he could make his U’s debut in Wednesday’s EFL Cup first‑round match against Championship side Aston Villa. Colchester opened the league campaign with a 3‑1 defeat at Accrington on Saturday.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is creating a permanent police memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. Spurred by the March murder of PC Keith Palmer, the project will honour more than 1,400 officers and staff killed on duty over the past 250 years. Features include a brass screen whose leaf‑shaped cut‑outs, engraved with the fallen officers’ names, will be given to their families. The memorial costs £4 million; the government has pledged £1 million and the trust is seeking a further £1.5 million from the public. Completion is planned for 2019.

Manchester United beat Sunderland 1‑0, keeping them 15 points clear at the Premier League summit with eight games left. Sir Alex Ferguson highlighted the team’s record 25 wins in 30 matches (50 points from the last 54) and their chance to surpass Chelsea’s 95‑point 2005 tally. Their next league fixture is the Manchester derby against City, which United will enter with a 15‑point cushion. Ferguson plans changes for Monday’s FA Cup quarter‑final replay at Chelsea after injuries to Rafael, Anderson and goalkeeper David De Gea, while Wayne Rooney is fatigued from international duty. Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez and Rio Ferdinand should return. Ferguson praised Sunderland’s second‑half effort and credited United’s determined defending for the victory.

Google chairman Eric Schmidt told BBC Radio 4 that the firm has paid the amount of UK corporation tax legally required—about £10 million between 2006 and 2011—and will simply follow whatever rules the UK government sets in future. He argued taxes are set by politicians, not companies, and called for clearer international tax laws. UK MP Margaret Hodge proposed a new committee to scrutinize big firms’ tax practices in secret, while EU leaders have agreed on greater information‑sharing to curb avoidance. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland, is among the multinationals criticized for minimizing UK tax payments.

• NHS Improvement is trying to cut the NHS’s reliance on costly agency staff.  
• Agency spending was £3.6 bn last year; the target is to trim £1 bn by this financial year‑end.  
• An October pay cap (no more than 55 % above normal shift rates, senior managers exempt) has saved about £600 m but progress is still 10 % behind plan.  
• Agency staff remain expensive because trusts must also pay agency fees and employers’ costs.  
• The regulator will publish league‑tables of trusts’ agency use and collect details of each trust’s 20 top‑earning agency workers amid evidence of rates far above the cap (e.g. £130/h for a surgeon, £70/h for a junior doctor).  
• Chief executive Jim Mackey says the NHS “doesn’t have the money” for such high agency bills and that more improvement is needed.

Longford symbolizes Ireland’s post‑crash hardship, but signs of recovery are emerging.  
• Local retailer Matt O’Brien says turnover fell 30 % during the recession yet has risen over the past year after the shop diversified into childrenswear and dress‑hire.  
• Fianna Fáil claims government policy ignores the Midlands: Robert Troy notes no IDA client has visited Longford in four years and argues the €500 m water‑meter scheme should fund broadband instead.  
• The coalition highlights a proposed €200 m Center Parcs resort in Ballymahon, expected to create about 1,000 jobs when it opens in 2019, though it still requires planning approval. Fine Gael TD James Bannon promotes the region’s waterways and scenery for tourism.  
• Traders welcome improving conditions but seek further support—such as scrapping town‑centre parking charges—to accelerate growth.  
Overall, the Midlands is edging into recovery, yet locals insist additional action is necessary.

Eight IPL teams are playing a double‑round‑robin season that ends with play‑offs and a final on 29 May (same stadium as the opener). The top four after the league stage reach the play‑offs (Qualifier 1 on 24 May, Eliminator 25 May, Qualifier 2 on 27 May, Final 29 May).  

Current individual leaders  
• Runs: David Warner 294, Virat Kohli 267, AB de Villiers 249  
• Sixes: Warner 12, de Villiers 12, Kohli 8  
• Highest innings: Quinton de Kock 108, Warner 90*, Gautam Gambhir 90*  
• Wickets: Mitchell McClenaghan 9, Bhuvneshwar Kumar 8, Mustafizur Rahman 7  

England involvement: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils), Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants).  

Match schedule (all 15:30 BST unless stated) runs from Mon 25 April to Sun 22 May for league games, followed by the three play‑off matches and the final. Full scores, fixtures and results are available on BBC Sport.

Plastic carrier‑bag use has risen by 200 million in England since 2013, adding to landfill and river pollution because most bags aren’t recycled. Starting in October, shoppers in England will be charged 5 pence per plastic bag to encourage reuse. Similar charges in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland have already cut bag consumption, and campaigners expect the English fee to reduce waste and benefit the environment.

High winds triggered widespread disruption across Wales on Friday: part of a school roof in Rhosgadfan was torn off; hundreds of homes lost power; speed limits and lane closures were imposed on major bridges; and trains on the Llandudno Junction‑Holyhead line faced delays. Gusts peaked at Mona on Anglesey, prompting Irish Ferries to cancel six fast crossings between Holyhead and Dublin and the National Trust to shut Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Conditions eased by evening, allowing restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge to be lifted, but ongoing blustery weather has pushed Rhyl’s Boxing Day sea dip to 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan confirmed he will join Marvel’s Black Panther, re‑teaming with Creed director Ryan Coogler.  Jordan said he is eager to collaborate with Lupita Nyong’o and star Chadwick Boseman.  Known for last year’s Fantastic Four reboot, Jordan plans to bring “a different spin” to his unspecified role.  Nyong’o, fresh off her Oscar win and Star Wars appearance, is also in talks for the film, which is set for a February 2018 release.

Alexandra Palace’s east wing is undergoing a £26.6 million restoration. Plans include:

• Reopening the 1875 theatre—still largely intact—for drama, film, comedy and live music in 2018.  
• Repairing and refurbishing the BBC studios.  
• Converting the glazed east court into a public and exhibition space.

Funding: £18.8 million from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8 million from Haringey Council, with the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust set to raise the remaining £1 million by summer 2017.

James Milner, 30, the former Manchester City midfielder, earned 61 England senior caps after debuting in 2009. He was in the squads for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he played only three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the England Under‑21 appearance record with 46 caps (first match in 2004) and scored his sole senior international goal in a 5‑0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers. He described his recent decision as “common sense” and wished manager Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success.

In Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, Marcy Smith’s son David noticed a fire while on FaceTime, woke his mother and sister, and got them out just before flames consumed their home. The blaze—sparked by rubbish Mrs. Smith had put in the wood stove—destroyed the house and killed the family’s dog and cats; the smoke alarm never sounded. Escaping in only their pyjamas, the family has since received clothing and other help from the community. Mrs. Smith says David’s quick action saved their lives and vows to remind him of his heroism.

Reports say an energy‑drink company is weighing a £200 million bid for West Ham United. Current owners David Sullivan and David Gold, who bought a majority stake in 2010 in a deal valuing the club at £105 million, now hold more than 85 percent. Since the club’s August move to London Stadium it has also attracted interest from Qatari and Chinese investors. Sullivan has said a minority stake might be sold to reduce debt, but he and Gold aim to keep overall ownership for their children.

At a fan‑voted film ceremony in Los Angeles, The Fault in Our Stars dominated, winning Best Movie while its star Shailene Woodley collected Best Female Performance, the Trailblazer Award and Best Kiss with Ansel Elgort; Woodley thanked novelist John Green for “a beautiful masterpiece.” Bradley Cooper earned Best Male Performance for American Sniper and dedicated the honor to the late Chris Kyle. Other prizes went to Channing Tatum (Best Comedic Performance, 22 Jump Street), Meryl Streep (Best Villain, Into the Woods), and Kevin Hart, who accepted the Comedic Genius Award alongside his children. Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers cast‑mates. Additional winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne, and trailers for upcoming films such as Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck and Marvel’s Ultron were previewed.

Aberdeen’s 21‑year‑old forward Cammy Smith, on loan to Dundee United since July and scorer of five goals this season, has now been brought in by Championship bottom side St Mirren. The Scotland U‑21 cap debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and has four goals from 89 games for the Dons. St Mirren boss Jack Ross hails him as a mature, versatile attacking option. St Mirren host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council, now taking advantage of warmer weather, is deploying Jetpatcher machines to repair about 145 potholes per day for the next four months, while additional crews fix rain‑damaged drainage and clear gutter debris.

• In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest’s Thistle oil platform, 125 miles north‑east of Shetland, were unknowingly exposed to alpha radiation (NORM) while removing pipework during a shutdown.

• Rigging supervisor Steve Innes says the men worked for hours without proper protective equipment and were only told of the hazard late in the trip; they now face ongoing blood tests and cancer worries.

• EnQuest states the exposure was under 1 % of the level that must be reported to the Health and Safety Executive, but it informed the HSE and has introduced extra precautions.

• Wood Group removed its staff for medical checks and says safety is its priority.

• Unite union criticises the treatment of the workers; the HSE says the incident was not legally reportable, so no investigation was launched.

In 2007 Singapore’s Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) paid US$650,000 for a bronze of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past. In a 2012 court case the dealer’s manager, Aaron Freedman, admitted trafficking and possessing 150 looted Indian antiquities, including this sculpture, believed stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. After India’s Archaeological Survey (ASI) formally requested its return in May and discussions with Singapore’s National Heritage Board, ACM agreed to repatriate the piece. It was one of 30 objects the museum bought from the dealer; none of the others are currently listed as stolen, though ASI has inspected them. ACM plans legal action to recover the money lost through the fraud.

A magnitude‑4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 local time, 35 km north of Lucca in the Garfagnana area, at a depth of about 15 km. It was felt from Milan to Florence, shook high‑rise buildings in Bologna and Modena, and prompted people in Lucca to rush into the streets. No injuries or major damage were immediately reported, though aftershocks followed, phone lines and power failed locally, and nearby schools were evacuated for checks.
