Italy, a quake‑prone country, recently suffered deadly shocks: a magnitude‑6 event in the same region last May killed more than 20, and the 2009 L’Aquila quake claimed almost 300 lives. After the L’Aquila disaster, six scientists and an ex‑official were convicted in 2012 for giving overly reassuring advice before the main shock.

On 8 September 2016, 62‑year‑old Sheffield grandfather Austin Grant—once skeptical about South Yorkshire’s climate—finally saw fruit growing on his plant (still unripe and attached) and said he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar has postponed the PC launch of Grand Theft Auto V from 27 January to 24 March to allow more testing and polish, assuring players the delay is in their best interests. Online heists will reach consoles ahead of the new PC date. PC screenshots reveal enhanced visuals—1080p at 60 fps, optional 4K resolution and triple‑monitor support—and the minimum system requirements are now available. The game originally set sales records, earning $1 billion within three days of its 17 September 2013 debut.

Simpson, a 76‑year‑old artist, won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for his 7‑ft work Squint (19). Previously shortlisted in 1991 and long‑listed three other times, he called the victory “very nice indeed” and plans to spend the prize money on canvases and high‑quality paints. Judge Ansel Krut praised the technically subtle yet challenging painting, which shows a medieval “leper squint” allowing outcasts to watch church services. Founded in 1957, the biennial prize has honored artists such as David Hockney and Peter Doig, with patron Sir Peter Blake winning the junior title in 1961.

Early Thursday, four masked gunmen carried out near‑simultaneous attacks on the Istanbul offices of pro‑government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, 20 km apart. Gunfire shattered windows and a small fire was set at Yeni Safak, but firefighters quelled it and no casualties occurred. Police have cordoned off both sites, recovered numerous spent bullet casings and are searching for the attackers; no group has claimed responsibility. The incident follows protests that targeted another paper, Hurriyet, last September.

A 24‑year‑old former Burton player, previously on loan at Crawley where he scored 3 goals in 23 games, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners from the Stags on a free transfer on 1 January, becoming Bignot’s first signing.

• Arsène Wenger, whose Arsenal contract ends this summer, is being linked with the permanent England manager’s role but says he is concentrating on his club job.  
• Wenger backs interim boss Gareth Southgate, praising his experience and decision‑making; Southgate has November matches against Scotland (World Cup qualifier) and Spain (friendly) to convince the FA to appoint him permanently.  
• Wenger stresses that competence, not “big names,” should decide the England appointment.  
• At Arsenal, Wenger plans to offer 21‑year‑old right‑back Héctor Bellerín a new deal amid interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, insisting the Spaniard’s long‑term future is at the club.  
• Midfielder Aaron Ramsey will be out for another one or two matches with a hamstring injury.

A worker at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating, and the company is fully cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf has announced a new charter arrangement that will resolve the wage dispute on the Northern Isles freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay. The boats, currently run by Seatruck for Serco Northlink, will return to direct Serco Northlink control next month. The change follows RMT union claims that some crew members were earning under £4 an hour; Seatruck had argued the UK minimum wage did not apply to the mostly non‑UK crew. Under the new deal, all crew will receive at least the minimum wage. Serco Northlink, holder of a six‑year £243 million Scottish‑government‑subsidised contract awarded in 2012, operates three ferries and two cargo ships on the route.

• 64‑year‑old Ken Dickie died in hospital on 14 May, six days after a confrontation at Rockley Park, Poole.  
• The row began on 7 May when Jamie Mitchell, 35, drunkenly stepped in between Dickie and Mitchell’s mother, Samantha, who had been in a long‑term but troubled relationship with Dickie.  
• Mitchell admitted common assault over the fight; he and his mother also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice after initially lying to police about what happened.  
• Mitchell later said he was trying to push the couple apart when the “tragic accident” occurred.  
• A jury returned its verdict at Winchester Crown Court (prompting Mitchell to shout “yes”); both defendants will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the reclusive British songwriter dubbed “The Invisible Man,” died in London last week aged 66 after a short, aggressive battle with cancer, his publisher Warner/Chappell confirmed. Born in Cleethorpes, he first found success in the 1970s with Heatwave, penning Boogie Nights, Always & Forever and Groove Line. Producer Quincy Jones then enlisted him for Michael Jackson’s solo work: Temperton wrote Off the Wall, Rock With You and Burn This Disco Out for the Off the Wall album, and Thriller, Baby Be Mine and The Lady in My Life for Thriller, helping make it the best‑selling U.S. album ever. He later won a 1990 Grammy for Birdland and earned two 1986 Oscar nominations for The Color Purple. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan and others.

Researchers from Swansea University, Exeter, Reading and Brazilian institutions have identified more than 450 large, 2,000‑year‑old geometrical earthworks (“geoglyphs”) in Acre, western Amazonia. Hidden beneath bamboo rainforest until recent deforestation, the ditched enclosures contain few artefacts and lack defensive layouts, leading scholars to think they served as occasional ritual gathering places rather than villages. Soil, phytolith, charcoal and isotope analyses show the sites were created amid tall forest, not exposed like Maya pyramids, and that for at least 6,000 years inhabitants selectively managed useful tree species (e.g., palms) instead of practicing large‑scale burning. This “prehistoric supermarket” model implies the Amazon was significantly shaped by humans before European contact, a legacy that still influences Acre’s forest biodiversity today.

Nick Kyrgios, ranked a career‑high world No 12, defeated world No 29 Sam Querrey 6‑4 6‑4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round of the Shanghai Masters. Fresh from winning the Japan Open, Kyrgios said travel and poor sleep left him tired and “a bit bored” during the match. Last year at the same event he was fined $1,500 for a foul‑mouthed outburst in which he called the tournament a “circus.”

Scientists, doctors and cancer charities argue that the HPV vaccine, already given to 12‑ and 13‑year‑old girls in Wales to prevent cervical cancer, should also be offered to boys because HPV is sexually transmitted and linked to rising head‑ and neck‑cancer rates—especially in men (three‑quarters of cases, average age 55). HPV accounts for 5 % of global cancers. Campaigners will deliver a letter urging the Welsh government to act immediately, while the government says it will wait for recommendations from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation; 85 % of school‑aged girls have been vaccinated since the programme began in 2008.

Jak Trueman, a 15‑year‑old West Calder High School pupil, died from the rare blood cancer gamma delta T‑cell lymphoma shortly after briefly attending a school prom organised for him. Throughout his illness, he and his family chronicled “Jak’s Journey” on Facebook, attracting more than 28,000 supporters and sharing visits from Rangers players and other sports and show‑business figures. His mother announced his death on the page, praising her “beautiful boy.” Jak’s courage earned him his Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy for overcoming adversity. After doctors confirmed on 23 January that the cancer had spread and treatment would stop, the family shifted focus to fundraising for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, including a charity football match at Livingston FC’s ground.

Africa Cup of Nations, Group D – Port‑Gentil  
• Egypt beat Uganda 1‑0.  
• Winner: Abdallah El Said, 89’, set up by Mohamed Salah after Uganda had a Joseph Ochaya strike ruled offside (52’).  
• Game was largely subdued on a poor pitch; Uganda failed to register a shot on target.  
• Table implications: Egypt (4 pts) meet Ghana on Wednesday with first place still open; Uganda are eliminated in their first AFCON since 1978.  
• Earlier the same day Ghana qualified for the quarter‑finals by beating Mali 1‑0.  
• Wednesday permutations: Mali must defeat Uganda and hope Ghana beat Egypt by ≥2 goals to advance.

Lancashire County Council, working with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, has chosen the disused Glenburn Sports College and nearby Skelmersdale College (Westbank campus) site for Skelmersdale’s proposed new railway station. The decision, reached after Network Rail compared this location with two alternatives, aims to restore rail services lost when the town’s station closed in 1956. Plans envisage two direct trains per hour to Liverpool, room for future expansion, and good road links. The council will now begin acquiring the land; Skelmersdale remains one of the largest north‑west towns without its own station.
Police discovered plants inside an “elaborate grow house” in a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning and arrested a man in his late 40s at the scene.

In Hamelin, Lower Saxony, a 28‑year‑old woman of Kurdish‑German origin was found late Sunday with severe injuries after being dragged by the neck through several streets. She underwent emergency surgery and was airlifted to a specialist clinic. Her 38‑year‑old ex‑partner, also a Kurdish‑German from nearby Bad Muender, later surrendered to police and is in custody. The motive is still unknown, and authorities have cordoned off the area and appealed for witnesses.

Study details:
• Researchers: Cass Business School, University of Warwick, University of Wisconsin.  
• Sample: 4,600 Australian employees from the 2013‑14 Workplace Relations Survey, with full‑time men compared to full‑time women and part‑time men to part‑time women.

Key findings:
1. Women ask for pay rises as often as men, contradicting the “reticent female” stereotype.  
2. When they do ask, men are about 25% more likely than comparable women to receive the raise.  
3. The gap persists after accounting for employer size, industry, parental status and qualifications, pointing to possible gender discrimination.  
4. Employees under 40—men and women—ask for and receive raises at similar rates, suggesting negotiating patterns may be changing for younger workers.

Implication:
The disparity appears driven not by female reluctance but by differential employer responses to identical requests.

Oxford City Council has spent funds investigating potential new burial sites, but every council‑owned location examined has been ruled out because of size, poor ground conditions, high water tables or legal covenants. The only cemeteries with remaining space—Wolvercote and Botley—are projected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021 respectively. Once they are full, only limited options such as reopening family plots, using a few reserved plots, or interring ashes will remain. The city has not added new burial space since 1932, yet the council says it is still looking for solutions.

At this year’s Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July), visitors can scan site signs and posters with a new app to access augmented‑reality content—videos, band interviews, information updates and ticket sales—on phones or tablets. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. The feature also lets people worldwide sample the festival’s atmosphere.

Many Clouds, a 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding, collapsed and died moments after defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase on Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. Veterinary examination found a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare event even in otherwise healthy sport horses. Although the Grand National winner had occasionally shown post‑race overheating and ataxia in the past, he displayed none of those symptoms on Saturday. His record included wins in the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, and trainer Oliver Sherwood called him “the horse of a lifetime.” The British Horseracing Authority is seeking to understand the causes and prevention of such rare incidents.

In 2004 a 15‑year‑old girl was raped in a Portsmouth garage by David (now Davina) Ayrton while two companions slept. Ayrton, who has learning difficulties, later mentioned the assault to a care‑home worker in 2014. Now 34 and identifying as female (but without medical transition, name changed in 2012), Ayrton was found guilty, remanded in custody pending 4 March sentencing, and is likely to be held in a male prison in Winchester because of risks of self‑harm and absconding.

World number one Novak Djokovic, 29, and his Serbian doubles partner were beaten 6‑4 6‑4 by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a day after Djokovic had been knocked out of the Olympic singles by Juan Martin del Potro. The loss follows his shock third‑round Wimbledon exit to Sam Querrey, though he had since claimed a 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Games.

Over 20 competitors will gather this Saturday in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, for a chainsaw‑only carving contest. Entrants hail from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US, each transforming logs into animal or human figures. Reigning champion Pete Bowsher of Moffat returns to defend his Claymore Trophy title.

Rugby scrum‑half Rhys Webb, 27, has been out since a serious foot injury in September’s World Cup warm‑up against Italy. He is now running again, treating rehab like pre‑season, and hopes to return by early February—or slightly sooner—in time for Wales’ Six Nations opener away to Ireland on 7 February. Capped 16 times, Webb has rejected outside offers and signed a new national dual contract to stay with his home region Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, stressing his commitment to playing for Wales.

Border agents near Sumas, Washington, stopped an alleged ecstasy smuggling attempt on Tuesday morning. Two men with backpacks were confronted; one, Nathan Hall, fired at agents and fled but was arrested in British Columbia hours later, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was captured immediately. Their packs held 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA and a fake California licence. Investigators then arrested Kali Henifin and her boyfriend Ryan Lambert, who allegedly planned to drive the drugs to San Francisco for $11,000. All four now face U.S. federal conspiracy and drug‑trafficking charges in a border area known for smuggling.

• NSPCC’s Childline handled more than 4,500 cyber‑bullying counselling sessions in the past year, up from about 2,400 in 2011‑12, and the true number of victims is believed to be much higher.  
• Children as young as seven reported being tormented online; trolls inflict “misery and humiliation” that continues outside school.  
• Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen warns that cyber‑bullying can become inescapable and urges parents, teachers and schools to step in because bullying “gets worse” if ignored.  
• The findings are published to mark Anti‑Bullying Week, organised by the Anti‑Bullying Alliance, which is working with families, schools and other groups to tackle the issue.  
• A child’s testimony describing being told to “kill myself” highlights the emotional harm and the difficulty victims face in seeking help.

After the U.S. abstained from a UN Security Council resolution that condemned Israeli settlement‑building as illegal, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu angrily accused Washington of orchestrating the measure and retaliated by summoning and recalling diplomats and cutting aid. To avoid worsening the dispute hours before U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry’s planned speech on the conflict, Netanyahu’s office asked Jerusalem’s Planning and Housing Committee to postpone a vote on authorizing 492 new homes in the East Jerusalem settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot. Kerry is expected to defend the U.S. stance, while Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas says the resolution prepares the ground for a 15 January French‑hosted peace conference aimed at setting a timetable to end Israel’s occupation.

On the eve of Queen Elizabeth II’s 90th birthday (21 April), a BBC interview featured Prince William praising her “duty, service and tolerance” as his model of monarchy while rebutting recent “work‑shy” headlines, saying he will assume fuller royal duties in time.  

Birthday celebrations include:  
• Release of ten commemorative Royal Mail stamps, among them a four‑generation portrait of the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William and Prince George.  
• The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh visiting Windsor’s Royal Mail office for its 500th anniversary, then opening a new bandstand in Alexandra Gardens where local schoolchildren sang “Happy Birthday.”  
• Thursday events: a public walk in Windsor, unveiling of a 6.3 km “Queen’s Walkway,” and lighting the first of more than 900 celebratory beacons worldwide.  
• Friday: lunch at Windsor Castle with U.S. President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama.  

Political leaders David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn plan parliamentary birthday wishes, with Mr Cameron calling the day an “important landmark.”  

The Queen, Britain’s longest‑reigning monarch, marks two birthdays each year (actual 21 April; official in June). Republican group “Republic” criticised the BBC for what it called unbalanced, celebratory coverage.

EFL Cup 2nd‑round tie: West Ham United beat League Two hosts Cheltenham Town 2‑0. 

Key points  
• Both goals came in a four‑minute spell before half‑time – Diafra Sakho converted Sam Byram’s pass for his first goal since November, and Andre Ayew quickly drove a second into the same bottom corner.  
• West Ham, making seven changes after recent league defeats, largely controlled the game and might have added further goals through James Collins, Angelo Ogbonna and Byram.  
• Cheltenham’s best openings were a Harry Pell volley, a Jordon Forster header and a late Pell cross that substitute Dan Holman just failed to reach; they rarely tested goalkeeper Adrián.  
• Ogbonna had a header cleared off the line by Kyle Storer and keeper Jonathan Flatt saved well from Sakho to keep the score respectable.  
• The result, mirroring West Ham’s 2013/14 win over the same opponents in this competition, eliminates the last League Two side before the third‑round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, 36, a hospital radiographer, was killed when Andreas Werner, 46, turned his VW Transporter across McNicholl’s path on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Werner admitted causing death by careless driving, received a £1,000 fine and a two‑year UK driving ban. The victim’s family opposed a jail sentence, viewing the crash as a momentary lapse; Werner expressed remorse.

Imran Khawaja, 27, from Southall, west London, left Britain for Syria in January 2014, joined the Islamic State‑linked group Rayat al Tawheed and became a prominent online propagandist under the name Abu Daigham al‑Britani. He posted slick recruitment videos and gruesome images—including one of himself holding a bag containing a severed head—aimed at attracting British supporters. After about six months he decided to return, persuading his cousin, Watford taxi‑driver Tahir Bhatti, to collect him in Bulgaria. To mask his movements, Khawaja published a fake online obituary claiming he had died in battle. When the pair reached Dover in June, MI5 and police arrested them. Khawaja, deemed one of the most dangerous British jihadists to come back from Syria, has pleaded guilty to four terrorism‑related offences and faces up to life in prison; Bhatti has admitted assisting an offender. Khawaja has been held in Belmarsh’s high‑risk terrorist unit while authorities assess his unknown intentions for returning to the UK.

Kayden Jackson, 22, who scored four goals in 36 games as Wrexham finished eighth, has become Barnsley’s third signing for next season ahead of their League One play‑off final at Wembley. Caretaker manager Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and style, and Jackson had rejected a new contract offer from Wrexham.

Bottles of Vanish detergent have been washing up since Sunday on Poldhu Cove and nearby Cornish beaches, probably from a container that the cargo ship MV Blue Ocean is thought to have lost off Land’s End in May, although the Coastguard says the link is still only circumstantial. National Trust volunteers are clearing the largely sealed, but sometimes leaking, bottles because the detergent poses a threat to wildlife, and Cornwall Council, Natural England and others are monitoring the coastline. The public are warned to stay clear of any further bottles and not attempt to recover them.

Around 14:00 a crash on the A9 north of Berriedale, Caithness caused several minor injuries, closed the road, led to diversions via the A897 Helmsdale‑to‑Melvich route, and remains under Police Scotland investigation.

French centre‑back Dorian Dervite, 28, has signed a new Bolton Wanderers contract. He joined from Charlton in 2014 and has played 83 times in all competitions. After making 14 appearances last season, he helped Bolton finish second in League One and win promotion to the Championship, earning praise from manager Phil Parkinson. Dervite’s extension follows new deals for David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan.

Liberal Democrat and Labour peers fell out after the Commons rejected their joint Lords amendments on EU citizens’ rights and a final‑deal vote.  
• Lib Dems want to keep pushing the amendments, calling Labour willing to “concede everything”.  
• Labour will defer to MPs, accusing Lib Dems of “grandstanding” and giving worried EU citizens “false hope”.  
• Lib Dem Baroness Ludford says Labour is “waving through” a hard Brexit; Labour sources foresee ongoing “residual tensions”.  
• Despite past cooperation on issues like higher education and housing, any near‑term alliance looks strained, though Lib Dems say they will still work with others where they agree.

• Defence ranks low with voters, so parties devote little manifesto space (page 77 in both main manifestos) and few specifics.  
• World threats are rising (migration, Islamist extremism, assertive Russia) yet UK forces are shrinking: Army falling to 82 000, Navy down to 19 warships, RAF to 7–8 fast‑jet squadrons, no Maritime Patrol Aircraft.  
• UK has slipped from 4th to 6th in world defence spending; without new money it will drop below NATO’s 2 %‑of‑GDP benchmark to c.1.7 %–1.5 % by 2020. Only UKIP and the DUP promise to sustain 2 %.  
• Further savings of £2–3 bn a year are likely, but Tory pledges to protect Army numbers, raise the kit budget 1 % yearly and replace Trident would limit where cuts can fall; Labour gives itself more room by avoiding such promises.  
• Trident renewal (four new subs, ≥£20 bn) is increasingly contested:  
  – Conservatives/UKIP: full like‑for‑like replacement.  
  – Labour: keep continuous patrols but consider three subs.  
  – Lib Dems: end continuous patrols (“part‑time” deterrent).  
  – SNP/Greens: scrap altogether.  
  The decision could again be delayed in the post‑election Strategic Defence Review.  
• New aircraft carriers (Queen Elizabeth, Prince of Wales) risk becoming hollow symbols: crew shortages and only 12 F‑35s planned for decks built for 36.  
• Senior analysts warn more cuts will erode capability, damage US perceptions of the UK, and leave Britain struggling to “punch above its weight.”

Barcelona are under investigation over possible tax irregularities in the 2013 transfer of Neymar.  
• The club originally said the striker cost €57 m (£48.6 m), including €34 m paid to his parents, but other contracts may raise the total outlay to about €106.8 m once signing‑on fees, wages and agents’ fees are included.  
• To counter claims of wrongdoing, Barça have filed an additional tax declaration of €13.55 m, while insisting their initial payments met all legal obligations.  
• Former president Sandro Rosell resigned last month amid related accusations of misappropriating funds; he also denies any misconduct.  
• A Spanish judge has ruled that evidence warrants the continuation of the probe, and it is unknown whether Barcelona’s tax payment will end the case.  
• On the pitch, Neymar, 22, has scored seven league goals and three in the Champions League this season.

• On 12 October, a wrong‑way crash on the M1 near Kegworth, Leicestershire, killed passenger Michael Luciw, 27, of Nottingham, and the wrong‑way driver,  79‑year‑old Albert Kenneth Newman, whose Mazda Premacy struck the Ford Transit van.  
• Luciw, a delivery driver and father of a baby girl, was travelling with colleague Andy Harrington; Harrington survived with serious injuries.  
• Luciw’s family and Harrington say the crash shows a need for compulsory, in‑car driving and medical tests for elderly motorists, arguing reaction times slow with age and alternative transport (e.g., free bus passes) exists.  
• Currently, UK drivers over 70 renew their licences by completing a self‑assessment form every three years; no driving or medical test is required.  
• The DVLA states it has no plans to tighten rules, claiming evidence does not show older drivers cause more serious accidents.  
• Age UK stresses that maintaining safe driving is vital for older people’s independence.

• Thousands of Scottish women with transvaginal mesh or tape implants for incontinence have reported severe complications; 400‑plus are suing health boards and manufacturers.  
• An independent review of the procedure’s safety split the panel: two harmed patients and a consultant quit, claiming the final report was “watered‑down” and had sections removed.  
• The review’s chair Tracey Gillies, who took over late in the process, apologised for failing to reach consensus, calling the role “almost mission impossible.”  
• The final report advises that mesh should not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, urges mandatory reporting of adverse events, and says women must be given full information and alternative treatments.  
• Health Secretary Shona Robison will keep implementing the recommendations but says Scotland cannot ban the devices; only the UK regulator (MHRA) can.  
• Prof. Alison Britton has been appointed to audit how the review reached its conclusions and to identify lessons for future reviews.

Laura Muir, 23, ran 14 min 49.12 sec for 5,000 m at Glasgow’s Emirates Arena, lowering Liz McColgan’s 25‑year‑old British indoor record by 14 seconds. Although McColgan initially questioned whether the largely solo, mixed‑race run met UK Athletics’ guidelines on competition format and drug testing, British Athletics says the mark should be ratified, noting no mandatory testing is required if none is provided at the event. McColgan welcomed the achievement, calling Muir “world‑class,” predicting she can improve to about 14:30 and contend for global medals, and likening the solo effort to her own record run. Muir already holds the national 1,500 m record and was a 2016 Olympic finalist.

Germany’s Michael Jung won individual eventing on Sam, a late stand‑in after Fischertakinou fell ill. France’s Astier Nicolas claimed silver and the USA’s Phillip Dutton took bronze. Britain’s William Fox‑Pitt, back only 10 months after a serious fall, finished 12th: he led after dressage, slipped to 21st after cross‑country penalties, then jumped clear in the final phase. Ireland’s Jonty Evans came ninth.

Andy Murray, 30, beat Italy’s 29‑seed Fabio Fognini 6‑2 4‑6 6‑1 7‑5 in 2 h 39 m, sealing victory at 20:57 BST after saving five set points and winning the last five games from 2‑5 down in the fourth set. The win puts Murray into Wimbledon’s last 16 for an 11th time; he will face France’s Benoît Paire on Monday. The match featured fading light, a possible roof delay, Fognini receiving a point penalty for an obscene gesture, and Murray complaining about slow play. Earlier, Briton Johanna Konta reached week two for the first time by defeating Maria Sakkari 6‑4 6‑1.

On 6 October 2014, paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST. Police arrived soon after and found patrons still inside; till receipts showed alcohol was served until 04:49 BST. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar closed for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside licensing hours. O’Neill, who has “an appalling record,” was fined £3,000; Thomas was fined £1,000. The judge lamented the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence and noted Dungiven licensing laws were ignored.

• Ulster Unionist leader Mike Nesbitt launched the party’s “Real Partnership” manifesto, saying “Domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” and urging voters to treat the election as a verdict on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, which he says is wasting £85,000 a day and reflects ten years of DUP/Sinn Féin misrule.

• Manifesto pledges: cut hospital waiting lists, raise PSNI numbers to 7,500, press ahead with the York Street interchange, defend LGBT rights, and guarantee no one is worse off because of Brexit, alongside a “Cleaning Up Stormont” drive against incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and corruption.

• Controversy now centres on Nesbitt’s call for Ulster Unionist voters to transfer later‑preference votes to the nationalist SDLP rather than Sinn Féin; senior colleague Danny Kennedy publicly distanced himself, but Nesbitt says he has “no regrets,” will not withdraw the comment, and reports strong grassroots support.

• Nesbitt insists that any post‑election Executive will include a nationalist party and he would “rather go in with the SDLP,” maintaining confidence despite differing views within his own candidate slate.

Northern Ireland’s Justice Minister Claire Sugden has won executive backing to ask the Assembly for a legislative consent motion that would pardon men convicted under now‑abolished sexual‑offence laws. Mirroring England and Wales’ recently announced “Turing’s Law,” the plan provides automatic posthumous pardons and lets living gay and bisexual men apply for pardons, aiming to deliver equal treatment “as soon as possible.” The motion will now go before the Assembly for approval.

Laura Muir, 23, from Kinross, ran 4:19.12 to finish second to Kenya’s Faith Kipyegon, breaking Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish mile record (4:22.60) and moving to No. 2 on Britain’s all‑time list behind Zola Budd (4:17.57). Already the Scottish 1500 m record‑holder and fifth‑place finisher at last year’s World Championships, Muir opened her season with this first mile race, following an 800 m win in France and ahead of a 1500 m race in Stockholm. She will try to book a Rio Olympic spot at the British trials in Birmingham (24–26 June) while continuing her veterinary studies, recently completing her fourth year.
The passage showcases photos of 26 Scottish beaches that have received the top “most excellent” rating for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC, in his closing remarks to the inquiry into Alexander Litvinenko’s 2006 death, said:

• Suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi lacked a personal motive; the Russian state “is likely to have been the sponsor” of the plot, though this does not necessarily implicate President Vladimir Putin.  
• Litvinenko, 43, ingested fatal polonium‑210 while drinking tea with the two men in London and died nearly three weeks later; scientific evidence shows a “trail of polonium” linking the suspects.  
• Possible motives include Litvinenko’s 2000 defection to the UK and his public attacks on Putin.  
• Horwell said Litvinenko was poisoned twice, the assaults were “an outrage,” and the long‑term public health risk from the radiation may never be known.  
• Attempts to extradite the suspects have failed, making a murder trial unlikely; Kovtun has refused to testify.  
The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been confirmed as Australia’s new Test captain, adding to his existing role as one‑day skipper and covering Twenty20 duties while Aaron Finch is injured. Fellow batsman David Warner, 28, becomes vice‑captain. Selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and leadership qualities, noting his previous stint as stand‑in Test captain against India and his record of 2,952 runs in 32 Tests at an average of 54.66. The appointment follows Michael Clarke’s decision to retire after Australia lost the Ashes; Marsh said Smith was the obvious successor and that Warner’s maturity now merits a leadership position. Smith and Warner will also lead Australia in the limited‑overs matches after the final Ashes Test at The Oval starting 20 August.

Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron repeatedly declined to say whether he considers homosexual sex sinful, instead stating “we are all sinners.” Despite past opposition to the 2007 Equality Bill—explained as concern for “individual liberties” after a party amendment failed—he insists he is “passionate about LGBT‑plus rights.” As leader he pledges to keep defending equal marriage, to broaden it by ending the “spousal veto” that limits transgender people’s marital rights, and to place LGBT equality “at the top of my agenda.”

Sanofi shut its Fawdon drug plant in 2015, cutting 450 jobs. Accord Healthcare will now reopen the site for pharmaceutical production and aims to re‑hire many former Sanofi workers. Local leaders hail the move as a major boost for Newcastle and the North East’s science‑healthcare sector. Accord, a global firm that makes and supplies over 130 medicines to about 60 countries, expects its investment to have a strongly positive economic impact on the area.

Richard Ellis (interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive) will leave on Friday when his contract ends, while Ciaran Monaghan (head of the chief executive’s office) and Ewan Sutherland (head of human resources and customer services) are departing through a voluntary redundancy/early‑retirement scheme. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn says the exits highlight the council’s difficulty retaining senior staff and predicts more will follow. Chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider says this season’s Honda Fireblade problems turned the TT into “a bloody disaster,” reducing him to a test rider. After skipping the North West 200 following team‑mate John McGuinness’s crash, he has also been withdrawn from next month’s Ulster Grand Prix because the bike remains uncompetitive. While clarifying he has not quit racing, he states he will do no further road races on Hondas this year and will focus instead on classic and unconventional events.

• Nigeria’s 11 April state elections confirmed the sweeping gains of the opposition All Progressives Congress (APC).  
• APC captured 19 of the 28 governorships declared, including the commercial hub Lagos and several key northern states such as Katsina and Kaduna; only Taraba is still pending and Imo was ruled inconclusive.  
• The governing Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) won just eight seats—mainly in the south‑east—and kept only one major stronghold in the oil‑rich south (Rivers). Seven states did not vote this cycle.  
• The result marks the PDP’s worst setback since civilian rule began in 1999 and follows its loss of the presidency to APC leader Muhammadu Buhari, who is to be sworn in on 29 May.  
• Analysts say the APC has relegated the PDP to a regional party: most of the north and south‑west now back the APC, while the PDP still controls all five oil‑producing states, posing challenges for Buhari if local militants disrupt production.  
• Voting was generally calmer than in past years, though the electoral commission recorded 66 violent incidents, mainly in Rivers and other southern states.  
• Observers attribute the PDP’s fall to defections, corruption allegations and its handling of Boko Haram’s insurgency; the party faces a period of rebuilding after 16 years in power.

US environmental group Mighty alleges that Singapore‑based commodities trader Olam and its majority shareholder, state investment fund Temasek, are fuelling Southeast Asia’s annual haze by buying palm oil from “rogue” suppliers and by clearing rainforest for plantations. The report says Olam, which sources 99 % of its palm oil from third parties and controls under 1 % of the global market, has created a “secretive” supply chain that obscures unsustainable practices in Indonesia and, via joint ventures, in Gabon.  

Olam rejects the accusations, claiming a “no‑burn, no‑peat, no‑deforestation” policy, vowing to drop non‑compliant producers and having just disclosed its 14 suppliers. Temasek likewise dismisses the charges, asserting support for no‑burn land clearance and noting that it does not direct Olam’s operations. The dispute highlights broader industry tensions: palm oil is lucrative but frequently linked to illegal burning, deforestation and labour abuses, while governments hesitate to act because the sector brings rural jobs and investment.
On 27 August 2016, after a new law permitted dogs to eat outdoors at restaurants, one venue started offering special “puppy platters” so pets could dine with their owners.

• Forward Fernando Forestieri (knee) remains doubtful, having only appeared as a substitute in the last two matches.  
• Derby County striker David Nugent (groin) could return after sitting out the draw with Huddersfield.  
• Midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a starting recall after coming off the bench to score a late equaliser against the Terriers.

Pakistan has lifted its 2012 Supreme‑Court‑ordered YouTube ban after Google created a Pakistan‑specific site.  
• The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority instructed all ISPs to restore access, and the state telecom company announced “Welcome Back YouTube.”  
• According to the IT ministry, the new local version lets the PTA ask Google to block material it deems “offending” for Pakistani users.  
• Google/YouTube says such requests will be reviewed under its community guidelines and listed in its Transparency Report, not automatically accepted.  
• Many Pakistanis celebrate the move, but some activists demand full disclosure of the agreement’s terms.  
• The original ban followed deadly protests over the anti‑Islam film “Innocence of Muslims.”  
• Google also recently launched local YouTube sites for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Fifa’s Ad‑Hoc Electoral Committee is chaired by Swiss‑Italian Domenico Scala.  Liberian FA president Musa Bility argues that, because Scala shares nationality with current candidate Gianni Infantino, Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations requires him to step aside, just as he and Claudio Sulser did before the May 2015 vote involving Swiss incumbent Sepp Blatter.  Bility has given Scala until Thursday to withdraw or he will appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport, insisting the credibility of the 26 February election is at stake.  

Scala’s spokesman, Andreas Bantel, counters that merely sharing a passport with a candidate “does not result in a conflict of interest” and says Scala’s 2015 withdrawal was a voluntary precaution because Blatter was the sitting president, a situation that does not apply this time.  

The election in Zurich, voted on by Fifa’s 209 members, will choose between five candidates: Infantino, Prince Ali (backed by Bility), Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman and Tokyo Sexwale.

Two employees, Daniel Timbers (29) and Barry Joy (56), died shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in the paint‑spraying area of Harford Attachments in Spar Road. Their bodies were removed on Tuesday afternoon. A forensic search indicates a flashover explosion—built‑up toxic fumes ignited, creating a fireball. Police say witness and forensic work is progressing, and Health and Safety Executive inspectors plus electrical experts are collecting further evidence.

• Tunisia risked exclusion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after angrily protesting a late penalty decision in their 2015 quarter‑final loss to hosts Equatorial Guinea.  
• Caf demanded an apology by 31 March 2015; a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou produced reconciliation, Tunisia apologised, and their 2017 place is secure.  
• Morocco had been banned from 2017 qualifying and fined $1 m for withdrawing as 2015 hosts over Ebola fears. The Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned the ban and cut the fine to $50,000, allowing Morocco back into the draw.  
• Draw for 2017 qualifiers: Tunisia face Togo, Liberia and Djibouti (Group A); Morocco meet Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé (Group F). If Tunisia reach Gabon 2017 it will be their 13th consecutive finals, a record.

During Chelsea’s 3‑1 win over Manchester City at the Etihad, a 95th‑minute melee led to both clubs being charged. City’s Sergio Aguero was dismissed for a high, late tackle on David Luiz and given a four‑match ban, while teammate Fernandinho, sent off for grappling with Cesc Fabregas, received a three‑match ban. Fabregas faces no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola has apologised, and both clubs must answer the charge by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales has some of the poorest cancer‑survival rates in the developed world, partly because patients who lack obvious “urgent” symptoms can wait weeks for a diagnosis as GPs shuttle them between tests. After studying Denmark’s successful model, two Welsh health boards are piloting rapid‑access diagnostic clinics:

• Cwm Cynon: 40 local GPs can send any patient they suspect may have cancer—despite non‑specific symptoms—to a new centre at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital, Llantrisant, within seven days. About six patients a week will undergo multiple tests, ideally on the same day.  
• Neath/Port Talbot: a parallel clinic will run at Neath Port Talbot Hospital.

Currently only 35 % of Cwm Taf patients with “concerning” symptoms receive a timely diagnosis; the six‑month pilot aims to raise this, speed treatment and reduce anxiety. If successful, the service will be extended across other Welsh health boards.

England crushed Pakistan in the second Test at Old Trafford, winning by their second‑largest run margin over Pakistan and squaring the four‑match series 1‑1. England piled up 589‑8 declared and 173‑1 declared; Pakistan replied with 198 and 234, lasting only 133 overs in total. Joe Root, promoted to No.3, earned man‑of‑the‑match honours with 254 and 71* plus four catches and a wicket, drawing lavish praise from captain Alastair Cook (105 and 76*), coach Trevor Bayliss and ex‑skipper Michael Vaughan. Commentators Geoffrey Boycott and Vaughan hailed England’s all‑round dominance, though Vaughan still expects a close series. Pakistan captain Misbah‑ul‑Haq admitted batting failures and low confidence—only he and Asad Shafiq have passed 50 in the series—but hopes for a response. Pakistan play a two‑day game at Worcestershire before the third Test starts at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Warren Gatland will coach the British & Irish Lions in New Zealand and has added Rob Howley to his Lions staff, so Wales’ forwards coach Robin McBryde will take charge of Wales’ summer tour—his third spell as stand‑in head coach after 2009 and 2013. The WRU will name assistant coaches shortly, with a full management group expected next week. WRU leaders Martyn Phillips and Gareth Davies say these Lions and tour roles give Welsh coaches valuable development opportunities that should benefit Welsh rugby long‑term.

Premier League, 6 Nov: Hull City 2–1 Southampton at the KCOM Stadium.  
• Charlie Austin’s 6th‑minute penalty put Southampton ahead.  
• Hull lost strikers Abel Hernández and Will Keane to first‑half injuries, bringing on Robert Snodgrass.  
• On 61 minutes Snodgrass equalised from Sam Clucas’s cross; two minutes later his free‑kick was headed in by Michael Dawson for 2‑1.  
• Keeper David Marshall and a last‑gasp Clucas goal‑line clearance preserved the lead.  
• Hull’s first league victory since 20 August ends a six‑game losing run, though they stay in the bottom three going into the international break.  
• Managers: Mike Phelan praised Marshall and Snodgrass; Claude Puel blamed a post‑Europa League lapse in concentration.  
• Next matches (19 Nov): Sunderland v Hull; Southampton v Liverpool.

At about 14:15 BST a crash on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa fatally injured a local motorcyclist; the tractor driver involved was unharmed. Lincolnshire Police are seeking witnesses, and the B1191 was closed between the B1192 (Woodhall Spa) and the A158 (Horncastle).

Macedonian President Gjorge Ivanov halted all investigations linked to covert recordings that allegedly show government vote‑rigging, wire‑tapping of 20,000 people and other abuses, saying the move would “put an end to the agony” before June’s early elections and would “defend national interests.”  
• Opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who has been releasing the recordings since February 2015, called the decision illegal and urged protests in Skopje; several hundred demonstrators gathered outside the prosecutor’s office.  
• EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn warned that Ivanov’s action violates the rule of law and threatens Macedonia’s EU accession hopes.  
• The government denies the allegations and accuses Zaev of trying to destabilise the country, while Zaev rejects that claim.

After Bob Bradley’s dismissal, Alan Curtis and assistant Paul Williams will oversee Swansea’s game against Bournemouth while the club rushes to appoint a new manager, with ex‑Derby boss Paul Clement their preferred choice. Curtis says Swansea need a leader who can steer them clear of relegation, warning that the strengthened Championship and the club’s limited ability to keep key players would make an immediate return far from certain if they go down. Promoted in 2011 after a recovery from near bankruptcy in 2003, Swansea have, in Curtis’s view, lost their identity since Michael Laudrup’s 2014 exit, with constant managerial changes and insufficiently replaced departures diluting the celebrated “Swansea Way.” Nonetheless, he believes the present squad can survive and stresses to newcomers how vital top‑flight status is for the club and the surrounding community.

Leyton Orient beat Dagenham & Redbridge 3‑2, sealing the Daggers’ relegation from League Two. Orient led 2‑0 through Jay Simpson before Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona levelled, but Armand Gnanduillet struck the winner.  

Key points  
• Dagenham, promoted to the Football League in 2007 and up to League One in 2010, drop back to the National League.  
• They have League Two’s worst goal difference, have conceded 20 more goals than at the same stage last season, and rely on 40‑year‑old Cureton, whose nine goals are half last year’s tally.  
• Manager John Still, in his third spell, vows to lead a promotion bid next season but blamed poor organisation and discipline for the drop.  
• Orient, now two points outside the play‑offs, played under interim boss Andy Hessenthaler after Kevin Nolan’s removal; Hessenthaler stressed professionalism and the need to keep winning.

Steven Gerrard, 36, has taken his first post‑retirement role, re‑joining Liverpool in February as a youth coach. Jürgen Klopp welcomed the move, noting Gerrard’s aim to become a manager and his commitment to learning the trade while completing his UEFA A licence. Gerrard, who debuted for Liverpool in 1998, won the Champions League, UEFA Cup, two FA Cups and three League Cups before finishing his playing career with LA Galaxy and retiring in November 2016. He recently declined the MK Dons manager’s job, judging it too early in his coaching development.

Morton beat Alloa comfortably: McManus scored in the 15th minute, Forbes’ deflected shot made it 2‑0, McAusland pulled one back before half‑time, but McManus added a second goal and Johnstone sealed the win late on.

• Ofsted inspectors found children being taught in filthy, unsafe conditions in three unregistered Birmingham settings that have now been shut; these are part of a wider probe of 18 suspected illegal schools, mostly in Muslim communities in the Midlands.  
• Any setting teaching over 20 hours a week must register as a school; some centres are exploiting home‑education rules to avoid this.  
• Running an illegal school carries a possible jail term of up to 51 weeks.  
• Ministers are consulting on tighter controls for places that teach 6‑8 hours a week and have funded a six‑person Ofsted team to hunt illegal schools; prosecutions will now be pursued with the education secretary’s consent.  
• Chief Inspector Sir Michael Wilshaw warns the problem is likely “the tip of the iceberg”, says children risk abuse or radicalisation, and criticises officials for earlier delays.  
• The crackdown will apply to all faith groups, and the consultation ends in mid‑January.

Lilliard Gin has launched a micro‑distillery in a cowshed at the Born in the Borders visitor centre, Jedburgh. Using one of the UK’s smallest production stills, lead distiller Kate Macinnes focuses on botanicals foraged in the Teviot valley to express the Scottish Borders’ “terroir.” The project complements the neighbouring Scottish Borders Brewery and precedes separate plans to build the area’s first whisky distillery since 1837. Named after Lilliard, heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, the brand also reflects its predominantly female production team.

In August 2013, eight‑year‑old Harry Whitlam was fatally struck by a tractor that Gary Green, 51, reversed at Swithens Farm in Rothwell near Leeds. Green, on private farm land and more than twice the drink‑drive limit after consuming about 13 pints, failed to see the child while backing up around 09:15. Prosecuted under health‑and‑safety, not road‑traffic, law, Green admitted failing to ensure others’ safety and received a 16‑week‑plus‑16‑month jail sentence. Harry’s mother, Pam Whitlam, said the loss had devastated their close‑knit family and urged that no one drive drunk anywhere. An HSE inspector called Green’s actions reckless and the case tragic.

Luis Suárez’s appeal to the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) has partly succeeded.  
• CAS upheld FIFA’s nine‑match international suspension and four‑month competitive‑match ban for biting Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini, but judged the ban from “all football‑related activity” excessive.  
• Suárez, 27, may now train, appear in friendly games, attend matches and do promotional work.  
• He must still miss Uruguay’s next eight competitive internationals and cannot make a competitive debut for Barcelona until 26 October’s El Clásico at Real Madrid.  
• Barcelona will present their £75 m signing on Monday; participation that night against Club León is uncertain. He is eligible for Uruguay friendlies versus Japan, South Korea and Saudi Arabia.  
• FIFPro called the remaining sanctions disproportionate; lawyer commentary welcomed the restored training rights.  
• This is Suárez’s third biting offence; he has previous bans for biting Otman Bakkal and Branislav Ivanović and an earlier eight‑match ban for racially abusing Patrice Evra.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake‑Smith and his partner Anna won a 380‑metre wife‑carrying race, finishing ahead of Lithuania’s Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa. The obstacle course included haystack hurdles, a steep slope and water‑pistol dodging; entrants could compete in any pairing, not just married couples. After a week of track training, the British pair’s victory qualifies them for the World Championships in Finland in July.

Paper car‑tax discs will end in October 2014, being replaced by an electronic system that lets motorists pay by monthly direct debit. Although this change will cut the volume of refund work and alter some job roles at DVLA’s 5,000‑staff Swansea centre, Roads Minister Stephen Hammond told local AM Mike Hedges that any staff reductions will be handled through redeployment and retraining rather than redundancies. Hedges said the assurance should reassure concerned employees, even though fewer job opportunities will remain.

• The EU is pressuring Hungary to withdraw three measures:  
  1) tight controls that keep asylum seekers in shipping‑container camps,  
  2) a Higher Education Law that could force the Central European University—founded by George Soros—to shut, and  
  3) a draft bill that would brand NGOs as “foreign‑backed.”  

• Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto says Budapest will not alter any of the laws, arguing they are domestic matters beyond EU competence.  

• Szijjarto also claims Poland has promised to veto any EU attempt to strip Hungary of its voting rights, a sanction that would require unanimous approval.  

• Thousands of Hungarians have protested the measures, and the European Commission has warned it may soon take action if Hungary does not change course.

Disney’s live‑action “Beauty and the Beast,” directed by Bill Condon, starts filming at Shepperton Studios in May and opens in U.S. theaters on 17 March 2017. The cast features:
• an unnamed newly announced star as Mrs Potts,  
• Kevin Kline as Maurice,  
• Emma Watson as Belle,  
• Dan Stevens as the Beast,  
• Luke Evans as Gaston, and  
• Josh Gad as Gaston’s sidekick LeFou.

Acclaimed Sunday Times columnist and critic Adrian (A. A.) Gill has died following a recent diagnosis of multiple cancers, which he had described as the “full English.” Gill, 62, had been undergoing chemotherapy and had just completed a final column about facing his illness that will appear in tomorrow’s paper.  

Editor Martin Ivens hailed him as “a giant among journalists,” while colleagues and media figures offered tributes to his dazzling, fearless prose and generous character, noting that he dictated his copy because of dyslexia. Gill joined the Sunday Times in 1993 and became one of its signature voices, though his forthright style also drew controversy, from derogatory remarks about the Welsh to recounting the shooting of a baboon.

Born in Edinburgh in 1954, Gill studied art in London before moving into journalism in the 1980s. He was previously married to author Cressida Connolly and later to future Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children. His terminal illness prompted him to become engaged to long‑time partner Nicola Formby, mother of their twins.

Mongolian rapper Amarmandakh “Amraa” Sukhbaatar, front‑man of the group Khar Sarnai, was allegedly assaulted while performing in Ulan Bator. Witnesses say a Russian diplomatic officer struck him with a bottle and kicked him in the face after the artist took the stage wearing a traditional Mongolian robe embroidered with a swastika—a symbol that pre‑dates Nazism in Mongolia. Sukhbaatar spent about 10 days in a coma with serious brain injuries. His family and lawyer deny claims he shouted “Heil Hitler.” Mongolian police and the Russian embassy are investigating; the embassy calls some media details “distorted,” and the suspect has not been detained.

Plane Stupid activists protested on the airport’s northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday against expansion plans. Police have charged them with aggravated trespass and entering a security‑restricted aerodrome area; they are due in court on 19 August. The Metropolitan Police will review the airport’s security.

In overcast conditions at Cardiff, Glamorgan were dismissed for around 220, a total built almost entirely on opener Nick Selman’s fluent 101 from 144 balls – his second first‑class century and a welcome return after four consecutive ducks. Aneurin Donald’s brisk 36 and a late stand from Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten secured a batting bonus point, but Gloucestershire seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles kept wickets falling, Taylor knocking over the stumps three times. Gloucestershire’s reply began shakily in the evening gloom and the match ended the day evenly poised. Glamorgan were captained by Michael Hogan, deputising for the injured Jacques Rudolph (neck). Both Selman and Taylor said post‑play that the pitch offered help to the bowlers and that the contest looks set to remain tight.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested in August after drunken late‑night online chats with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee in which he threatened to lure North Wales Police to a fake crime scene on the Dee Estuary and shoot them. He admitted two related offences at Mold Crown Court, has a prior 2009 firearm conviction, and was on bail for other firearms charges (later cleared) when the threats were made. Judge Niclas Parry remanded him in custody; sentencing is set for next week.

Surrey recovered from 8‑2 to 255‑7, built around a 130‑run stand between Steven Davies and Ben Foakes (90). Yorkshire’s chase faltered when Stuart Meaker removed Jonny Bairstow, Gary Ballance and Jack Leaning in a nine‑ball burst; despite Tim Bresnan’s 68 they were dismissed for 236 with seven balls left. Surrey therefore beat Yorkshire by 19 runs to reach Lord’s, skipper Gareth Batty hailing the all‑round effort while Yorkshire captain Alex Lees rued a top‑order failure.

At 07:00 BST a 56 ft (17.1 m) converted trawler, located 6 miles (10 km) west of South Stack, reported flooding when its own pump failed to keep up. Holyhead coastguards dispatched an RNLI lifeboat, which supplied an additional pump and towed the vessel safely to Holyhead.

Scottish middle‑distance runner Laura Muir, 24, will skip the April 2018 Commonwealth Games because her final‑year veterinary exams fall in May. She recently placed 4th in the 1500 m and 6th in the 5,000 m at the World Championships, setting a 5,000 m outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 (a race won by Hellen Obiri). Muir may instead target the World Indoor Championships in Birmingham in March, but says completing her degree comes first and she expects to have several more Olympic opportunities ahead.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are nowhere near last season’s title‑contending level and will do well simply to finish in the Premier League’s top four.  

Key causes of the decline  
• Goals lost: Luis Suárez has been sold and the injured Daniel Sturridge has played only three of 10 league games; replacements Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert and Fabio Borini neither score nor press with the intensity Rodgers’ system needs.  
• Reduced attacking thrust: far fewer first‑half goals, few midfield runners beyond the striker and a big drop in set‑piece productivity.  
• Defence still shaky: heavy spending on Mamadou Sakho and especially £20 m Dejan Lovren has not produced a leader; Simon Mignolet is an excellent shot‑stopper but does not command his area.  

Chelsea match preview  
Savage expects another Chelsea win, calling the Blues “on a different planet”.  His suggested XI is: Mignolet; Johnson, Skrtel, Toure, Moreno; Can, Gerrard; Sterling, Coutinho, Lallana; Borini—with Lovren omitted and Borini preferred for his work‑rate.  Full‑backs must join attacks selectively to guard against Chelsea counter‑attacks.  

Steven Gerrard’s future  
Despite the infamous slip against Chelsea and doubts over a new contract, Savage believes the 34‑year‑old can still anchor midfield if he manages the physical and mental demands of age; Liverpool are unlikely to let him leave, but another top club would take him if they did.

East Ayrshire Council plans a £45 million education campus on Sutherland Drive, Kilmarnock, combining primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre. The council hopes to name it after celebrated Kilmarnock‑born author William McIlvanney, acknowledging his passion for education. McIlvanney, once an English teacher, became a full‑time writer in 1975, earning fame for Remedy Is None, the Laidlaw trilogy and other works that made him the “Godfather of Tartan Noir.” He was also a noted poet, journalist and broadcaster, and died at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

A suspected British sea mine from the 1940s‑50s was found in the river at Gourock on Monday. Today three nearby streets were evacuated, residents within 500 m were told to stay indoors with windows open, and a half‑mile exclusion zone was imposed on the water; small boats were grounded and Caledonian MacBrayne ferries to Gourock and Rothesay were disrupted. Police said the measures were purely precautionary, while Navy divers decided to move the deteriorated mine to a safer location because its remaining explosive content was unknown. Inverclyde Council thanked locals for their cooperation.

UK Sport has announced its 2017‑21 elite‑programme awards for the Tokyo 2020 cycle:

• Total pot: £345 m for 31 Olympic & Paralympic sports – £2 m less than for Rio 2016, with £9 m still unassigned.  
• Medal targets: 51‑85 Olympic and 115‑162 Paralympic medals (Rio delivered 67 and 147 respectively).  
• Sports losing all funding: archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby – and, most controversially, badminton, despite its Rio men’s doubles bronze and previous £5.74 m grant.  
• Major cut: cycling down by more than £4 m to £25.98 m.  
• Small rise: judo, even though it matched badminton with one Rio bronze.  
• Team‑ball sports (basketball, handball, volleyball) complain UK Sport “has no interest in team sports” after earlier removals.  
• New Tokyo sports (baseball/softball, karate, skateboard, sport climbing, surfing, plus Para‑taekwondo & Para‑badminton) await funding decisions pending medal‑potential reviews.

UK Sport chair Rod Carr and CEO Liz Nicholl say limited money must be targeted at the strongest medal prospects; government and lottery backing is confirmed. Badminton England calls the zero allocation “catastrophic” and vows to fight the decision.

Bournemouth councillors have approved (7–3) a redevelopment plan for East Cliff’s conservation area. Three Victorian hotels—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—will be demolished to build a six‑storey, 90‑room four‑star hotel plus two assisted‑living blocks of nine and seven storeys containing 122 apartments. Supporters (246 letters) say the project boosts tourism and senior housing; opponents, including 49 residents, the Ancient Monuments Society and English Heritage, argue the large‑scale scheme would severely harm the area’s historic character.

Off‑duty soldier Pte Matthew Boyd, 20, of the Royal Gibraltar Regiment, was attacked outside The Cellar bar in Brecon in the early hours of 8 May while walking back to barracks. Jake Vallely, 24—drunk after a seven‑hour binge and bragging he was “the hardest man in Brecon”—punched Boyd to the ground, beat him until he was motionless, then dragged the body away and fled. Boyd was later found unconscious by police and died; Vallely was convicted and will be sentenced on 8 December. Vallely’s friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after evidence showed he had left before the violence began. Police condemned the “despicable” attack, and Boyd’s family paid tribute to the popular young soldier, saying Vallely had left an irreparable void in their lives.

Barnet Council chief executive Andrew Travers has stepped down by mutual agreement after a major polling‑day error that left voter names off the register at all 155 polling stations, causing many to be turned away. The council has apologised, offered emergency proxy votes, and ordered an independent investigation, due to report by the end of May and to examine preparations for June’s EU referendum. Deputy chief executive John Hooton will act as interim chief. Travers, who served 3½ years and attributes the problem to faulty electoral lists, was thanked by the council for his contribution.

Gateshead beat Wrexham 2–1.  
• 18ʹ Josh Gillies put Gateshead ahead with a free‑kick.  
• 35ʹ Wrexham’s Sean Newton levelled, also from a free‑kick.  
• 78ʹ Ryan Bowman headed the winner from a right‑wing cross (credited in the report to Craig Baxter/Jamie Chandler).  

Manager reaction:  
– Gateshead’s Malcolm Crosby felt his side passed better after the break and praised Bowman’s goal.  
– Wrexham’s Gary Mills said his team were strong in the first half but “too open” later and failed to take their chances.

The 2014 Global AgeWatch Index, released on 1 October 2014, ranks the social and economic wellbeing of people aged 60+ in 96 countries: Norway places first, while Afghanistan is last, with Mozambique just above it.

OneWeb and Airbus are mass‑producing a low‑cost satellite constellation to deliver global broadband, with a priority on connecting schools.  

Key points:  
• Scale: at least 600 satellites initially, potentially 2,000+; about 300 in orbit by end‑2020, 600+ a year later, 800+ by mid‑decade.  
• Manufacturing shift: new assembly‑line facilities (first in Toulouse, two more in Florida) target three satellites per shift for under US$1 million each, using automotive‑style automation and a revamped supply chain.  
• Launch plan: more than 20 Soyuz rockets will place clusters of 32–36 satellites into 1,200 km orbits, beginning with 10 test craft next April and another batch in November.  
• Financing and position: US$1.7 billion equity raised; further loans in negotiation. Company is registered in the UK Channel Islands, giving the UK economic and regulatory involvement.  
• Competition: rivals include SpaceX, Boeing and ViaSat, but Airbus cites OneWeb’s first‑mover advantage.  
• Space‑debris strategy: satellites will be de‑orbited within two years; each carries extra hardware and a capture adapter to minimize collision risk, exceeding the five‑year guideline urged by ESA studies.  
• Broader impact: Airbus hopes the high‑volume approach will serve other customers, though bespoke “gold‑plated” spacecraft will still be required for specialized missions.

• Scottish Finance Secretary John Swinney says the UK government’s latest spending review imposes “unprecedented” pressure on Scotland, forecasting the Scottish discretionary budget will be 12.5 % lower in real terms by 2019‑20 than in 2010‑11, with 4.2 % of the fall still to come and more than £1 billion of additional cuts due before 2020.  
• Swinney, who unveils the 2016‑17 budget on Wednesday, vows to protect schools, hospitals and policing despite the reductions, citing past delivery of more police, lower crime, better schools, free university tuition and record health spending.  
• The UK Scotland Office counters that Holyrood will actually have £390 million more to spend next year (£750 million including underspend) and a nearly £30 billion block grant, claiming this is a better outcome than independence.  
• Scottish Labour’s Jackie Baillie accuses Swinney of “posturing” and demands a long‑term anti‑austerity budget, promising Labour would make different tax choices from both the Conservatives and the SNP.

Standard “accessible” toilets are often unusable for the estimated 250,000‑plus UK residents who require a hoist, adult‑sized changing bench and extra space, meaning they need “Changing Places” toilets (12 m², with specialist equipment and room for two carers). Only 893 exist nationwide, so many disabled people and their families are forced to change loved ones on dirty floors or in car boots, leaving them isolated and anxious. Although Changing Places specifications have been listed in Building Standard BS 8300 since 2009, they are only recommendations. Campaigners such as mother Lorna Fillingham (who has launched a petition and given evidence to Parliament) want them made compulsory in all new large buildings—shopping centres, cinemas, stadiums, etc.—because voluntary guidance is often ignored by designers focused on mandatory rules. Businesses cite space and cost barriers, yet examples like Arsenal FC show installation is feasible and welcomed by the public.

Italian consumer groups, backed by SEIU and several European unions, have filed an antitrust complaint with the European Commission against McDonald’s. The complaint alleges that McDonald’s exploits its dominant position by forcing franchisees into unusually long contracts, charging them above‑market rents and high fees, which purportedly limits franchisees’ ability to switch brands, raises prices, and reduces consumer choice. Franchisees run 73 % of McDonald’s European outlets. McDonald’s, which earned $9.27 bn from franchised restaurants in 2014, denies wrongdoing, saying it fairly shares risks and rewards with its licensees. The Commission will examine the submission and may open a formal investigation.

Thirteen‑year‑old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down was unexpectedly found to have a large primary cancer and five secondary growths during what was meant to be an appendix operation on Christmas Eve. To rally support, Bangor Elim Church—where Josh’s father is on staff—tagged posts with #prayforjosh on Facebook and Instagram. The hashtag soon went viral: one update was shared 948 times and viewed over 79,000 times worldwide, drawing encouragement from around the globe and especially from Josh’s Bangor Grammar classmates on Twitter. The online campaign even inspired an anonymous donor to fund a large #prayforjosh billboard beside the A2 at Holywood, symbolising the widespread backing Josh and his family have received during his cancer battle.

The Ministry of Defence’s latest estate reorganisation will:

• Close historic Brecon Barracks, in use since 1805 and currently employing about 85 civilian and 90 military staff.  
• Leave the nearby Sennybridge training area and Dering Lines infantry school open.  

Local Conservative MP Chris Davies calls the Brecon decision “abhorrent,” is launching a petition, and fears a blow to an area already facing high unemployment and reliant on military tourism.

Additional changes in Wales:  
• Create a specialist light‑infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan.  
• Shut Cawdor Barracks, Pembrokeshire, in 2024.  
• Close a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025.

Labour’s Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith supports rationalising the estate but warns the closures will cause uncertainty for affected workers and communities.

The House of Lords EU Committee says the UK fishing industry, though small (0.5 % of GDP, 12 000 fishers), must not be sidelined in Brexit talks. Because most UK‑caught fish are exported to, and much of what Britons eat is imported from, the EU, continued tariff‑free access to that market is vital; in return, Britain may have to let some EU vessels keep fishing in UK waters. The Committee urges retention of key parts of the Common Fisheries Policy—scientific quota setting, shared stock management and international cooperation—and warns that leaving the CFP could split fisheries governance into separate English, Welsh, Scottish and Northern Irish regimes. While many fishers view Brexit as a chance to take full control of the 200‑mile exclusive economic zone and boost exports, the report stresses that “trade‑offs” are inevitable. The government says it aims for maximum single‑market access while reshaping fisheries management to secure fair quotas, sustainable stocks and healthy seas.

Edward Snowden, a 29‑year‑old former CIA technician, has admitted leaking documents that outline large‑scale U.S. surveillance. The files say the NSA:

• Requests millions of Verizon phone records (numbers, duration, locations).  
• Uses the “Prism” programme to reach chat logs, voice calls, file transfers, social‑network posts and search data held on the servers of Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube and Apple.  

Washington claims the data helps stop terrorism but discloses no details; specialists doubt it is an unlimited “backdoor,” suggesting access may be target‑specific and court‑approved. Firm privacy policies already allow compelled disclosure, and most cloud data—often stored inside the U.S.—is reachable under the Patriot Act and FISA, even when it belongs to non‑Americans.

Other governments’ roles are unknown: the U.K. will not confirm or deny cooperation and the EU has demanded explanations. Officials argue security outweighs complete privacy, while critics and Snowden say the programme threatens the civil liberties of anyone using major online services.

OpenAI is a new, non‑profit AI research venture backed by Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys and Amazon Web Services, with a $1 billion pledge of which only a small portion will be used in the near term. Free from the need to generate profit, it aims to develop AI that benefits all of humanity and acts as an extension of human will. The project arises amid debate: figures such as Musk and Stephen Hawking warn that advanced AI could pose an existential threat, while other experts judge the danger to be remote.

Lance Bombardier Ben Parkinson, who suffered severe brain injuries in an Afghan bomb blast in 2006, carried the Olympic torch for about 30 minutes on 26 June with the aid of an assistant. His appearance prompted an overwhelming public response: more than 5,000 Facebook friend requests (exceeding the personal‑page limit), 19,000 page hits, a surge of mail and e‑mails, and numerous invitations to appear with the torch. Now speaking unaided, he trains up to 12 hours a day, walks with crutches, and devotes his remaining time to fundraising for military charities, notably as patron of Pilgrim Bandits. Facebook suggests he open a public page or use the “subscribe” feature to accommodate supporters. Parkinson is one of 8,000 torchbearers on the 8,000‑mile, 70‑day relay leading to the London 2012 Olympic opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011 the U.S. poverty rate stayed at 15%, keeping 46.2 million people in poverty after three years of increases and just below the 2010 record of 15.1%. Real median household income fell 1.5%, and the poverty line for a family of four was $23,021 (£14,300). Income inequality widened as the Gini index rose 1.6%—its first annual rise since 1993—while the share of Americans without health insurance dropped from 16.3% to 15.7%.

Wicket‑keeper‑batsman Jos Buttler, 25, who joined Lancashire from Somerset in 2013, has signed a contract extension that keeps him at the county until 2019. A short‑format specialist, he owns England’s three quickest ODI hundreds, highlighted by a 46‑ball century against Pakistan. Coach Ashley Giles hails his talent and influence, noting Buttler’s role in Lancashire’s 2015 T20 Blast triumph. After a stint with the Mumbai Indians in the IPL, Buttler will rejoin Lancashire for Friday’s T20 Blast match against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, Campbeltown, Chatham and Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour and up for disposal. Interested parties had to register by 23 January; bids are now being finalised, with ship viewings in late February‑March and a decision due in spring. The Ministry of Defence, via the Disposal Services Authority, aims to sell at least one vessel to a UK recycler to gauge industry capacity, while Portsmouth MP Penny Mordaunt urges that at least one ship be preserved, ideally as an artificial reef to boost tourism. The MoD will weigh all options for maximum taxpayer return, but is not disclosing bid details. Type 22 frigates were versatile 280‑crew warships, and last year the carrier HMS Ark Royal fetched £3 million as scrap.

Since 1987 Fiji has faced repeated military coups (1987, 2000, 2006) driven largely by tension between indigenous Fijians and Indo‑Fijians. The upheavals damaged tourism, the wider economy and Fiji’s international standing, leading to its 2009 suspension from the Commonwealth (lifted after promised 2014 elections). Emigration after the coups left indigenous Fijians a small majority, while social life remains informally segregated. Economically, Fiji depends on sugar and tourism but also mines gold, silver and limestone and has service and light‑manufacturing sectors; chronic trade and budget deficits keep it a major per‑capita aid recipient.

Syria’s Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad says Damascus is still committed to the UN‑OPCW plan to eliminate its 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, blaming a missed 5 February hand‑over deadline on two rebel attacks against convoys moving material from Damascus to Latakia. To date only about 4 % (30 tonnes) has left the country; Russia wants all stocks at the coast by 1 March and complete destruction is due by end‑June.

Mekdad also rejected U.S. criticism of government barrel‑bombing in Aleppo, insisting the army does not target civilians and accusing Washington of backing “terrorists.” The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and Aleppo activist groups say government helicopter barrel bombs have killed hundreds of civilians in recent days.

Separately, rebels from the Islamic Front and al‑Nusra Front stormed Aleppo’s central prison, reportedly freeing hundreds of detainees. Activists claim the facility is now in rebel hands, while state media says the assault was repelled and fighting continues.

Booker Prize 2014 key facts:

• First year the £50,000 prize is open to any writer in English, regardless of nationality; winner revealed Tuesday night at London’s Guildhall and broadcast on BBC.

• Shortlist of six:
  1. Neel Mukherjee – The Lives of Others (1960s Calcutta family and politics) – bookmakers’ favourite at 5/2.
  2. Howard Jacobson – J (dystopian love story; he won in 2010) – odds 4/1.
  3. Ali Smith – How to Be Both (dual narratives set in 15th‑century Italy and the 1960s).
  4. Joshua Ferris – To Rise Again at a Decent Hour (atheist New York dentist and identity theft).
  5. Karen Joy Fowler – We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves (family story with an unusual sibling) – best‑selling title so far (55,000 copies).
  6. Richard Flanagan – The Narrow Road to the Deep North (WWII Thailand‑Burma railway love story) – next in betting at 3/1.

• Sales surge followed shortlist announcement; Mukherjee’s weekly sales jumped from 97 to 507 copies.

• Critic David Brauner calls it a “weak list,” rates Jacobson strongest but doubts repeat win.

• Prize in its 46th year; judging panel chaired by A.C. Grayling with Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, Erica Wagner.

• Each shortlisted author gets £2,500 and a special edition; last year’s winner was New Zealander Eleanor Catton for The Luminaries (youngest ever at 28).

• The case centres on a celebrity, identified only as PJS, who is fighting to keep his identity secret in England and Wales after allegations of extra‑marital sexual activities.

• The Sun on Sunday wants to publish details of PJS’s “occasional sexual encounters” (including a 2011 three‑way encounter with two people referred to as AB and CD) that were offered to the paper in January.

• A High Court judge first refused an anonymity injunction, but two Appeal Court judges later granted one.  
  – News Group Newspapers then asked the Court of Appeal to lift the ban, arguing the story was already public in the US, Scotland and online.  
  – On Monday the Court of Appeal agreed, saying confidentiality was now “so widespread” that a permanent ban was unlikely and policing the internet was “hopeless.”

• PJS, who has young children and a famous spouse, has applied to the UK Supreme Court.
