  – The Supreme Court will decide whether to hear the appeal and, if so, whether to allow or dismiss it.  
  – An interim injunction preventing publication of PJS’s identity in England and Wales stays in force until that hearing concludes.

In short: PJS is seeking a Supreme Court appeal to preserve his anonymity after the Court of Appeal moved to lift a media ban, arguing his alleged affair is already widely publicised; the interim gag order remains until the Supreme Court rules.

Fosse Park, a retail site by M1 junction 21 that opened in 1989, was purchased in August for £345.5 million. The new owner, Crown Estates, is working with Blaby District Council to resolve planning issues and intends to: 1) tackle parking and traffic congestion, and 2) refurbish tired-looking units and common areas to improve the site’s overall appearance. Council leader Ernie White supports the plans, calling the park an important “gateway” into the city.

Disney’s live‑action “Beauty and the Beast” was postponed in Malaysia over a brief “gay moment.” The Malaysian Censorship Board has since cleared it with one minor cut and a P13 rating, but no new release date has been set, prompting cinemas to refund advance tickets. The edited scene shows side‑character LeFou grappling with feelings for Gaston, and the review has sparked widespread online criticism in a country where homosexual acts are illegal.

Landlords who rent to more than three unrelated tenants in Southampton must buy a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence costing about £1,000, yet the city council believes roughly 1,500 such properties remain unlicensed. Avoiding a licence risks fines of up to £20,000, and so far one company and 13 individuals have been prosecuted. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses with three storeys or more and at least five unrelated occupants; in Southampton it covers homes in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, Swaythling (since 2013) and Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, Bassett (since 2015). Shelter reports five‑to‑six daily calls from HMO tenants worried about eviction and substandard conditions, reflecting a wider shortage of affordable, regulated housing.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are trying to form a minority government to avoid a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate such a government but will not back its programme. The main obstacle is disagreement over water charges: Fianna Fáil wants them scrapped, while Fine Gael supports retaining them, with a commission on Irish Water being discussed. After the election—Fine Gael 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, Labour 7—no party has a majority and a taoiseach has yet to be elected.

A fire erupted Tuesday on the Italian ferry “The Sorrento” about 27 km off Mallorca while it was sailing to Valencia. The blaze, originating on a car deck, grew so quickly that all passengers and crew abandoned ship in lifeboats and were taken aboard the ferry Puglia for return to Palma de Mallorca. At least three people were air‑lifted to hospital, one with serious injuries. Several vessels assisted, the cause of the fire is still unknown, and authorities warn the damaged ferry could sink; counsellors are being sent to meet the rescued passengers.

• 38 MPs reported allegations – largely via social media – that some voters (notably students) cast two ballots in the 8 June UK general election, an offence punishable by an unlimited fine.  
• The Electoral Commission says the risk arises because Britain’s 381 local electoral registers are not linked to the national online registration site; the two databases cannot cross‑check entries.  
• Between 1 Dec 2016 and the 22 May deadline 4.9 million applications were filed (most online) but the register grew by only 1.4 million, indicating 30–70 % of applications were probably duplicates.  
• Duplicate handling imposed heavy administrative and financial burdens; the watchdog urges:  
  – integrating local registers,  
  – an online “check if you’re already registered” tool used in countries such as Australia, New Zealand and Ireland,  
  – requiring people registered at two addresses to nominate in advance which seat they will vote in.  
• A record 46.8 million people registered (500,000 more than 2015); 68.7 % turned out—the best since 1997.  
• Labour backs prosecutions for double voting but cautions against reforms that would deter young or student voters.

Former University of Nebraska football star Lawrence Phillips, 40, was found dead in his prison cell in an apparent suicide early Wednesday. After a brief NFL career with the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers, Phillips’ off‑field troubles led to multiple convictions, including assault for driving into a group of teenagers and for attacking a former girlfriend, earning him a sentence of more than 30 years. He had been housed alone after being accused of murdering cellmate Damion Soward and had just been ordered to stand trial in that case. Authorities have not said how he killed himself. Former coach Tom Osborne called him intelligent but unable to conquer his anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram and official mascot of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal in Chester during celebrations of the regiment’s eighth anniversary. Brigadier Andrew Williams awarded the promotion for the ram’s “good behaviour.” Derby XXX is the 30th ram in a mascot line dating back to 1858, when the first Private Derby was adopted by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot; the tradition was taken on by the Mercian Regiment in 2007. Joining the regiment in February 2014, the ram has an army number, receives pay for rations, takes leave during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate, has switched on Ashbourne’s Christmas lights, and has met Prince William at a memorial for the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool reached the Europa League semi‑finals with a sensational 4‑3 win over Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, overturning a 0‑2 deficit after nine minutes and a 3‑1 aggregate deficit with 33 minutes left. Dortmund’s Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre‑Emerick Aubameyang struck early, Marco Reus later made it 3‑1, but Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho and an injury‑time header from Dejan Lovren completed the comeback. 

Jurgen Klopp’s mantra of “turning doubters into believers” was reflected in both players and crowd: an electric, emotionally charged stadium (including a prolonged “You’ll Never Walk Alone” and a perfectly observed Hillsborough silence) helped unnerve Dortmund. Klopp’s touchline passion contrasted with the dignified presence of opposite number Thomas Tuchel, who admitted the belief in the ground felt “meant to be.”

The match showed Klopp’s stamp on Liverpool—relentless spirit, Origi’s emergence, Coutinho’s flair—yet also exposed defensive frailties (Alberto Moreno and Sakho’s positioning). With Sevilla, Villarreal and Shakhtar Donetsk still in the competition, Liverpool can eye both the trophy and the Champions League place it carries. Klopp has added incentive by banning his players from touching the “This Is Anfield” sign until they win silverware.

UK Brexit Secretary David Davis, after an EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee meeting in London, proposed monthly sessions to share analysis with Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland so the devolved administrations can feed into the UK’s Brexit strategy. He described the talks as constructive. Scotland’s Brexit minister Michael Russell welcomed the engagement but said the UK government still has not clarified whether it seeks to stay in the EU single market or customs union, insisting single‑market membership is vital for Scotland. Meanwhile, the Scottish government plans to oppose Westminster in the Supreme Court appeal on triggering Article 50, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe applying to be heard.

Thirteen cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham—including Daisy, Debbie, Denise and Diane, all cloned from the same adult ewe that produced Dolly—are undergoing intensive health checks. Led by Prof. Kevin Sinclair, the study uses physical exams, X‑rays and fMRI scans to look for cardiovascular disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis, testing whether cloning accelerates ageing, a concern that arose when Dolly developed early arthritis and died at 6½. Approaching their 9th–10th birthdays, the clones currently appear healthy; full study results are due next week.

• Shutter Speed, the unbeaten 4‑7 favourite trained by John Gosden and ridden by Frankie Dettori, captured the Musidora Stakes at York, defeating Vintage Folly by 1¾ lengths on very soft ground.  
• Gosden will now aim Shutter Speed at the French Oaks at Chantilly (10 f), while relying on Enable and Coronet for the longer Epsom Oaks.  
• Tasleet (14‑1) landed the Duke of York Stakes for trainer William Haggas; Jim Crowley steered him home ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas.  
• Gosden is unsure whether Derby hope Cracksman will contest Thursday’s Dante Stakes, given the soft going and the short 16‑day gap to the Derby.

• Sterling seesawed, ending Monday lower: –0.2% to $1.4226, –0.6% to €1.2605 and –1% against the yen, while the market “volatility index” touched 2008‑crisis highs.  
• Falls followed weekend polls putting Leave ahead; Betfair cut Remain odds to 68.5%. Analysts expect each new poll to hit the pound harder as the 23 June vote nears.  
• Hedge funds are heavily short‑selling sterling; traders say the currency has dropped more than 2% in two sessions, returning to April/March levels.  
• Brexit worries knocked shares: Nikkei –3.5%, Hong Kong –2.5%, FTSE 100 –1.1% (Lloyds –4.2%).  
• Leave campaigners argue the pound is only back at March levels and that a weaker currency benefits exporters—April trade data already showed a narrower UK deficit.

Braintree Town (“the Iron”) sit sixth in the National League, one point shy of the play‑offs. After a six‑hour trip they lost to Barrow, conceding inside five minutes; the defeat made it three losses in a row for Braintree while stretching Barrow’s unbeaten league run to nine. Manager Danny Cowley praised his side’s efforts, said their achievements to date are “remarkable” for a part‑time team, and vowed to embrace the challenge ahead.

From April 2015 Northern Ireland’s 11 new councils will take over most planning powers, deciding on house builds, extensions and other local developments that are presently ruled on by the Stormont‑run Planning Service. Supporters such as Michael Corr of PLACE see this as a democratic chance for councils to shape community and development plans, provided voters elect representatives who understand regeneration issues. Opponents, led by Friends of the Earth, recall 1960s allegations of housing bias and fear renewed favouritism, cosy developer‑politician links and opaque party funding. They demand strict codes of conduct and fuller disclosure of political donations, a decision resting with the Northern Ireland Secretary.

One‑year‑old cat Teenie was found in NiddryView, Winchburgh on 14 March with three air‑gun wounds (two to the shoulder, one to the left back leg, which vets later amputated). Owner Sarah Nisbett says the cat is now relearning to move, and worries that children could also have been hit. The Scottish SPCA is investigating, calling the shooter “callous” and urging the public to report information. Chief Supt Mike Flynn argues the case shows the need for the Scottish government’s proposed air‑weapon licensing, which would require owners to show a legitimate reason for possession. In last year’s government consultation, however, 87 % of respondents opposed such licensing, branding it “draconian” or “heavy‑handed.”

Liverpool have signed 24‑year‑old Belgium striker Christian Benteke from Aston Villa after activating his release clause, making him the club’s second‑costliest acquisition and seventh signing of the summer. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 Villa games and 15 last season after returning from an Achilles injury, says he joined to win trophies and buy into manager Brendan Rodgers’ project. With last season’s strike force misfiring after the departures of Luis Suárez and Raheem Sterling, Rodgers hopes Benteke—added alongside new forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino and the returning Divock Origi—will revive Liverpool’s attack. Ex‑boss Paul Lambert and former Reds striker John Aldridge back Benteke to succeed, praising his power, pace and goal threat while noting the higher expectations at Anfield.

A study for the charity Tablets for Schools, covering 671 UK state and independent schools, found:

• Tablet penetration: used in 68 % of primaries, 69 % of secondaries; 9 % of schools issue one per pupil, with academies the heaviest users.  
• Growth: school tablet numbers are forecast to double from about 430,000 (2014) to almost 900,000 (2016); 45 % of current non‑users plan to adopt them.  
• Achievement: no clear, isolatable link between tablets and higher academic results, though head teachers report better motivation, engagement and family involvement.  
• Pupil behaviour: two‑thirds take internet devices to bed; in one‑to‑one schools a quarter of secondary pupils call themselves “internet addicts.”  
• Literacy study: separate research by the National Literacy Trust/Pearson suggests touch‑screens particularly help boys and disadvantaged pupils learn to read.  
• Rationale: heads argue tablets mirror pupils’ home and future work environments and offer advantages over laptops (size, portability, instant start‑up).

Overall, tablet use in schools is expanding rapidly, is seen as motivational, but definitive evidence of improved attainment remains absent.

“Growing Up in the City,” at the Museum of Liverpool until 25 September, presents 25 photographs tracing children’s lives in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s. Chosen by Curator of Urban Community History Kay Jones from hundreds of archive images, the pictures depict both play and work, marking everyday scenes and special occasions such as a 1887 fancy‑dress ball attended by the well‑off Rollo children and an early‑1900s young maid in service. Together they offer a social history of changing childhood experiences—celebrating happy moments while acknowledging the hardships some children faced.

Torquay United (the Gulls) have signed two players:

1. Myles Anderson, 27‑year‑old centre‑back  
   • Cancelled his Barrow deal by mutual consent to make the move.  
   • Former Aldershot, Exeter and Italian‑based defender; could face Barrow on 18 February.  
   • Manager Kevin Nicholson sees him as the vocal, leader‑type the side needs.

2. Ruairi Keating, 21‑year‑old striker  
   • Recommended by ex‑Port Vale boss Micky Adams.  
   • Has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps; transfer awaits international clearance.  
   • Described by Nicholson as raw but highly motivated.

Torquay sit four points above the National League relegation zone after just one win in six matches.

Bolivia has passed a new child‑protection and labour law that:

• Allows children as young as 12 to work for others, provided they have parental authorisation.  
• Was signed by Vice‑President Álvaro García Linera (while President Evo Morales was abroad) after Congress approved it earlier in the month.  
• Includes tougher penalties for crimes against children, notably a 30‑year prison term for child homicide.  
• Aims to balance Bolivia’s widespread child labour—about 500,000 minors already work, many in informal or hazardous jobs—with international norms, and to help eradicate extreme poverty.  
• Is being reviewed by the International Labour Organisation, which normally sets 14–15 as the minimum working age.

Rosie O’Donnell, 50, suffered a “widow‑maker” heart attack after developing chest pain, nausea and fever at her Nyack, New York home. After looking up “women’s heart attack symptoms” online and taking aspirin, she saw a cardiologist the next day, who placed a stent in an artery that was 99 % blocked. O’Donnell, who recently ended The Rosie Show and is known for roles in Drop Dead Diva, Will & Grace and Nip/Tuck, urged women to recognize symptoms and call 911, noting she herself had not phoned emergency services.

Che Labastide‑Wellington, from Harrow, was stabbed at about 00:30 GMT in an alleyway near a party on Belvedere Way, Kenton, after a group of youths had earlier tried to force entry. The 17‑year‑old died roughly an hour later; another boy, 16, was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police say the party was properly supervised and Che was not involved in the initial dispute but appears to have been targeted later. Detectives seek witnesses who were between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at the time. Arrested: a 21‑year‑old man (murder), two boys aged 15 and 16 (murder, bailed until mid‑December), and a 14‑year‑old boy (offensive weapon).

More than 15 years ago Denmark’s cancer survival rates were poor, largely because patients with unclear or minor symptoms waited too long for diagnosis. In response, the country restructured its diagnostic pathway into three routes: 1) strict fast‑track targets for patients showing clear “alarm” cancer symptoms; 2) multidisciplinary hospital‑based diagnostic centres that rapidly assess patients whose symptoms GPs cannot explain; and 3) “yes‑no” centres offering quick tests for people with very mild symptoms to rule serious disease in or out. This reorganisation has improved survival rates without overloading services by streamlining GP‑specialist collaboration and ensuring every referred patient is investigated within 30 days. A Welsh delegation that studied the Aarhus model believes similar changes could help Wales narrow its survival gap with leading European countries.

• After the UK government decided to close the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), Powys County Council won the contract to take over the OFT’s national enforcement work on estate agents.  
• The Powys‑based team, headed by James Munro, will receive about £170,000 a year and will be able to issue warning and banning orders against estate agents who act dishonestly or break the Estate Agents Act.  
• Consumers will still complain first to their local authority trading‑standards offices; those offices will prosecute where necessary and pass any suspected Estate Agents Act breaches to the new Powys unit.  
• Munro hopes the project will showcase Powys’s ability to handle further external contracts in the future.

NHS Employers has backed a Nuffield Trust plan to retrain parts of the 1.3‑million NHS workforce so staff such as nurses and pharmacists can take on duties normally done by doctors, helping to ease shortages in junior‑doctor rotas and overloaded GP surgeries. The think‑tank cites existing pilots where nurses cover hospital‑doctor tasks and pharmacists support GPs, arguing this matches the shift toward managing long‑term conditions and that doctors make up only about 10 % of staff. While the report says extra money will be needed for training and could give staff more rewarding roles, unions and the BMA warn the idea must not become a cheap, quick fix or undermine doctors’ training and call for proper funding and support.

A crash at 03:00 GMT shut the A36 (Lower Bristol Road) in Bath near the First Bus depot. The closure lasted until 14:00 GMT, causing significant rush‑hour disruption to traffic and bus services. Police are investigating the collision. First says most routes are running again and expects a full service by the evening commute, thanking passengers and staff for their patience and help.

NRW says the proposed £1.3 bn Swansea tidal lagoon would kill about 21 % of salmon and 25 % of sea trout each year; Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) rejects this, claiming its own modelling shows a worst‑case loss of only about 2 % of all fish and alleging NRW will not disclose its methods. NRW insists it has shared extensive data, that independent experts have reviewed its work, and that its figures are the best available. The lagoon is intended as a prototype for larger schemes around Wales, and while the Welsh Government supports it, both ministers and industry await the UK government’s forthcoming verdict on the project’s viability.

Stormont DETI Minister Arlene Foster has announced the creation of an industry‑led agri‑food marketing body for Northern Ireland, to be developed by the Agri‑Food Strategy Board. Modelled on the successful Scotland Food and Drink organisation, it will give strategic leadership and better coordinate government and private‑sector marketing. The agri‑food sector supports almost 100,000 local jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as a boost to export‑led growth but cautioned it may affect the work of existing bodies and will be discussed further with AFSB.

The Woodland Trust is asking volunteers to help plant thousands of native saplings this Saturday at Brackfield Wood, about seven miles from Derry. The site is one of four new woods in a four‑year UK programme that aims to plant millions of trees in memory of those who died in WW1. Brackfield’s target is 40,000 trees—one for each of the estimated 40,000 Irish lives lost. Saplings and guidance are provided; participants should bring sturdy footwear. When complete, the wood, filled with trees and wildflowers such as poppies, will serve as a lasting wildlife haven and memorial.

• At the Harrogate crime‑writing festival, the 2014 Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award went to Hilary for “Someone Else’s Skin”, praised by judges as tightly written and powerfully atmospheric.  
• U.S. writer Sara Paretsky received the festival’s Outstanding Contribution to Crime Fiction honor for her 23‑year career creating the ground‑breaking female detective V.I. Warshawski and for founding the support group Sisters in Crime.  
• Festival programming chair Ann Cleeves highlighted the strength of the shortlist and Paretsky’s role in changing perceptions of female crime writers and protagonists.

Mitchell Santner, the 24‑year‑old New Zealand left‑arm batting all‑rounder, broke a finger in just his second match for Worcestershire in 2016, derailing the county’s T20 campaign. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes says there is “unfinished business” and confirms Santner will rejoin the Rapids after the June 2017 ICC Trophy, aiming to contribute with both bat and ball. Worcestershire have already secured Australian fast bowler John Hastings as their primary overseas player for the entire 2017 season.

• In February 2008, 47‑year‑old British millionaire Barry Pring was struck and killed by a car travelling about 75 mph with no lights or licence plates while he was trying to hail a taxi on a Kiev dual carriageway.

• At the time, his Ukrainian wife, Ganna (Anna) Ziuzina, 28, had returned to a restaurant to fetch a glove; witnesses described the collision as deliberate.

• An Exeter inquest, overseen by coroner Dr Elizabeth Earland, concluded Barry Pring was unlawfully killed, citing overwhelming—though largely circumstantial—evidence.

• Family and close friend Peter Clifford believe the death was a staged hit‑and‑run so Ziuzina could inherit Pring’s wealth; she attempted to claim assets within days, sold his belongings, moved funds, and legally stood to receive the first £200,000 of his estate. Computer records also showed she was having an affair.

• Ziuzina, a former lap dancer who met Pring online in 2006 and married him in 2007 after a four‑day engagement, refused to attend the inquest, saying her previous statements to Ukrainian police were sufficient.

• Ukrainian authorities ended, then reopened, a murder investigation in 2011; it remains open but is not actively pursued.

Charlie Fearns, a young boy from Litherland, Merseyside, requires experimental T‑Cell therapy available only at Seattle Children’s Hospital after a third cancer relapse and a failed previous transplant left no treatment options in the UK. His parents, Sophie and Rob Fearns, learned via email on Wednesday that an anonymous donor has paid the full cost of the therapy, giving the hospital financial clearance to begin treatment as soon as a schedule—expected next week—is confirmed. The family is “ecstatic,” “overwhelmed,” and deeply grateful for the donor’s generosity.

After leaked celebrity photos were traced to software that downloaded iCloud back‑ups, Apple has expanded its opt‑in two‑step verification to cover iCloud. When signing in from a new device, users must now enter a four‑digit code sent to a trusted phone or the Find My iPhone app; a 14‑character recovery key can restore access if the trusted device is lost. The change blocks tools such as Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker, whose developer confirms it can no longer list or fetch back‑ups. Apple also now emails account owners whenever a back‑up is downloaded. Critics welcome the upgrade but argue two‑factor authentication should be the default and note that losing or stealing the recovery key could still cause problems. Apple says it will push users harder to enable the feature and adopt stronger passwords.

• TV personality and former non‑league player Mark Wright is in talks to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town; exact details are still to be finalised, but he is expected to join the board as a director.  
• Billericay Town, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points off the play‑offs, were recently bought by multi‑millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who says he can invest about £10,000 a week.  
• The club boosted its squad in early March by signing 35‑year‑old former England defender Paul Konchesky.

• After a BBC probe into working practices at Sports Direct’s Derbyshire warehouse, the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee wants owner Mike Ashley to give evidence on low‑paid workers and minimum‑wage enforcement.  
• Committee chair Iain Wright’s letter gives Ashley until 21 March to accept one of several proposed Westminster hearing dates; refusal could lead the committee to pursue contempt proceedings via the House of Commons.  
• Ashley had instead invited the committee to a private meeting at the firm’s Shirebrook site, which the committee declined in favour of a public session.  
• Sports Direct has not commented on the letter; it has previously said Ashley will oversee a review of workers’ rights.

Opposition leader Boris Nemtsov began compiling a dossier on Russia’s role in Ukraine but was murdered before finishing it; his colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin, have now released the 64‑page report “Putin. War.” Drawing on open‑source material gathered since the 2014 annexation of Crimea, it argues that:

1. Regular Russian army units, not just “volunteers,” secured every major rebel victory in Donetsk and Luhansk, with soldiers admitting they were sent under orders.
2. Volunteers are recruited and paid about $2,000–3,000 a month, and total Russian spending on the conflict is put at roughly 53 billion roubles (≈$1 billion).
3. The report lists unit numbers, personnel names, and weapon photographs, though some images are hard to authenticate publicly.

The authors say Putin orchestrated the war to revive domestic popularity. Only 2,000 copies have been printed so far; many publishers fear involvement, and, like Nemtsov’s earlier corruption exposés, the report may struggle to spur public protest despite widespread online availability of its evidence.

Craig Nelson (also known as Craig Preston), 34, from Wath-upon-Dearne, Rotherham, was found dead with head injuries near the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A 41‑year‑old man and a 23‑year‑old woman have been arrested in Sheffield and remain in South Yorkshire Police custody.

Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones says he was neither shown nor involved in drafting Theresa May’s Article 50 letter, calling it the latest sign that devolved governments are being ignored. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns rejects this, noting repeated talks and the letter’s specific reference to Wales. May tells EU Council president Donald Tusk that, as EU powers return to the UK, Westminster will “consult fully” on which should be handed to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, and expects a “significant increase” in devolved decision‑making. Which powers—such as farming or regional aid—and whether funding will accompany them remain unclear; further detail may appear in Thursday’s Great Repeal Bill white paper.

On Friday night in Newry’s Nursery Drive/Parkhead area, attackers damaged two cars and targeted PSNI officers carrying out their duties. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin condemned the “mindless” assaults, while police appealed to parents to keep track of their children’s activities.

American Apparel’s board, responding in a San Francisco court to Dov Charney’s defamation suit, stated that the ousted founder and ex‑chief executive will never return, citing evidence of sexually explicit emails to female staff, racially derogatory remarks, and repeated violations of the firm’s harassment and discrimination policies. The board contends these actions make him unemployable and too risky for shareholders. Charney’s lawyer rejects the allegations, accusing the company of invading Charney’s privacy to gain leverage. Earlier, the company obtained a restraining order barring Charney from publicly disparaging American Apparel or seeking to remove its directors.

Great Britain’s men’s basketball team play Greece at London’s Copper Box in their sole home warm‑up before FIBA EuroBasket 2017. Greece, 92‑64 winners when the sides met in Patras earlier this month, are without three of those players for the rematch. GB guard Teddy Okereafor, a Stratford native, expects a strong atmosphere as several teammates make their London debuts. After this game, coach Joe Prunty’s squad heads to a four‑team tournament in Poland, then on to their EuroBasket group in Istanbul in early September. The match is broadcast 17:30‑19:30 BST on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website/app.

At the 2007 iPhone launch, a BBC reporter borrowed Phil Schiller’s demo handset so he could show it on the Ten O’Clock News, drawing both ridicule and complaints that the BBC was over‑promoting a product. Defending the coverage, he argued that some inventions—perhaps like the Model T—signal a “step change” in everyday life. A decade on, he feels vindicated: the iPhone sparked the smartphone era, putting pocket computers in the hands of billions, transforming tasks such as photography and spawning widespread industry disruption. Jobs’s breakthrough was pairing existing phone functions with an irresistibly simple interface, marking the true start of the mobile‑connected age, which companies like Amazon and Google now advance with AI products.

Near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, five cats—including seven‑month‑old Meereen who died on Monday—have died over the past two weeks after ingesting antifreeze. Tests confirmed the toxic substance in all cases. The RSPCA has not yet determined whether the poisonings are accidental or deliberate and is urging local residents to store chemicals safely and clean up any antifreeze leaks or spills.

Despite Syriza preparing to accept a third bailout that will impose higher VAT, pension cuts, subsidy reductions, privatisations and market‑opening reforms it once condemned, Athens is quiet and tourism is booming (airport arrivals expected to rise from 21 m to 25 m). Greeks may be waiting to see precisely what Alexis Tsipras has conceded for the €86 bn package after July’s bank shutdown convinced the government that “there is no alternative”. Tsipras remains popular even though fiscal austerity continues and monetary austerity persists because banks are still partly closed, threatening business credit and Christmas retail orders. The bailout’s success depends on restoring hope; many believe this requires creditors to cut Greece’s unsustainably large debt by 30–50 %, with Brussels—especially Berlin—showing restraint and granting relief rather than celebrating Athens’ capitulation.

Ross Kemp will make a short return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell—his first appearance since 2006—to join Barbara Windsor (Peggy Mitchell) in her final storyline. Peggy, who re‑emerged after leaving in 2010, tells son Phil that her cancer is back and will die of the disease in episodes airing this spring. Kemp said he could not refuse reuniting the Mitchell brothers with their mother for her farewell. Producers call the comeback a chance to showcase classic Mitchell family drama.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon, 26, had obsessively stalked 24‑year‑old Alice Ruggles and then murdered her last October. When police told her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, they immediately knew Dhillon was responsible. Dr Hills feels deep guilt for having earlier reassured Alice that ignoring him would be safe. Recognizing they all underestimated the danger, the family has launched the Alice Ruggles Trust to warn others about stalking. Dhillon denied murder but was convicted and given a minimum 22‑year sentence.

EDF’s board has approved funding for the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear plant in Somerset, but the UK government has unexpectedly ordered a further review and will not sign contracts until the autumn. The pause, announced by Business Secretary Greg Clark hours after EDF’s decision, surprised the company and has cast doubt on a flagship post‑Brexit investment. 

Key facts about the scheme:
• Cost: £18 bn; about one‑third to be provided by China General Nuclear.  
• Output: expected to supply 7 % of UK electricity.  
• Scale: 5,600 workers at peak, 230,000 t of steel, 4,000 km of cabling.  

Concerns:
• Environmental impact and high guaranteed price of £92.50/MWh (roughly double the 2013 market rate).  
• EDF’s financial strain—shareholders must raise €4 bn; senior figures Thomas Piquemal and Gérard Magnin have quit, calling the project risky.  
• Reliance on foreign state‑backed investors.

Industry bodies warn delays could threaten future energy security and raise costs, while Greenpeace argues the plant offers poor value compared with renewables. The decision marks the latest twist in a timeline that began with the UK’s 2006 pro‑nuclear policy, 2013 construction approval, and a 2015 EDF‑China investment deal.

England and Wales’ updated online divorce application now explicitly asks for “the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with.”  
• Family lawyers, including Margaret Heathcote (Resolution) and Georgina Hamblin (Vardags), warn that naming this third party heightens conflict, delays cases, and raises costs, because the named person becomes a co‑respondent who must receive papers and may respond.  
• Although Ministry of Justice guidance on the form says it is “not normally necessary” and there is “no obligation” to name anyone, lawyers fear petitioners will still fill in the box.  
• Previous forms only provided optional space for a co‑respondent.  
• In 2015 England and Wales recorded about 100,000 divorces: 12,148 cited adultery, 46,815 cited unreasonable behaviour.  
• Judges reportedly disapprove of petitioners drawing new partners into proceedings, and lawyers often advise against it, despite many clients’ initial desire to do so.

Critics from the forestry body Confor say Welsh and UK ministers focus too heavily on environmental objectives—such as planting native broad‑leaf trees and improving public access—while neglecting productive conifer planting needed for timber. Although conifer forests have long supported a Welsh timber industry worth over £450 million a year, at least 16,000 ha have disappeared since 2001, making Britain the world’s third‑largest wood importer. Only 90 ha of new woodland were planted last year, far below the 20,000 ha a year Confor says are required to meet government targets and mill demand. The Welsh government seeks a balance of economic, environmental and social goals through schemes like Glastir and its Woodlands for Wales strategy, but Confor argues current rules are too bureaucratic and threaten future timber supply.

A boy was struck and badly injured on Bank Street near Langloan Primary School in Coatbridge at about 16:40. Emergency crews attended and he was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where he is in a serious condition.

Russian defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko has presented Russia’s Ushakov medal to surviving British veterans of the WWII Arctic Convoys, including 91‑year‑old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, who said he felt “honoured and delighted.”  

The convoys sailed from Britain to northern Russia through extreme cold and constant German attack, losing 104 merchant ships, 16 warships and more than 3,000 Allied seamen; Churchill called it “the worst journey on earth.” Their cargoes helped the Red Army defeat Germany on the Eastern Front.  

Although the Russian embassy offered the medal in 2012, the UK Foreign Office at first blocked it under rules barring foreign awards for events more than five years old. After campaigning—despite the UK’s creation of its own Arctic Star in 2012—an exception was granted, and President Putin gave the first medals in London on 16 June 2013. The Ushakov medal honours sailors who showed courage in defending Russia or its interests.

• Inspectors found serious delays and weak enforcement in the “community pay‑back” (unpaid work) scheme: some offenders waited months to start and many were not penalised for non‑attendance (one did only 16 hours in 17 months).  
• Courts can impose 40–300 hours of unpaid work for offences such as theft or drug crime; about 70,000 people received such sentences in 2014.  
• The review of 100 cases and interviews with 86 offenders produced 15 recommendations. Key problems: poor organisation, offenders sent away even when they arrived on time, and the work viewed only as punishment rather than rehabilitation.  
• Inspectors acknowledged examples of well‑run projects where offenders gained skills and motivation to avoid re‑offending.  
• Chief Inspector Paul Wilson called performance “not good enough” and urged urgent action.  
• The Ministry of Justice accepted all recommendations and said it is acting to ensure offenders attend, work is tougher and breaches are punished.

Tabloid The Sun labelled comedian‑activist Russell Brand a “hypocrite,” arguing that his calls for an economic‑political “revolution” to help the poor clash with his own life in an upscale London home. Similar criticism arose when a Channel 4 News reporter asked Brand about his rent while he protested outside Downing Street; Brand dismissed the question and walked off. He has neither confirmed nor denied legal action against The Sun but has mocked the paper on Twitter via #TheSunLogic. In previous statements Brand concedes he is rich and has benefited from the current system, yet argues that his personal wealth does not invalidate the need to tackle inequality, pledging personal change and wider systemic reform.

J. Craig Venter, a biologist‑entrepreneur born in 1946, turned genome research into a race by launching Celera Genomics in 1998 to decode the human genome in three years, prompting competition with the publicly funded project; both published in 2001. Known for outspoken self‑promotion and private wealth, Venter first rose at the U.S. NIH, where he sped gene discovery in the late 1980s by sequencing expressed RNA rather than entire genomes, work some peers scorned. After funding disputes he founded The Institute for Genomic Research, releasing in 1995 the first complete genome of a free‑living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. In 2006 he created the J. Craig Venter Institute to build synthetic life; after more than a decade the team reported success—an artificial microbe dubbed “Synthia”—in Science. Venter also sails the world on his yacht Sorcerer II, cataloguing oceanic microbial DNA. Though often controversial for limiting data access and flaunting resources, his fast‑track methods have accelerated genomics and, he argues, synthetic organisms could spark a new industrial era by producing fuels and capturing carbon dioxide.

• Survey of ~1,000 English parents (26 Feb–5 Mar) – 628 had children who take school lunches.  
• 4 in 5 lunch‑taking pupils had tried foods at school they’d never eaten at home.  
• 50 % of parents said children later asked for those foods to be cooked at home.  
• Most‑liked vegetables: carrots, sweet‑corn, peas; least‑liked: aubergine, chick‑peas, spinach.  
• Study was commissioned by England’s School Food Trust after a Mumsnet poll suggested some parents resort to packed lunches because of fussy eaters.  
• Trust chair Rob Rees and Mumsnet co‑founder Carrie Longton say school meals, now bound by strict nutrition rules, expose pupils to healthier, more varied food and peer pressure encourages them to try it.  
• Uptake: about 40 % of English primary pupils (slightly lower in secondary) and 46 % of Scottish pupils eat school lunches.

Álvaro Morata, 23, is starring for Spain at Euro 2016. After rising through Real Madrid’s academy (10 senior goals, debut at 18) he moved to Juventus in 2014, with Real retaining a buy‑back clause of up to €30 million (£23 m). For Juve he netted 27 goals, won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and scored in the 2015 Champions League final after appearing as a substitute in Real’s 2014 triumph. Morata, linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, has three goals for Spain in the current tournament.

Wilson, 30, re‑signed for Nottingham Forest from Celtic for £2.5 m in August 2013, made 51 appearances in that second stint, was released in May and is currently without a club; earlier in his career he spent four seasons at Forest and also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world’s third‑largest retailer, is exiting its loss‑making U.S. chain Fresh & Easy. It will transfer about 200 stores and roughly 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 staff to Los‑Angeles‑based private‑equity firm Yucaipa, run by Ron Burkle. Tesco will lend the new business about £80 million and expects the overall exit to cost £150 million, although the loan may be repaid. Around 50 remaining stores will close. Tesco retains an option to buy back a stake if Yucaipa turns the chain profitable. The move follows Tesco’s first decline in annual profits in 20 years.

An athlete tells BBC Sport’s Nick Hope that after facing and overcoming racial abuse—and briefly weighing up competing for France—he is now focused on winning a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The piece also points readers to a guide on taking up martial arts.

• The only previous inventory of French Alpine glaciers (c. 1970) recorded about 375 km² of ice.

• A new survey, presented at the AGU Fall Meeting by Marie Gardent (University of Savoie), re‑mapped c. 600 glaciers in the Mont Blanc, Ecrins, Belledonne, Vanoise, Ubaye and Grande Rousse–Arves massifs using historical maps, satellite images and aerial photos, with manual checks to correct automatic delineation errors.

• Results show total glacier area fell to roughly 340 km² by 1985‑86 and to about 275 km² by the late 2000s—an average loss of ~26 % in 40 years.

• Retreat is uneven: southern sectors have shrunk most; Belledonne glaciers are almost gone and the Ecrins retreat is over three times that of the Mont Blanc Massif. Northern areas fare better due to higher precipitation, more cloud and greater elevations.

• France’s largest glacier, La Mer de Glace on Mont Blanc, has declined slightly from 31.5 km² to just over 30 km².

• Similar accelerated ice loss is being observed elsewhere in the Alps.

Scotland’s women have won all five Euro 2017 qualifiers and will virtually clinch a first‑ever major‑tournament berth if they beat fellow unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk on Friday; the return game in Reykjavik on 20 September should decide the group winners. After play‑off failures for Euro 2013 and the 2015 World Cup, 24‑year‑old Bayern Munich striker Lisa Evans says missing out again “would be devastating.” With the six best runners‑up also qualifying, Scotland are already well placed to reach next summer’s finals in the Netherlands without a play‑off.  

Iceland, ranked 20th (one spot above Scotland), are top seeds, but Evans believes home support could be decisive. Twelve of Scotland’s 20‑player squad now play abroad—five in England, four in Sweden, two in the USA (including BBC Women’s Footballer of the Year Kim Little) and Evans in Germany—experience Evans says is raising national‑team standards. She recently won the Frauen‑Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, celebrating alongside men’s stars Franck Ribéry and Arjen Robben, and feels the high‑level competition abroad is accelerating Scotland’s progress.

Stuart Campbell – Scottish‑born blogger behind the pro‑independence site “Wings Over Scotland” and a former video‑games reviewer now living in Bath – was arrested in western England after a south‑London woman alleged he had harassed her online for the past two years. The complaint centres solely on a series of publicly visible tweets. Campbell, who denies any threatening content and accuses the media of fuelling speculation, has been released on bail while Metropolitan Police continue their investigation, with a return date set for mid‑September.

Peta has asked Skegness to drop its historic “Jolly Fisherman” mascot—created in 1908 for a railway poster with the slogan “Skegness is so bracing”—and replace it with a fish mascot bearing the line “Skegness – A Happy Plaice.” The group says Jolly symbolizes cruelty to sea animals and that the change would present Skegness as a progressive, animal‑friendly resort. Mayor Carl Macey welcomes suggestions but doubts residents will support removing a figure widely viewed as cheerful and harmless, noting that, unless there is a clear need, the council is unlikely to replace him.

Georgia struck first through scrum‑half Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland then dominated possession (91 % in the opening half‑hour) and ran in six tries to secure a comfortable victory.

Scottish scoring:
1. Tommy Seymour try (Greig Laidlaw conversion)
2. Penalty try after collapsed maul (Laidlaw conv.; Georgian lock Kote Mikautadze sin‑binned)
3. Sean Maitland try (Laidlaw conv.)
4. Stuart Hogg try from his own chip‑and‑chase (Laidlaw conv.)
5. Hamish Watson try soon after the break (Laidlaw conv.)
6. Second Hogg try, finishing a long‑range counter started by debutant Ali Price.

Georgia’s other points came from two Merab Kvirikashvili penalties and a second Lobzhanidze try after their scrum shoved Scotland over the line; Scotland prop Moray Low was yellow‑carded during this spell.

Head coach Vern Cotter praised Scotland’s ball retention and game management, noting sloppier handling in the wet second half but overall continued improvement.

Starting line‑ups and replacements for both teams are listed in the passage.

Widnes Vikings beat Castleford Tigers 38‑28. 

Key points
• First half: Widnes led 14‑6 through tries by Macgraff Leuluai, Patrick Ah Van and Chris Bridge; Castleford’s only reply came from loanee Paddy Flynn.  
• Early second half: Flynn scored again for Cas, but Widnes surged to 38‑12 with tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor.  
• Late comeback: In four frantic minutes Castleford crossed three times—Larne Patrick, Luke Gale and Flynn’s hat‑trick effort—cutting the gap to 10, but Widnes held on.  
• Significance: Widnes, who had lost nine of their previous ten, climb to seventh above Wakefield; Castleford stay sixth, one point ahead of Widnes and suffer a fourth straight home league defeat.

Kuwaiti national Fawzi al‑Odah, 37, held at Guantanamo Bay since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan for alleged al‑Qaeda/Taliban links, has been freed. A U.S. Periodic Review Board ruled in July that he no longer posed a “continuing significant threat,” leading to his return home on a Kuwaiti government plane. Al‑Odah, who denies the charges and once challenged his detention in the U.S. Supreme Court, must spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant‑rehabilitation center under the release terms. He is the first prisoner released since May’s Taliban–Bergdahl swap, reducing the camp’s population to 148. Opened in January 2002, Guantanamo remains open despite President Obama’s pledge to close it, while Kuwait has actively sought the repatriation of its detainees.

Thousands gathered in London to mark Anzac Day. A dawn service at Hyde Park Corner was followed by a Westminster Abbey ceremony and a parade of about 400 people to the Cenotaph for wreath‑laying. The events, attended by veterans, officials and many Australian and New Zealand expatriates, featured prayers read by children and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand and the UK. Anzac Day honours the Australian and New Zealand troops who landed at Gallipoli in 1915—their first major World War I battle—and has been commemorated in London since King George V attended a service in 1916.

Striker David Clarkson, 30, has re‑signed for St Mirren after a July spell at Premiership Motherwell and is set for a possible debut against Alloa on Saturday. The twice‑capped Scotland international scored nine goals for Dundee last season but has mostly been a substitute this term; he insists he is fully fit after regular U20 matches and training. With nearly 400 club appearances—including stints at Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers—Clarkson hopes to help eighth‑placed St Mirren climb the Championship table and build momentum.

Bernard Matthews has been bought by food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. After talks with Unite, the new owner guaranteed that all existing workforce agreements, including the current pension scheme (the final‑salary scheme closed in 2004), will stay unchanged. Boparan plans to revive the company’s profitability by investing further, cutting costs and using surplus plant capacity to process chicken as well as turkey.

Since its 14 May launch, the new Cowes‑East Cowes chain ferry has repeatedly broken down, run aground, been halted by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency for training problems, and damaged cars during boarding. At a council scrutiny meeting, leader Dave Stewart called the start “frustrating and disappointing,” announced that crossings will be free until 2 July and ordered an independent audit review. Local businesses say six months of trade have been lost and seek compensation; transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is “up for discussion.” Ward added that electrical faults have been fixed, ramp extensions are being built to stop vehicle damage, and grounding issues linked to seamanship have been resolved, characterising the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems.

The House of Lords EU Committee says the UK fishing sector—small in economic terms but strongly pro‑Brexit—must not be sidelined in negotiations.  
Key points:

• Most UK‑caught fish are exported, mainly to the EU, while much of what Britons eat is imported, so continued tariff‑free access to EU markets is vital.  
• In return, the EU is likely to seek continued access for its boats to UK waters; Brexit will involve such trade‑offs.  
• Many CFP elements (scientific quota setting, shared‑stock cooperation) should be kept, and the UK will still face international obligations.  
• Leaving the EU could split management into four separate UK regimes.  
• Some in the industry see more opportunity than risk, citing recent quota increases and the prospect of full control over a 200‑mile zone.  
• The government says it aims for maximum single‑market trading freedom while reshaping fisheries policy for fairer, sustainable management.

Timothy Geaney admitted taking or allowing indecent images of children between 2004 and 2014. Earlier this year Dumfries Sheriff Court placed the 69‑year‑old on the sex offenders register, gave him a community payback order and required him to attend a sex‑offender programme; most images showed young boys partially dressed in erotic poses.  

At a subsequent General Teaching Council for Scotland hearing, the panel ruled that his decade‑long offending was incompatible with professional standards, posed a continued risk and showed no evidence of remediation. Consequently, Geaney was found unfit to teach, removed from the teaching register and barred from re‑applying for at least two years.

• A major fire on 2 March at Recovered Fuels Shipping Ltd’s waste site in Duncan Street disrupted train services and travel.  
• Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) had inspected the premises nine times in the past year and found the operators, Asset and Land Group, “broadly compliant” with fire‑safety laws.  
• GMFRS expressed concerns to the Environment Agency (EA) in February about potential risks to residents, transport and the environment.  
• Following joint visits, the EA suspended the company from accepting waste and has now revoked its environmental permit; the revocation takes effect on 7 August, after which the firm must cease operations and remove all waste unless it successfully appeals by that date.  
• The cause of the blaze is still undetermined, and the company could not be reached for comment.

• Syria missed the 5 Feb. deadline to hand over its full chemical‑weapons stockpile; only about 4 % (30 tonnes of 1,300) has left the country.  
• Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that Syria “is doing its best” to meet the timetable but convoys have twice been attacked en route to Latakia. He said the country is at war and security delays must be acknowledged.  
• Mekdad rejected U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry’s criticism of government barrel‑bomb use in Aleppo, insisting the army does not bomb civilians and accusing the U.S. of backing “terrorists.”  
• Monitors say barrel‑bomb attacks in Aleppo have killed 246 people, including 73 children, in five days; activists reported 14 more deaths on Thursday.  
• Rebel forces (Islamic Front/Ahrar al‑Sham and al‑Nusra Front) reportedly stormed Aleppo’s central prison, freeing hundreds, though state media claim the assault was repelled; fighting continues.  
• The OPCW admits the chemical‑weapons removal is slowed by security issues; Russia wants all agents moved to the coast by 1 March, and the overall destruction deadline remains end‑June. Mekdad says Syria will meet all obligations.

England crushed Pakistan inside four days at Old Trafford to square the four‑match series 1‑1.  
Key points:

• England totals: 589‑8 dec and 173‑1 dec. Pakistan replied with 198 and 234, giving England their second‑largest run‑victory over Pakistan.  
• Joe Root, promoted to No. 3, was Man of the Match: 254 in the first innings, 71* from 48 balls in the second, four catches and a wicket.  
• Captain Alastair Cook scored 105 and 76*. Pundits Michael Vaughan and Geoffrey Boycott hailed the performance; Vaughan called Root’s 254 his best Test innings.  
• Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs in their two innings; only Misbah‑ul‑Haq and Asad Shafiq have passed 50 in the series so far. Misbah blamed poor shot selection and low confidence but hopes for a response.  
• Pakistan play a two‑day warm‑up at Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Wales’s Older People’s Commissioner, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review of the quality of life and care in Welsh residential homes.  
Key points:  
• She is collecting first‑hand evidence from residents, their relatives, friends, care staff, providers and public bodies.  
• Findings will inform recommendations aimed at improving care and highlighting both good practice and shortcomings, focusing on health, relationships and the care‑home environment.  
• Rochira says correspondence shows “unacceptable variations” in care quality across Wales.  
• Care Forum Wales backs the review’s goals but criticises the absence of a care‑home provider representative on the commissioner’s advisory panel, calling it a missed chance for full sector engagement.

Paul Sheerin, 39, a former Aberdeen (Dons) midfielder and Arbroath’s player‑manager since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes selected him after “a comprehensive process,” according to chief executive Duncan Fraser, who praised Arbroath chairman John Christison for facilitating the move. Under Sheerin, Arbroath won their first national trophy—the 2011 Scottish Third Division title and promotion—but they were relegated to League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013‑14. Sheerin’s playing career included several Scottish clubs, a spell with Östersunds in Sweden, and a Scotland U‑21 cap in the mid‑1990s.

Caretaker duo Alan Curtis and Paul Williams will lead Swansea against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley’s dismissal, while the club hopes to swiftly appoint ex‑Derby boss Paul Clement as permanent manager. Curtis stresses the need for a leader who can avoid relegation, noting that dropping into an increasingly strong Championship would make an immediate return unlikely. He says Swansea have lost their distinctive “Swansea Way” since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, amid frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements, but believes the current squad can survive. Curtis also reminds new signings of the club’s rise from near bankruptcy in 2003 to Premier League promotion in 2011, underscoring how vital top‑flight status is for the club and community.

Craig Venter (b. 1946) is a biologist‑entrepreneur who repeatedly accelerated genome research by pairing bold technical shortcuts with private funding.

1. Early life: A poor student turned Vietnam field‑hospital orderly, the war instilled urgency and led him to medical research.
2. Sequencing innovations: At the U.S. NIH in the 1980s he adopted automated sequencers and, by analysing RNA rather than whole DNA, began producing gene data at unprecedented speed—drawing both scientific shock and criticism.
3. Private ventures:
   • 1992 – Left NIH to found The Institute for Genomic Research.  
   • 1995 – Released the first complete genome of a free‑living organism (Haemophilus influenzae).  
   • 1998 – Created Celera Genomics, forcing a race with the public Human Genome Project; both teams published the human genome in 2001. The episode made Venter wealthy but controversial over data‑sharing.
4. Synthetic life: In 2006 he launched the J. Craig Venter Institute to build a synthetic organism. After more than a decade the team reported success in Science with the engineered microbe “Synthia.”
5. Other work: A global ocean‑sampling voyage on his yacht Sorcerer II is cataloguing microbial genomes to probe evolution and protein function.
6. Vision: Venter argues that custom‑built microbes could trigger a new industrial revolution—producing fuels, capturing CO₂ and mitigating environmental damage.

Known for ambition, wealth and lack of modesty, Venter’s competitive tactics have sped up genomics while earning both acclaim and opprobrium.

Sutton Trust/Boston Consulting Group report says England’s apprenticeship system is a “patchwork” of mostly low‑level, short programmes. Key findings:

• Scale and level: Of 520,000 annual starts, fewer than 200,000 are level‑3 (A‑level) and 58% are below that; three‑quarters go to people over 25 already in work.  
• Employer engagement: Only 20% of English employers offer apprenticeships versus 51% in Germany.  
• Competition & choice: 11 applicants chase each place; England has 18,000 vocational qualifications compared with Germany’s 330.  
• International contrast: Germany creates 570,000 new youth apprenticeships a year, 90% at level‑3.  

Recommendations:

• Create up to 300,000 new apprenticeships annually, mainly three‑year level‑3; limit level‑2 to 10% and introduce some four‑year level‑4 routes.  
• Deliver training only in high‑quality institutions and improve careers guidance.

Reactions:

• Sutton Trust chair Sir Peter Lampl calls current provision a “cruel deception” that harms social mobility.  
• Association of Colleges supports higher standards but says expanding places will be “a massive challenge” and some respected level‑2 schemes (e.g., construction) must remain.  
• Department for Education says reforms are under way: minimum one‑year duration, more English/maths, and further plans to “drive up standards” will follow.

Britain’s 37‑year‑old Paralympian Sarah Storey won the time‑trial in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska. The victory gives her 16 world cycling titles, with a chance for a 17th in Saturday’s road race. Storey, who began as a swimmer and moved to cycling in 2005, is Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian: 22 medals (11 gold, 8 silver, 3 bronze) from six Games, including four golds at London 2012. Across swimming and cycling she now holds 21 world titles and is aiming for more success at Rio 2016.

• Hereford United’s long‑running financial crisis has ended in expulsion from the Conference Premier after the club repeatedly missed deadlines (5, 6, 7 and finally 12 June) to settle £148,000 owed to football creditors and other debts totalling about £225,000 (including more than £70,000 to HMRC).  
• A last‑week takeover by London businessman Tommy Agombar failed to secure the required funds; earlier, an offer from the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust to buy the club for £1 and clear debts had been rejected.  
• The expulsion voids Hereford’s dramatic final‑day survival on 26 April; Chester, originally relegated, are reinstated to the Conference Premier, while Hayes & Yeading stay in Conference South.  
• Former boss Martin Foyle (now at Southport) has issued a winding‑up petition over unpaid wages and has signed ex‑Hereford players Kingsley James and Dan Lloyd‑Weston, both still owed money.  
• Declining gates since relegation from the Football League in 2012 (average attendance down from 3,270 to 1,758) have worsened the club’s finances.  
• Observers note the league “bent over backwards” to help; supporters lament a “desperately sad day” but accept the club has “nobody to blame but themselves.”

Milner, 30, has ended his England involvement after earning 61 senior caps since his 2009 debut. The former Manchester City player was in the squads for two World Cups and two European Championships but featured for only three minutes at Euro 2016. He is England’s most‑capped Under‑21 footballer with 46 appearances (first in 2004) and scored his sole senior international goal in a 5‑0 win against Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, pioneering conductor and scholar of the early‑music movement, has died at his Cambridge home after several months of illness. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned later. Hogwood founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directed it on six continents for about 30 years, and oversaw more than 200 recordings, notably the first complete Mozart symphony cycle on period instruments and a celebrated 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. Trained at Cambridge and with leading harpsichordists, he began with the Academy of St Martin‑in‑the‑Fields and co‑founded the Early Music Consort of London. Hogwood also led the King’s Lynn Festival, Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, and taught at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell. Colleagues praised his generosity, scholarship, and lasting legacy in historically informed performance.

A Northern Ireland boy with special educational needs left mainstream school in June because he could not cope. His parents requested a special‑school place, but in September were told every special school in the South Eastern Education Board area was full and no admission date could be given. The child is now isolated at home, his mother having quit her job to care for him. An extra classroom assistant has since been hired at a local special school, and the family hopes he can start within weeks, yet they fear other families face the same shortage. The Education Authority said it cannot comment on individual cases but is reviewing special‑school capacity across Northern Ireland, aiming to improve local availability from 2016.

• Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) wants to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue; shareholders vote on 9 May.  
• Newport County AFC holds a legally binding 10‑year lease on Rodney Parade (to 2023) with fixture priority while in the Football League. Chairman Tony Foxall insists the deal must be honoured.  
• Newport RFC’s Will Godfrey says County and Newport Squash Club are protected by existing agreements, and the WRU has been informed.  
• WRU plans to lay an artificial pitch, which would breach Football League rules.  
• On the field, County sit two points above the League Two relegation zone with two matches left; a win coupled with a Hartlepool defeat would secure safety. Relegation back to the National League would be a major setback for club and city.

• Sierra Leone has just been declared free of Ebola after an 18‑month epidemic that killed about 3,955 people there and 11,314 in total (4,808 in Liberia, 2,536 in Guinea, 8 in Nigeria, 1 in the US, 6 in Mali).  

• The BBC interviewed a man who was kidnapped at 15 by Revolutionary United Front rebels during the civil war (1991‑2002).  
  – Branded “RUF”, drugged and threatened with mutilation or death, he took part in looting and killings.  
  – He later escaped to Freetown, was jailed for petty crime, and met preacher Richard Cole, founder of Lifeline Nehemiah, who helped him finish school and dedicate himself to rebuilding the nation.  

• When Ebola struck in 2014, he and Lifeline Nehemiah treated the outbreak as a “common enemy”:  
  1. Educated more than 10,000 people in local languages about the disease and how to stay safe.  
  2. Delivered food and supplies to roughly 11,000 people in urban and rural areas.  
  3. Partnered with other agencies and community chiefs to build an Ebola treatment unit that saved many lives, despite starting with no funds.  

• He now sees himself as a changed person committed to investing in Sierra Leone’s youth so they can help shape the country’s—and the world’s—future.

A threatened sale of the Wedgwood Museum’s 80,000‑piece collection—valued at £15.75 m and earmarked to cover Waterford Wedgwood’s pension debt—has been averted. A public appeal led by the Art Fund met its fundraising target within a month (launched September). The Art Fund will buy the collection, gift it to the Victoria and Albert Museum, and the V&A will permanently loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, keeping the works together and on public view. Administrators Begbies Traynor confirmed the deal on Monday; supporters, including MP Tristram Hunt and the Wedgwood family, hailed it as vital for preserving an important part of Britain’s cultural heritage.

TV personality and former non‑league footballer Mark Wright is negotiating to buy a 20% stake in Billericay Town, with details still to be finalised; he is expected to join the board.  
The club, recently bought by millionaire Glenn Tamplin—who says he can invest £10,000 a week—currently sits eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off the play‑offs, and has just signed ex‑England defender Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1‑1. 

Key events  
• 12': Blackpool took the lead when Nathan Delfouneso chipped into the box and Jamille Matt finished from close range.  
• 17': Keeper Sam Slocombe brilliantly denied Matthew Briggs, but from the ensuing corner Colchester’s Kurtis Guthrie scrambled in the equaliser.  
• First‑half stoppage: Slocombe twice kept Colchester out, saving George Elokobi’s close‑range shot and seeing Guthrie hit the bar.  
• 75': Blackpool’s Tom Aldred headed wide when unmarked, squandering the hosts’ best late chance.  
• Added time: Colchester substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a reckless tackle on Jim McAlister.  

Result: Blackpool 1 – 1 Colchester United, with Colchester finishing the match with ten men.

Fawley Waterside plans to turn the 198 m‑high chimney of the disused Fawley oil‑fired power station (closed 2013) into the tallest visitor attraction south of The Shard, making it the focal point of a £1 billion “merchant city” scheme. The 300‑acre redevelopment, bought in 2016, will include a marina, housing, restaurants and fast ferries to Southampton and Portsmouth, with an outline planning application due this year and construction hoped to start in 2018. Built in 1971 beside the Esso refinery, the 2,000 MW plant once supplied electricity to a million homes and contained 1,100 miles of cabling. Developer Aldred Drummond says keeping the existing chimney offers a ready‑made landmark comparable to Brighton’s i360 or Portsmouth’s Spinnaker Tower.

At the Hong Kong Track Cycling World Championships, 23‑year‑old Briton Chris Latham claimed bronze in the men’s scratch race—GB’s second medal after Elinor Barker’s earlier silver in the women’s scratch. Adrian Teklinski (Poland) took gold and Lucas Liss (Germany) silver.  

Elsewhere:  
• Men’s team pursuit – GB finished fourth, losing the bronze ride‑off to Italy.  
• Men’s keirin – Joe Truman was eliminated in the semi‑finals.  
• Women’s team pursuit – the youthful quartet of Barker, Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd and Ellie Dickinson qualified fifth and missed the medal round.  
• Women’s sprint – Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant went out in round one; she still has the 500 m time trial and keirin to contest.  

Pundits praised Latham’s perfectly‑timed sprint and viewed the young women’s pursuit squad as promising for Tokyo 2020.

Ross Kemp will make a short return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell after a ten‑year absence. He is coming back because Peggy Mitchell – played by Dame Barbara Windsor, who recently re‑appeared to reveal her cancer has returned – will die in episodes airing this spring. Kemp says reuniting the Mitchell brothers (Grant and Phil, played by Steve McFadden) for their mother’s final moments felt right, and producers describe the storyline as a chance to showcase both actors in classic, emotional scenes.

Liverpool beat Tottenham 2‑0 at Anfield with two Sadio Mané goals in 138 seconds. Mauricio Pochettino criticised his side’s first‑half display, saying the lack of desire and inability to handle pressure show they are “not ready to fight for the Premier League”; a Chelsea win at Burnley could move Spurs 12 points adrift. Tottenham have won only twice away since 24 September and just once in their last 17 away matches against fellow top‑six teams. Pundit Danny Murphy highlighted their uncharacteristically poor defending, noting that abandoning their usual back‑three system and a lack of pace and belief on the road are major problems that must be fixed quickly.

The 11 April state elections dealt Nigeria’s ruling Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) its worst setback since civilian rule began in 1999.  

1. Results  
   • The opposition All Progressives Congress (APC) captured 19 of the 28 governorships declared; the PDP won 8, Taraba is pending, Imo was ruled inconclusive, and seven states did not vote this cycle.  
   • APC victories included most northern states, the outgoing vice‑president’s home states of Katsina and Kaduna, Adamawa (Boko Haram–hit), and the commercial hub Lagos.  
   • PDP retained Rivers and all five oil‑producing states but otherwise was reduced to a south‑east/Niger‑Delta stronghold.

2. Political implications  
   • Coming a month after Muhammadu Buhari’s presidential win, the governorship sweep gives the APC unprecedented national dominance and relegates the PDP to a regional party.  
   • Buhari, to be sworn in on 29 May, still faces unrest risks in oil states that remain under PDP control.

3. Conduct of the poll  
   • The electoral commission recorded 66 violent incidents—mainly in southern states—yet observers judged the vote calmer than previous contests.

4. Reasons for PDP decline (analysis)  
   • Voter desire for change after 16 years of PDP rule, high‑profile defections to the APC, corruption allegations, and perceived failure against Boko Haram all hurt the party.

Overall, the elections consolidate APC control of Nigeria’s presidency, key northern states, and Lagos, while exposing PDP’s shrinking national reach and setting new political dynamics for Buhari’s incoming administration.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) is introducing an augmented‑reality app that lets users scan on‑site signs and posters to access videos, band interviews, ticket links and other updates on their phones or tablets. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean. The feature aims to enhance visitors’ experience and allow people worldwide to sample the festival’s atmosphere.

Ofsted has rated five Birmingham “Trojan Horse” academies inadequate.  
1. Park View School and its sister primary, Nansen, have had formal notice from Education Minister Lord Nash that their academy‑funding agreements will be terminated; this could remove Park View Educational Trust from running them.  
2. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School received similar letters: they must end discrimination against non‑Muslims, stop gender segregation, and broaden the curriculum by 4 July or also face funding loss.  
3. Saltley School, the only local‑authority school placed in special measures, will get a temporary governing board and new leadership to improve standards.  

Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw says a “culture of fear and intimidation” and an “organised campaign” to impose a narrow faith‑based agenda exist in these schools. Reports cite inadequate safeguarding and unvetted extremist speakers. Some parents and staff dispute Ofsted’s findings, claiming bias, and have asked Education Secretary Michael Gove for an open meeting.

Eight‑year‑old Vincent “Vinnie” Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at a Boots store in Ipswich. Prosecutors at Ipswich Crown Court allege that optometrist Honey Rose, 35, from Newham, east London, failed to spot Vinnie’s swollen optic discs and to refer him for urgent care. They say this omission allowed brain fluid to build up, raising skull pressure and causing his death, and argue her conduct fell so far below professional standards that it was criminal. Rose denies the charge of gross‑negligence manslaughter. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, arranged and filmed sexual encounters between a woman and a man he found online, then sent an explicit clip to the woman’s sister on Christmas Day 2014. Tried at Dundee Sheriff Court, he was found guilty of coercing the woman into sex (Sept 2013–Sept 2014) and of making her sister and father view sexual images, as well as threatening or abusive behaviour on 25 December 2014. Placed on the sex‑offenders register and deemed a moderate re‑offending risk, Weatherhogg’s case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing, where the judge said punishment must match society’s abhorrence.

Afghanistan beat Ireland in the first T20 in Greater Noida, reaching 171‑4 with two overs left after Ireland had posted 165‑5. For Ireland, Stuart Thompson scored 56, Gary Wilson 41* and William Porterfield 39, but Paul Stirling fell for 0. Afghanistan’s chase was led by Samiullah Shenwari (56), Mohammad Shahzad (47) and Najeeb Tarakai (27); spinner Amir Hamza took 2‑23. Porterfield said Ireland were about 15 runs short and did not bowl well enough. Paceman Boyd Rankin missed the T20s with a back injury but should return for the ODIs starting 15 March. The sides play the second T20 at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona originally said Neymar’s 2013 transfer from Santos cost €57 m (£48.6 m), but court documents allege the total outlay—once signing‑on fees, wages, agents’ commissions and an additional tax payment—is about €130 m (£106.8 m). Amid an investigation into possible tax fraud tied to the deal, ex‑president Sandro Rosell resigned and is also under scrutiny, though he denies wrongdoing. To forestall further legal action, the club has made an extra tax declaration of €13.55 m while insisting it committed no offence. Neymar, 22, has scored seven La Liga and three Champions League goals for Barça this season.

British tourists David Miller, 24, from Jersey, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, from Great Yarmouth, were found murdered on Koh Tao beach on 15 September. A Metropolitan Police team has finished reviewing the Thai investigation and will return to the UK to report to the victims’ families, thanking Thai authorities for their cooperation.  

Thai police are holding two 21‑year‑old Myanmar migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who allegedly confessed to the killings; officers deny claims the confessions were later withdrawn. The pair are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape and robbery, offences that carry a possible death penalty.  

British officials previously raised concerns with Thailand over DNA verification and alleged suspect mistreatment. The UK review followed an agreement between Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan‑ocha and UK Prime Minister David Cameron. Post‑mortems showed Miller died from drowning and head trauma, while Witheridge died from head injuries; Thai police say DNA from Witheridge matches the suspects.

Scotland’s women have won all five Euro 2017 qualifiers and can all but clinch a first‑ever major‑tournament berth by beating fellow unbeaten Iceland at Falkirk on Friday; the return in Reykjavik on 20 September should decide the group winner. Forward Lisa Evans, twice a play‑off loser with Scotland, says another near‑miss would be “devastating”, but believes the side “have a really good chance”. With the six best runners‑up also qualifying automatically, Scotland are well placed even without a play‑off.

Iceland are top seeds and ranked one spot higher at 20th, yet Evans hopes for a big home crowd. Twelve of Scotland’s 20‑player squad now play abroad; Evans herself has just won the German Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and says overseas experience is raising national‑team standards.

Apple has extended its opt‑in two‑step verification to cover iCloud back‑ups after celebrity photos were stolen, blocking the Elcomsoft tool thought to have been used in the hacks.  
Now, when an Apple ID is entered on a new device a user must also supply a four‑digit code sent to a trusted phone or the Find My iPhone app; without it, access to iCloud and iTunes/iBooks/App Store purchases is denied. A 14‑character recovery key can restore access if the trusted device is lost.  

Security researcher Vladimir Katalov, whose software could previously download iCloud back‑ups, says the new system prevents that and now emails users whenever a back‑up is downloaded. He warns that losing or having the recovery key stolen could create new risks.  

Professor Alan Woodward argues the bigger issue is that two‑factor authentication should be enabled by default, a step Apple chief Tim Cook says the company will promote more aggressively along with stronger password use.

During the 23 Jan–22 May European‑election campaign:

• Spending by party  
  – Conservatives: £2,980,815  
  – UKIP (election winner): £2,956,737  
  – Liberal Democrats: £1,580,575  
  – Labour (2nd place): £1,027,339  
  – Green Party: £534,249  
  – SNP: £267,372  

• Cost per vote  
  – Labour: 26p  
  – Greens: 43p  
  – UKIP: 68p  
  – Conservatives: 79p  
  – Liberal Democrats: £1.45  

• Results noted  
  – UKIP won; Labour came second.  
  – Lib Dems lost 11 of their 12 MEPs.
