• Overall, the six parties together spent £9,347,087, and all except Labour spent more than in the 2009 European campaign.

• Centre‑back Myles Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow deal to sign for their National League rivals Torquay United and may face Barrow on 18 February.  
• Torquay have also agreed to sign 21‑year‑old striker Ruairi Keating, previously with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps; the move needs international clearance.  
• Manager Kevin Nicholson calls Anderson the experienced leader he wanted and describes Keating as young but eager.  
• Torquay sit four points above the relegation zone, with just one win in their last six matches.

Many Clouds, a 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding, collapsed and died from a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage” shortly after defeating Thistlecrack in the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day. The British Horseracing Authority called such episodes rare and unrelated to any significant pre‑existing health problems. Although the horse had previously shown post‑race overheating and ataxia, he had never collapsed before and displayed none of those symptoms on Saturday. Winner of the 2015 Gold Cup trial and 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, Many Clouds was described by trainer Oliver Sherwood as the “horse of a lifetime.”

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears during the Scottish Parliament’s farewell session for departing MSPs.  
• Ex‑First Minister Alex Salmond, Marwick and veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil are all standing down before the 5 May election.  
• In his valedictory address Salmond repeated his view that Scotland is “not divided, but diverse,” welcomed new powers from the Scotland Bill while saying they fall short of referendum promises, and signed off with “goodbye… for now,” peppering his speech with humour about Cheltenham and the coming election.  
• McNeil, an MSP since 1999, urged Holyrood to strengthen accountability and learn from Westminster’s committee system.  
• Marwick praised Salmond’s service and had earlier been visibly emotional after McNeil’s speech.  
• Former Scottish Conservative leader Annabel Goldie is also leaving, joking she will miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

Disney’s live‑action “Beauty and the Beast,” directed by Bill Condon, begins filming at Shepperton Studios in May and opens in U.S. cinemas on 17 March 2017.  
Confirmed casting:  
• (Unnamed in the excerpt) star as Mrs Potts, the teapot housekeeper originally voiced by Angela Lansbury.  
• Kevin Kline as Maurice, Belle’s father.  
• Emma Watson as Belle.  
• Dan Stevens as the Beast.  
• Luke Evans as Gaston.  
• Josh Gad as LeFou, Gaston’s sidekick.

On the day of summary, the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will meet victims’ families at 11:00 BST in Warrington to announce whether anyone will face charges over the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, in which 96 football fans died. The CPS is considering evidence on 23 suspects: 15 from Operation Resolve (examining the disaster’s causes) and eight from the Independent Police Complaints Commission investigation into police actions afterward. Relatives, including Margaret Aspinall of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, say the announcement marks another step in their long struggle for accountability following last year’s inquest verdict that the victims were unlawfully killed.

Chelmsford Prison has recently seen repeated attempts to smuggle contraband, with many packages being thrown over its walls. A former inmate says the jail is well‑known for widespread availability of mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, and claims drones have delivered items, although the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) says there is no proof of drone use at Chelmsford. Local residents have witnessed packages being hurled four times in two weeks and have been invited to a meeting on how to respond. The MoJ states staff work hard to block contraband but more action is planned at the justice secretary’s request; smuggling items over prison walls now carries a potential two‑year prison sentence.

• 72‑year‑old lollipop lady Sylvia Blackburn suffered serious head injuries when she was struck outside Bedford Road Lower School, Kempston, in December.  
• Driver Brian Wright, 55, admits hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, claiming the low evening sun blinded him.  
• Prosecutors say Wright drove his VW Golf through a red light while Blackburn, in high‑visibility clothing, was helping a woman and her six‑year‑old cross the road; other traffic had already stopped.  
• Wright expressed remorse in court, and proceedings were briefly paused so he could compose himself.  
• Blackburn is now in residential care; the trial at Luton Crown Court is ongoing.

Scottish middle‑distance runner Laura Muir, 24, will skip the 2018 Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her final‑year veterinary exams fall a month later. Fresh from the World Athletics Championships, where she placed fourth in the 1500 m and sixth in the 5,000 m (setting an outdoor PB of 14:52.07), Muir returns to university next week to finish her degree. Though “gutted” to miss a rare chance to represent Scotland, she is eyeing March’s World Indoor Championships in Birmingham and believes she still has “two, even three more Olympics” ahead. Hellen Obiri won the London 5,000 m ahead of Almaz Ayana and Sifan Hassan.

Trevor Deely, 22, vanished while walking home from a Christmas party in Dublin in December 2000. Gardaí have begun a weeks‑long excavation of a three‑acre woodland site beside the R112 in Chapelizod as part of a fresh investigation led by six detectives. Enhanced CCTV shows Deely speaking with, and later being followed by, an unidentified man in black outside the Bank of Ireland; police released the footage in April and are again appealing for that man to come forward.

• Juan Martín Del Potro (ranked 165 after long injury lay‑off and three wrist operations) upset 4th seed Stan Wawrinka 3‑6 6‑3 7‑6(2) 6‑3 at Wimbledon, his first Slam since 2014; he next meets Lucas Pouille or Donald Young and sits in Andy Murray’s half of the draw.  
• Del Potro, Wimbledon semi‑finalist in 2013, said the win “feels amazing” and that he is “enjoying playing tennis again.”  
• Also in Murray’s half, 15th seed Nick Kyrgios edged Dustin Brown 6‑7 6‑1 2‑6 6‑4 6‑4 after rain delays; he will play 22nd seed Feliciano Lopez, who rallied past Fabio Fognini 3‑6 6‑7 6‑3 6‑3 6‑3. The Kyrgios/Lopez winner could face Murray (or John Millman) in the last 16.  
• Routine second‑round wins: 10th seed Tomas Berdych beat Benjamin Becker 6‑4 6‑1 6‑2; 12th seed Jo‑Wilfried Tsonga beat Juan Monaco 6‑1 6‑4 6‑3.

• Morocco and Tunisia both risked missing the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations but have now been cleared to compete.  
• Morocco’s earlier ban (and US$1 m fine) for refusing to host the 2015 finals over Ebola fears was overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, cutting the fine to US$50 000.  
• Tunisia faced expulsion after sending an angry letter to CAF about refereeing in their quarter‑final defeat by Equatorial Guinea; they avoided the ban by apologising in March after talks with CAF president Issa Hayatou.  
• Moroccan FA president Fouzi Lekjaa and Tunisian vice‑president Maher Snoussi say relations with CAF are repaired.  
• 2017 qualifying draw: Tunisia meet Togo, Liberia and Djibouti in Group A; Morocco play Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé in Group F. Tunisia’s appearance in Gabon would be their 13th consecutive Nations Cup finals.

McLaren, once a dominant Formula 1 force with 182 race wins, 12 drivers’ titles and 8 constructors’ crowns, is now reduced to targeting the fourth or, at best, third row of the grid and “decent points.”  

Key points in the team’s rise‑and‑fall cycle:  
• Golden eras: mid‑1980s with Porsche engines, 1988‑‑91 Honda partnership (15 wins from 16 in 1988 with Senna/Prost), and 1998‑99 Mercedes period with Mika Häkkinen.  
• Trophies have dried up since Lewis Hamilton’s 2008 title; the last constructors’ championship was 1998.  
• Major setbacks: 2007 “spygate” (stripped of constructors’ points, fined $100 m) and 2009 “lie‑gate.”  
• Performance slump began in 2013 when chassis design faltered; today the car is strong but the returning Honda engine is weak.  
• Ron Dennis, back in charge since 2014, and double champion Fernando Alonso believe a turnaround is imminent and that McLaren will be the team to end Mercedes’ current dominance—yet, for now, that hope is all they have.

Joe’s Bar in Dungiven stayed open and served alcohol until at least 04:49 BST on 6 October 2014, when paramedics were called to a sudden death at 06:00. Police found patrons still inside. Limavady Magistrates Court ordered the bar closed for three months. License holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, was charged with two counts of allowing drinking after hours and fined £3,000; James Thomas, 44, faced one count and was fined £1,000. The judge condemned O’Neill’s “appalling” record and said the premises had been run improperly.

Stephen Curry hit eight 3‑pointers—giving him a new NBA single‑season record—and scored 45 points as Golden State erased a 13‑point deficit to beat Portland 116‑105; Klay Thompson added 26 points. For the Blazers, LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and Damian Lillard 20.

In Chicago, the Bulls overturned a 19‑point halftime deficit with a 39‑8 third‑quarter surge to defeat Miami 89‑78. Pau Gasol posted 16 points and 15 rebounds, Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson scored 14 apiece, and Derrick Rose had 12 as Chicago reclaimed the East’s No. 3 seed. Miami’s Hassan Whiteside had 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Dwyane Wade struggled, scoring nine on 4‑for‑20 shooting; the Heat were outscored 57‑27 after halftime, hurting their playoff hopes.

Dutch YouTube free‑kick specialist Bas van Velzen visited Liverpool’s Melwood training ground posing as a “competition winner” due to receive a lesson from Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Markovic. Once the shooting started, the players realised he was no ordinary fan as he repeatedly curled free‑kicks into the top corner, leaving the stand‑in keeper stranded and impressing the quartet. Van Velzen, whose online videos have made him a sensation, said meeting and surprising his idols was “amazing” and “really satisfying.” He capped the session by revealing Balotelli’s famous slogan T‑shirt, echoing the striker’s “Why Always Me?” celebration.

A Canadian study of 676 breast‑cancer patients who carried BRCA mutations shows that removing the ovaries (oophorectomy) sharply improves survival for BRCA1 carriers. Among the 345 women who had the surgery:

• Breast‑cancer deaths in BRCA1 carriers fell 62 %, and overall mortality dropped 65 %.  
• If the ovaries were removed within two years of diagnosis, BRCA1 carriers saw a 73 % cut in death risk.  
• The benefit appeared immediately and persisted for at least 15 years.  
• No clear survival advantage was found for BRCA2 carriers.  
• Nine ovarian‑cancer deaths occurred only in women who kept their ovaries.  
• The procedure was most effective in estrogen‑receptor–negative disease.

Because BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations give women up to a 70–80 % lifetime risk of breast cancer and a high risk of ovarian cancer, journal editors suggest oophorectomy be discussed at diagnosis for mutation carriers. Actress Angelina Jolie, who has a BRCA1 variant, underwent a double mastectomy in 2013 and an oophorectomy in 2015, exemplifying this preventive approach.

On Easter Sunday at about 10 a.m. in Durham, North Carolina, married couple Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed while lingering on the tracks by Amtrak train No. 80 (the Carolinian) traveling from Charlotte to New York City on Norfolk‑Southern property. None of the 166 passengers were hurt, though one person fell ill during the ensuing 2 hour‑45 minute delay. The couple, pronounced dead at the scene, were believed by an acquaintance to be living in a nearby homeless camp. After the delay, the train resumed its route; Durham lies roughly 25 miles northwest of its next stop, Raleigh.

Carlos Toro, 66, a former mid‑level Medellín cartel member, fled Colombia in the 1980s and then spent 27 years as an unpaid undercover informant for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. His information helped bring down figures such as cocaine boss Carlos Lehder and ex‑Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. The DEA had promised Toro U.S. citizenship, but after his recent retirement due to poor health, the agency has refused assistance; his last visa expired January 1. Now living in the U.S. illegally, unable to receive Social Security and fearing assassination if deported, Toro says he will go into hiding if necessary. Even a former DEA handler has personally given him money for medical needs, calling the government’s inaction “bureaucracy at its worst.”

ICANN is investigating Vox Populi Registry, the Canadian operator of the new “.sucks” top‑level domain, after complaints that it is demanding excessive fees from brands and celebrities who feel forced to buy the names to protect their reputations. Since the domain opened on 30 March, addresses such as youtube.sucks, visa.sucks and bankofamerica.sucks have been registered, and Kevin Spacey has reportedly paid to have his name removed. During a trademark‑holder “sunrise” period Vox Populi set the price at about $2,499 per year (resold for roughly $2,000); ordinary consumers will be able to register “.sucks” sites for $10 a year starting in September. An ICANN advisory panel representing firms like Microsoft, Verizon and eBay calls the pricing a “shakedown scheme” and wants the rollout halted. ICANN has asked U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine whether the company’s practices are illegal and says a negative finding could put Vox Populi in breach of its contract.

In June 1988 a still‑unknown baby boy was discovered wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating on Windmill Pit pond at Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk. Police could not identify the mother, so villagers paid for the unnamed infant’s burial at St Peter’s church.

During a 2014 cold‑case review the body was exhumed. DNA taken from a leg bone was run through the national database, matched to a relative, and led detectives to the boy’s mother. She admitted concealing her pregnancy, delivering the baby alone, finding him stillborn and placing his body in the pond on 5 June 1988.

The woman (not publicly named) was arrested for infanticide; that allegation was dropped after a second post‑mortem and her account showed no foul play. She remains on bail while prosecutors consider lesser charges of failing to register a birth and preventing lawful burial.

The child was re‑interred on 5 June 2014 under the name “Peter,” with a new headstone funded by stillbirth charity Hana’s Gift. Police say modern DNA techniques have solved the 27‑year mystery.

Five years ago Kristopher Hicks, then 23, jumped from taxi driver Michael Young’s moving cab in Bath after Young, wrongly suspecting a fare‑evasion, locked the doors and drove him back toward the rank. Hicks leapt out at over 20 mph, suffered catastrophic brain injury, developed epilepsy and now needs 24‑hour care from his mother. High Court judge Mr Justice Edis ruled Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks and is liable for damages, though compensation will be cut by 50 percent because Hicks chose to jump; the award is expected to total several hundred thousand pounds plus £250 for the false imprisonment. Both parties may appeal; a future hearing will set the final amount.

Multiple severe storms Wednesday night triggered tornado sirens in Kansas and Missouri.  
• Kansas: A reported tornado passed 6 mi NW of Goddard, skirting Wichita, and additional twisters were sighted near Aetna in the southwest.  
• Missouri: The National Weather Service suspects a tornado hit Potosi, causing wind damage, flooding, downed trees and roof damage; baseball‑size hail was reported in nearby Farmington.  
CNN meteorologist Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are especially dangerous, and the Weather Service expects more storms Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and the southern Great Lakes region.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida meet in a middle‑weight bout in New Jersey on Saturday, with the winner expecting a UFC title shot. Rockhold, riding a three‑fight win streak since losing to Vitor Belfort, vows to “be the bull” and pressure Machida, believing his wider skill‑set and ground game give him the clear edge. He nonetheless respects Machida’s long‑standing elite status. Machida, coming off a victory over CB Dollaway, counters that if he executes his trademark evasive style he can “stop Luke” and secure the next title opportunity. Both fighters report strong training camps and enter the contest confident.

A video taken at Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, shows an Aerostar light twin aircraft attempting to land with its landing gear still retracted. The plane hits the runway on its belly, its propellers strike the tarmac, and the wings bounce from the impact. Realizing the mistake, the pilot applies full throttle and, despite damaged propellers, manages to take off again. The pilot—85‑year‑old Chris Georgaklis, who has nearly 50 years of flying experience—then flies about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and lands safely with his dog on board. Gear‑up (belly) landings are usually caused by pilot error or mechanical failure; the FAA is investigating this incident.

• Manuel Pellegrini says Yaya Touré has under‑performed this season, admits his own disappointment, but promises to back the midfielder until the campaign ends and insists Touré does not need a rest.  
• City will nonetheless consider summer offers for the 31‑year‑old, who has two years left on his £220,000‑a‑week contract.  
• The champions have taken only 18 of the last 39 Premier League points; defeat to West Ham on Sunday could let Liverpool close to within one point.  
• Captain Vincent Kompany may miss the rest of the season with a muscle injury.  
• Goalkeeper Joe Hart says players—not just the manager—must accept responsibility and states the squad still supports Pellegrini.  
• Manchester City are eyeing West Ham left‑back Aaron Cresswell to help meet home‑grown quotas, but Hammers boss Sam Allardyce warns the 25‑year‑old not to repeat mistakes made by English players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who rarely played after moving to City.

• Domenico Rancadore, 65, a Sicilian‑Mafia member nicknamed the “Godfather of Uxbridge”, was convicted in Italy in 1999 and given a seven‑year term for “mafia association”.  
• He fled to Britain in 1995, lived quietly under the alias “Marc Skinner” for two decades and was arrested in London in 2013 on a European Arrest Warrant.  
• After lengthy extradition hearings, a judge finally ordered his return to Italy this February.  
• Italian law, however, voids a jail term if more than twice the sentence length has elapsed; Rancadore’s penalty therefore expired in October 2014.  
• Italy’s Court of Appeal has now “extinguished” the sentence, the European Arrest Warrant will be withdrawn and Westminster Magistrates’ Court is expected to formally discharge him; he need not attend.  
• The conviction itself remains but can no longer be enforced.  
• Lawyers and commentators criticised the cost and delays—some caused by CPS paperwork errors—saying the proceedings were effectively pointless once the sentence had lapsed.  
• Rancadore will remain in the UK with his family unless Italy’s Supreme Court overturns the decision, which observers consider unlikely.

Mr Mole, the Paul Nicholls‑trained mount of retiring champion jockey A.P. McCoy, lines up in Saturday’s seven‑runner Grade 1 Celebration Chase at Sandown as a 7‑2 co‑favourite with Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. Sprinter Sacre will be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville because Barry Geraghty is injured. The race will be McCoy’s final ride in a Grade 1; his full book of mounts for his last day in the saddle will be set on Friday. Other contenders include Mick Channon’s Somersby.

• In 1975 nine‑year‑old Marcia Trimble was raped, strangled and left under a shower curtain and wading pool in a disused garage 150 yards from her Nashville home; cookie money was missing and cookies were scattered around her clothed body.

• Her mother, Virginia Trimble Ritter, heeded her husband’s advice not to view the body or crime‑scene photographs when the child was found 33 days later.

• The murder remained Nashville’s most notorious unsolved case for 33 years; a teenage neighbor was charged in 1979 but the case was dropped for lack of evidence.

• In 2006 DNA from the child’s clothing identified Jerome Sidney Barrett, who had been in and out of prison for sex crimes; he was convicted in 2009 of second‑degree murder and given 44 years.

• Last year Ritter insisted on finally seeing the crime‑scene images on investigator Mickey Miller’s laptop. Horrified by her daughter’s injuries, she said she now wants revenge, shouting, “If I had a gun I’d kill him!”

World No. 1 Rory McIlroy, 25, says it is “unthinkable” that he will finish his career without winning the Masters, a victory that would give him the career Grand Slam and place him alongside Sarazen, Hogan, Player, Nicklaus and Woods. Though he has only one top‑10 in six Masters starts and infamously collapsed with a closing 80 in 2011, McIlroy calls that failure “the most important day” of his career because it spurred his later major wins: the 2011 U.S. Open, 2012 PGA, and both the Open and PGA in 2014. Believing Augusta National fits his game and hoping to win there multiple times, he plans to block out the intense pre‑tournament hype—just as he used golf as a “sanctuary” while navigating last year’s broken engagement and legal battles—and focus simply on playing his best this April.

This week’s top‑trending stories included:

• A rare quadruple rainbow photographed by fashion‑exec Amanda Curtis over New York.  
• China’s latest vice crackdown: banning exotic dancers hired to perform at rural funerals.  
• Robert Downey Jr. cutting short a U.K. Channel 4 interview after questions turned personal.  
• The viral #KylieJennerChallenge, where teens suction their lips with jars to mimic the star’s pout.  
• 102‑year‑old former dancer Alice Barker watching film of her 1930s performances for the first time.  
• A bomb‑themed “prom‑posal” rejected by a school, with the student alleging racism.  
• Casting news: Ewan McGregor will voice Lumiere in Disney’s live‑action “Beauty and the Beast.”  
• Johnny Depp’s dramatic, almost unrecognizable look in the new “Black Mass” trailer.  
• A pregnancy announcement spoofing the “Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air” rap.  
• A military father’s surprise photobomb of his son’s picture.

All of these items lit up social media over the past week.

Official figures show 272 children with foetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) were hospitalised in England last year, yet experts say many more are affected. WHO data suggest at least 1 % of UK newborns—about 7,500 a year—may develop lifelong learning, behavioural, and physical problems after prenatal alcohol exposure. FAS can cause organ damage, cerebral palsy, sight loss, epilepsy and permanent dependence, as illustrated by 15‑year‑old Niamh Brown, whose adoptive parents founded the FASD Trust. Current UK advice allows up to two units of alcohol twice weekly during pregnancy, but specialists urge a zero‑alcohol guideline.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, 31—nicknamed “Boomerang Boy” for his long, repeat‑offending record—burst into Shildon Post Office and Stores, County Durham, at 8 p.m. on 15 March, waving an axe at assistant Andrea Brighty and demanding cash. Owner Sab Dhillon rugby‑tackled him, and Dhillon’s wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, forcing him to drop the weapon until police arrived and arrested him. McKerry, whose criminal history dates to age 12 and includes scores of prior arrests, pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court and has been jailed for six years.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31) and Darren Smalley (35)—have been charged in Nova Scotia with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault after an alleged gang rape of a woman in her early 20s during an alcohol‑fuelled party at Shearwater military barracks on 10 April.  

Bail: £2,000 each; passports surrendered; forbidden to leave Nova Scotia, apply for new travel documents, contact the victim or six named witnesses, or resign from the Navy without court approval. They must live and work on Halifax’s Stadacona naval base until trial and return to court on 27 May. Conviction could bring up to 14 years in prison; further charges may follow pending forensic results.

Valerie Jackson, a 35‑year‑old mother from Las Vegas, cares for her four‑year‑old son RJ, one of only about 70 people worldwide with Netherton’s syndrome. The congenital skin disorder leaves his skin constantly red, inflamed and scaly, so she covers him with Vaseline and other creams several times a day and limits his baths to prevent painful dryness; the family has slept poorly for years. Because RJ’s appearance resembles severe burns, strangers frequently accuse Valerie of abuse. During one shopping trip to Walmart five armed police officers confronted her after a shopper reported that she had scalded her son; the officers left once she explained the condition. The family has also been barred from play centres and subjected to taunts—often from adults—who mistake the disease for sunburn or injury. RJ was first hospitalized at birth with an unexplained rash; after doctors failed to diagnose him, Valerie discovered a Facebook support group that matched his symptoms and confirmed Netherton’s syndrome, a rare, incurable form of ichthyosis that can cause infection, allergy problems and slow weight gain but often improves with age. Despite ongoing ignorance and bullying, Valerie and her husband Reginald continue the rigorous skin‑care routine and stress that RJ is a happy, “beautiful” little boy.

Protein World’s “Are you beach‑body ready?” posters, showing bikini model Renee Somerfield, have sparked a major backlash on the London Underground.  

Key facts  
• A Change.org petition against the ads has passed 50,000 signatures; more than 200 complaints have gone to the Advertising Standards Authority, which is now assessing the case.  
• Many posters were defaced and a protest in Hyde Park is scheduled for 2 May.  
• Transport for London is taking the ads down this week as the paid three‑week slot ends, adding it will consult the ASA before accepting similar ads again.  
• Protein World has vigorously defended the campaign on social media—calling critics “a nation of sympathisers for fatties”—and says the model’s image is un‑photoshopped. The firm reports violent threats, including a bomb threat now under police investigation.  
• TV presenter Susanna Reid called the ad “anxiety‑inducing” during a live interview with the company’s marketing head, while commentators such as Katie Hopkins and Samantha Brick have supported the message.  
• The row unfolds against booming UK protein‑powder sales, forecast to rise from £170 m in 2012 to £358 m by 2017.

• Several train operators plan steep rises in “unregulated” fares—those not controlled by government—during the May 17 price‑change window, with some increases as high as 87 %.  
• First Great Western’s biggest jump is on the North Cotswolds line (London–Charlbury): the off‑peak return will rise from £33.30 to £62.40 if passengers return on an evening‑peak train.  
• The change comes only ten days after the general election, despite Conservative and Labour pledges to keep rail prices frozen in real terms.  
• Prime Minister David Cameron, whose Witney constituency is served by the route, has written to FGW asking for an urgent review of the decision.  
• FGW says the rise brings the route into line with its other services and notes that advance singles could still let some travellers make a return trip for about £20.  
• Other notable increases:  
  – Off‑peak first‑class single Crewe–Northampton (London Midland): £30 → £37.  
  – Anytime return Stafford–Liverpool (Virgin): £26.50 → £33.  
  – Anytime first‑class day return Manchester–Stoke (Virgin): £29 → £35.30.  
• Virgin argues most of its affected tickets are “Virgin‑only” fares that remain at least 20 % cheaper than rivals and says its average West Coast rise is just 1.65 %.  
• Critics point out that hundreds of anytime and off‑peak returns already rose by about 40 % in January, calling the latest moves inconsistent with parties’ fare‑freeze promises.

John Young, 66, a retired soldier and HGV driver, was blinded in his left eye after being struck by a brick thrown into his Oldham, Greater Manchester home on 18 April at about 11:20 pm. He and his new wife Elaine, 54—married only three weeks earlier—were writing wedding thank‑you cards when youths began pelting their window with stones. When a brick smashed the glass, Young opened the front door to remonstrate and was hit directly in the face by another brick, suffering an eye injury that surgery could not save. Police say there appears to be no motive beyond vandalism, describing the assailants as yobs “messing around.” Detective Constable Gareth Gwilliam has appealed for witnesses to call 101. The shaken couple now plan to leave the neighbourhood for Elaine’s flat in Southport.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, who missed the entire 2014 season with leg injuries from a car crash that killed his father, has signed a one‑year contract extension keeping him at the county until the end of 2016. After ankle surgery he returned to action on Derbyshire’s pre‑season tour of Abu Dhabi, and elite performance director Graeme Welch praised his resilience and form, hoping the new deal will bolster his confidence for the coming season.

Five‑year‑old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed last year with stage‑4 neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, lungs, neck and bones.  
Treatment: 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, surgery to remove the kidney tumour, a stem‑cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy at Manchester’s Christie Clinic.  
Coping: Harley asked to paint his radiotherapy immobilisation mask as a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle and wore a superhero costume, a story that drew worldwide attention and gifts from TV channel Nickelodeon.  
Outcome: Doctors have now declared him cancer‑free; he will attend regular follow‑ups while returning to normal life and school.  
Recognition: He received Cancer Research UK’s Little Star award and is fronting the charity’s Kids & Teens fundraising campaign.  
Background on the disease: Neuroblastoma is a rare, aggressive childhood cancer of nerve tissue; fewer than 100 UK children are diagnosed each year, most under five.

Aston Villa boss Tim Sherwood says 19‑year‑old Jack Grealish should focus on securing a regular place at Villa after his standout FA Cup display against Liverpool, rather than rushing a decision on whether to represent England or the Republic of Ireland. Sherwood, citing his past experience with Nabil Bentaleb, insists the international choice is “purely up to” Grealish and should be made with his heart once he has played more club games. Grealish’s father echoes the view that sustained club form must come first, acknowledging the decision—likely after the season—will be difficult, with even the possibility of split friendly appearances for both countries.

Private‑jet travel is booming (2.5 million U.S. flights and 705,000 European flights in 2013; market value put at $16.7 trillion in the U.S. and $15.8 trillion in Europe). Big sporting weekends such as the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix create peak demand, with sample round‑trip charter prices of about $38,000–$54,000 (New York–Glendale) and roughly £8,800–£8,900 (London–Cannes/Nice). Popular routine hops include Los Angeles–Las Vegas (~£2,890) and Milan–Rome (~$5,880 one‑way).

Landing charges for private jets vary sharply; a list based on a 767‑400 aircraft shows the ten costliest airports:

1. Haneda, Tokyo – £4,559 ($6,850)  
2. Narita, Tokyo – £3,728 ($5,600)  
3. Kansai, Osaka – £3,594 ($5,400)  
4. Toronto Pearson – £3,461 ($5,200)  
5. Darwin – £3,059 ($4,600)  
6. Bristol – £2,929 ($4,400)  
7. Chūbu Centrair, Nagoya – £2,863 ($4,300)  
8. Dublin – £2,729 ($4,100)  
9. La Guardia, New York – £2,630 ($3,950)  
10. Salzburg – £2,530 ($3,800)

The dominance of three Japanese airports, plus unexpected appearances by hubs such as Darwin, Bristol, Dublin and Salzburg, highlight where the wealthy frequently fly and the premium they pay simply to land.

Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, filmed her Labrador Cooper and smaller dog Daisy sharing a McDonald’s ice‑cream cone. While Daisy gently licks, Cooper swallows the rest in one bite. Gallegos, who runs Dogpatch Resort, says Cooper always eats fast and lets Daisy eat first. The clip has drawn both praise and criticism yet has surpassed seven million views. Gallegos defends the occasional treat, noting her dogs are healthy and that her previous pet lived to 19 with weekly ice creams. A second video shows the pair at Starbucks, where Cooper similarly downs a whipped‑cream “pup‑uccino.”

Gary Locke, 41, has been appointed Kilmarnock’s permanent manager on a three‑year contract. Formerly Allan Johnston’s assistant and ex‑Hearts boss, he took charge when Johnston resigned in early February and has since suffered just one defeat in seven matches. Locke will address the media on Friday and was pictured sealing the deal with chairman Jim Mann.

Jessica Kemp of Eustis, Florida says Seminole County Elementary warned it would remove or suspend her five‑year‑old autistic son, Logan, because the DoTerra essential oils she applies to his head and neck—scents such as lavender, chamomile and sandalwood—smell and distract classmates. Kemp argues the oils keep him calm, notes he has used them all year, and plans to fight the decision. A school‑board letter called the oils a “problem,” but the Lake County School District later stated Logan will not be suspended, labeling the matter a health issue.

• Around 3 p.m. Wednesday a huge blaze swept through the 90‑condo Sandpiper beach‑side complex in Westhampton Beach, Hamptons.  
• Twelve fire crews fought the flames, but could not enter the building; the structure eventually collapsed.  
• Smoke and flames were visible three miles away, and heat was so extreme it melted paint on nearby buildings.  
• No injuries reported, but residents—including on‑site manager Rob Taber—“lost everything.”  
• The complex, used as seasonal homes (May‑November), is now destroyed.  
• Exact cause is still under investigation; one report suggests it may have begun near a parked car.

Queen Elizabeth II, 88, was seen riding her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, through Windsor Great Park in the spring sun. True to habit she wore only a silk scarf, refusing a riding helmet—something she says would spoil her carefully set hair. A lifelong horse‑lover, she first rode at four on a Shetland called Peggy and has since owned mounts such as Betsy and Surprise. Although a knee problem has reduced her time in the saddle and ended her Trooping the Colour appearances on horseback, she still rides, visits her Windsor stables regularly, and encourages her grandchildren to use her horses.  

Alongside her Thoroughbred racehorses, the Queen breeds Fell and Highland ponies, maintaining a Fell stud at Hampton Court. Fell ponies, an ancient Cumbrian breed dating to Neolithic times, are hardy, mainly black, 13–14 hh, and historically served Celts, Romans, Vikings and miners as pack animals before becoming popular family riding ponies in the 1950s—a role they still fill today.

In North Brisbane on Thursday night, a noise dispute led 28‑year‑old warehouse shift‑worker Phillip Pama to confront neighbour Leon Yeaman, 55, who was allegedly drunk, playing loud music and shouting. During the argument Pama, reportedly pushed, threw a single, “blind” punch that struck Yeaman; paramedics could not revive Yeaman, who was pronounced dead at about 11 p.m. Pama, a married father of three with no prior violence, was charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail (passport surrendered, 6 p.m.–2 a.m. curfew, twice‑weekly police reporting) and will reappear in court on May 18.

Russian music teacher Yulia Simonova, 52, tried to hire a contract killer to torture and murder her 15‑year‑old former pupil and lover, Damian Vanya, after he left her for a classmate. She offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the attack, specifying that the boy’s arms, legs and kidneys be destroyed so he would slowly bleed to death, and that she would “finish him” herself. Police set up a sting in Shatura, near Moscow; an undercover officer posing as the hitman recorded her instructions and accepted expense money. Armed officers then arrested Simonova in her car. She has been charged with attempted murder and faces up to 15 years in prison. Vanya says he is relieved and hopes she is jailed for a long time.

Chelsea’s 52‑year‑old manager José Mourinho says he prays daily and has a strong personal faith but never discusses football with God or with his wife. He tries to keep his professional life separate from family life, describing himself as a good family man who helps others and acknowledging that his job’s competitive nature can lead to mistakes. Mourinho and his family, aware of poverty through his role as a World Food Programme “ambassador against hunger,” only pray about personal matters. Chelsea are currently league leaders and face QPR next; earlier in the season Mourinho was fined £25,000 for alleging a refereeing “campaign” against his club.

On the April 1 episode of “The Price Is Right,” 91‑year‑old former host Bob Barker returned for the first time since his 2007 retirement. He opened the show, ran the “Lucky Seven” pricing game, then passed hosting duties back to current host Drew Carey, showing little rust after eight years away.

Secret Service agent Arthur Baldwin, off duty, was arrested about 12:30 a.m. Friday on the 3200 block of D Street SE in Washington, D.C., for allegedly trying to break into a house. He faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property, is on leave, and has lost his security clearance. Baldwin, assigned to the agency’s Foreign Missions Branch, was to be arraigned Friday afternoon; no attorney is listed. His arrest follows separate recent misconduct probes—including a supervisor placed on leave two days earlier and a March 4 incident involving two officials—adding to the agency’s mounting controversies.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life in Lahore Safari Park to photograph a male lion. He left his car, lay on the ground about 10 feet from the hungry animal and took several shots. The camera’s shutter alerted the lion, which charged, but Saeed managed to dive back into his car unharmed. He later admitted he likely would not attempt such a dangerous stunt again.

NYPD is seeking the public’s help to identify a woman, aged 25–45, who was found unconscious and later pronounced dead on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Brooklyn’s Gravesend neighborhood. She carried no ID but has a faded right‑leg tattoo—a heart with a ribbon bearing the name “Monique” and topped by a rose—whose image police have released. The cause of death is still pending the medical examiner’s report. Anyone with information should call NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800‑577‑TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple who returned home from the UK in 2009 without enough money to buy property, bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent about 18 months turning it into a two‑bedroom wood‑and‑steel house. The $25,000 project produced a largely self‑sufficient home: most power comes from roof‑mounted solar panels (their first bill was $25), heating is via a wood‑fired stove, hot water and cooking use gas, and water is drawn from a nearby spring. Now parked on a lot they own in Nelson, the cypress‑lined house—complete with stained‑glass windows—houses the couple and their cat amid surrounding trees and a brook. They hope to build another similar dwelling in the future.

A U.S. study of 352 kindergarten pupils found that those who shared iPads in class for a full school year scored about 30 points higher on early‑literacy tests than classmates who either had no iPads or an individual device. Researcher Courtney Blackwell (Northwestern University) concludes that the benefit stems from the collaborative use of the tablets, and suggests schools rethink how they deploy the technology. The results will be presented at the 65th International Communication Association conference in Puerto Rico, amid wider debate about the value of classroom technology.

A piglet born without hind legs on Ms. Duan’s farm in Qionglai City, Sichuan (south‑west China) has learned to walk upright on its two front trotters. A video of the determined “Super Pig,” posted by People’s Daily Online, shows it wobbling but repeatedly regaining balance while foraging and mingling with its fully‑limbed littermates; the clip has turned the animal into an internet sensation and drawn villagers to see it. The story echoes an earlier Chinese favorite—a two‑legged rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo in Guangxi that also walks on its front paws.

At Sunday’s inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Dale Coyne Racing front‑outside tire changer Todd Phillips was struck in the pits when Francesco Dracone’s car spun while leaving its stall on lap 25. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut at the infield care center and was released. Slippery track conditions from earlier rain plagued many drivers; Dracone later retired and was classified 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), in their Rio de Janeiro apartment’s garden just four days after their wedding. CCTV shows him dragging her outside, smashing her head on concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, then shooting her in the face five times. He later told police he acted out of jealousy over other men looking at her. After the killing he fled in a stolen car, crashing and being arrested; officers recovered four handguns, a shotgun and a bullet‑proof vest. Severiano has confessed and faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, 41‑year‑old Australian journalist and best‑selling author of “I Quit Sugar,” told Women’s Weekly Australia that crippling anxiety, stress, thyroid disease and a sense of isolation once left her suicidal, feeling there was “no point” in continuing. She now accepts she is an anxious person and has “found some peace,” but says anxiety is fast becoming the “new depression.” Wilson stresses that depression and anxiety are tightly linked and must be addressed together, noting Beyond Blue’s figure that one‑in‑three Australian women will experience anxiety. Help is available via Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a 23‑year‑old Portland woman who was seven months pregnant, came home in November 2014 to find her boyfriend’s ex‑girlfriend shooting heroin in her bathroom. After the woman refused to leave, Curtin hit her in the head and arm with a crowbar. Curtin was charged with second‑degree assault and faced nearly six years in prison, but prosecutors have now dropped the case, saying her use of force against the intruder was justified under Oregon law. Curtin has since given birth, ended her relationship with the child’s father, and moved in with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, is filmed receiving treats when her owner sneaks in a piece of broccoli. She bites the vegetable, makes a disgusted face, and spits it onto the floor, unlike the two children she lives with who are hoped to enjoy their greens. Other videos show Gemma mainly sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC’s Hong Kong website contained a hyperlink for its discontinued Young Entrepreneur Awards that now led to a pornographic site, after the award URL lapsed following its 2011 cancellation and was taken over by the porn business. HSBC removed the link, stressed it had no connection with the external site, confirmed its own site remains secure, and issued a public apology for the incident.

Early Sunday morning in Clinton, Maryland, 13‑year‑old Marcus and his 9‑year‑old sister Aaliyah were trapped in a second‑floor bedroom after a fire started on the first floor of their home. Marcus calmly spent 11 minutes on a 911 call, gave firefighters precise directions, and reassured his panicked sister. Prince George’s County firefighters entered the house, broke the bedroom window, and Lt. Kenny Ward passed Marcus out to rescuers and gave his own air mask to Aaliyah. The children were taken to Children’s Hospital with non‑life‑threatening injuries; their mother, step‑father, and older brother escaped on their own and were treated at MedStar Hospital.

Blue‑glowing plankton (Noctiluca scintillans) have created a vivid night-time display at Jervis Bay on Australia’s south‑east coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the scene, calling it a “beautiful supernatural” sight produced by millions of light‑emitting cells. Oceanographer Iain Suthers (UNSW) says these naturally occurring blooms appear mainly in spring and autumn, are generally harmless, and result from the carnivorous plankton’s defensive bioluminescence; a similar event lit Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014.

New lab tests that analyse genetic markers in removed breast‑tumour tissue (e.g., the EndoPredict test) can tell within days how likely a woman’s cancer is to return.  

Key points:  
• For some patients the test shows a recurrence risk as low as 5 %, similar to or better than the benefit achieved by routine post‑surgery chemotherapy.  
• Women with a low score may safely forgo chemotherapy and avoid its severe side‑effects (hair loss, nausea, weight change, extreme fatigue).  
• Most tests cost about £2,500 and are presently available mainly privately, but specialists argue NHS use would be cost‑effective because it would save many courses of chemotherapy.  
• Surgeons Hemant Singhal and Kefah Mokbel stress the test helps tailor treatment; patient case (Becca Cornford) illustrates choosing to skip chemotherapy after receiving a low EndoPredict score.

• Since 1990, when women were first allowed to serve on Royal Navy ships, more than 25 female sailors have had to be air‑evacuated from vessels because they were found to be pregnant.  
• HMS Ocean alone accounted for five pregnancy “medevacs” in the past nine years; HMS Illustrious (nicknamed “HMS Lusty”) and 18 other ships—including HMS Dragon, Enterprise and Richmond—have also had emergency removals.  
• The Ministry of Defence says a strict “no‑touching” rule applies at sea, so pregnancies are assumed to have begun before embarkation or while on shore leave.  
• The disclosure follows last year’s recall of Commander Sarah West, the Navy’s first female warship captain, amid allegations of an onboard relationship.  
• Similar issues occur on land operations: 99 British servicewomen were flown home from Afghanistan for pregnancy between 2006‑2013, and 102 were evacuated from Iraq. Military regulations bar pregnant personnel from war zones, and those affected are returned on the first suitable flight.

A small, four‑propeller drone equipped with a camera, smoke flares and a bottle containing trace amounts of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s Tokyo residence. While the cesium level posed no immediate health threat, the incident has heightened fears of drone‑based terrorism, especially with the upcoming Olympics and G7 summit. Japan currently has few drone flight restrictions over central Tokyo or government buildings. The discovery coincided with a court decision allowing the restart of two Sendai nuclear reactors—a move many Japanese oppose after the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Abe was in Indonesia at the time of the incident.

Chinese security guard Lu Xincai, from Zhejiang province, brings his 84‑year‑old mother, who has Alzheimer’s, to work every day. After his father died and with no one else to care for her, he seats her on the back of his motorbike, secures them together with a sash, and drives the 4 km trip slowly so they can talk; the journey takes about an hour. His bank employer provides a room for her, and Lu checks on her regularly to prevent her from wandering. Lu says he is repaying the devotion she once showed her children.

A nationwide study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (UW), using 3.7 million CDC survey responses, found that from 2005‑2012 heavy drinking in the U.S. jumped 17.2 %, largely because women’s consumption rose sharply. Heavy drinking (≥1 drink/day for women, ≥2 for men) characterized 8 % of adults in 2012; binge drinking (≥4 drinks/occasion for women, ≥5 for men) affected 18 %, with women’s binge‑rate growing more than seven times that of men (e.g., up 36 % in Santa Clara County, CA). County extremes ranged from 6 % to 36 % for binge drinking (Madison County, ID vs. Menominee, WI) and 2 % to 22 % for heavy drinking (Hancock County, TN vs. Esmeralda County, NV). Researchers link the rise to changing gender norms, youthful and affluent populations, cheaper alcohol, increased advertising and weaker alcohol‑control laws; excessive drinking already causes about 88,600 U.S. deaths and costs over $220 billion annually.

UN/WHO officials warn that caesarean sections are being used too freely, jeopardizing mothers and babies.  
Key points:  
• Caesareans should be done only when medically necessary because they can cause infections, serious complications, disability or death.  
• In England, more than 25% of births are by caesarean—over double the early‑1990s rate—partly due to women requesting planned operations out of birth anxiety.  
• WHO says the ideal rate is 10‑15%, noting the procedure also diverts money: a planned caesarean costs the NHS about £2,369 versus £1,665 for a natural birth.  
• The warning conflicts with current NHS/NICE guidance that allows caesareans on request, even without medical need.  
• Research shows roughly 1 in 10 caesareans result in infections, indicating doctors may be underestimating the risks.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham was arrested on April 17 in Edgartown, Martha’s Vineyard. Police say she broke into an $800,000 summer home, lived there for about a week, and ran a yard sale with the owners’ belongings. Charges: breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Items reported missing include deck chairs, a Weber grill, furniture, lamps, kitchenware, linens, and a painting. Police ask anyone who obtained these items to return them and may help buyers seek restitution. Filkins is due back in court on May 14.

Bella Crooke of Melbourne lost her unlocked iPhone at a Saturday‑night birthday party. A security guard turned it in to Albury Police Station (on the NSW‑Victoria border) Sunday morning. To find the owner, officers used the phone to post humorous selfies and pun‑filled status updates on Bella’s Facebook—showing the handset in a “holding cell,” joking it would be fully “charged,” and inviting “Bella to post bail.” The posts quickly spread among her friends. When Bella arrived about 1 p.m., police recognized her from Facebook, returned the phone, and continued the banter by replying to her friends’ texts. Bella has since set a password and publicly thanked the “boys in blue” for their good‑humored help.

A five‑day‑old hippo calf in South Africa’s iSimangaliso Wetland Park was killed after blundering into a prolonged fight between two adult males. Witness Stacey Farrell saw one combatant seize the youngster, drag it through the water and hurl it into the air while the mother, who had stayed with her herd for safety, looked on helplessly. The badly injured calf died a few hours later.

• A three‑bedroom, 1,990 sq ft maisonette in Egerton Place, Knightsbridge, is for sale at £575,000—far below local prices—because its lease has only three years remaining.  
• The purchase price equates to about £191,000 a year (£15,000 a month), roughly the normal rent for a similar flat in the area.  
• A second, larger (2,500 sq ft) unmodernised maisonette on the same street is also available for £595,000, likewise with a three‑year lease.  
• Both properties need full renovation; in modernised condition agents estimate they would fetch £2,750–£3,000 per sq ft, valuing the smaller at around £6 m and the larger at about £7.5 m.  
• Extending the lease to 90 years would require negotiating with the freeholder (thought to be the Wellcome Trust) and is expected to cost £3.35–£4.5 m, making the low asking price largely a “teaser.”  
• Short‑lease sales in Knightsbridge are rare, prompting strong interest, but experts caution buyers that the apparent bargain comes with a “massive premium” for lease extension and renovation.

Late Friday a computer failure disrupted cash registers at roughly 8,000 company‑run Starbucks stores—7,000 in the U.S. and 1,000 in Canada—preventing credit‑card transactions. While the systems were down, many outlets either handed out free drinks and food or closed early to avoid the giveaway; excited customers publicized the freebies on Twitter. Starbucks said the outage occurred during a routine daily system refresh, apologized, and reported that all stores would reopen “business as usual” on Saturday after resolving the problem. The glitch followed the company’s report of record quarterly revenue of $4.6 billion.

Police say rural parts of west Wales—specifically Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire—are being used to train and radicalise Islamist extremists. Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter‑Terrorism Unit told Ceredigion Council that terrorists often pose as ordinary visitors while pursuing hidden agendas and stressed that such activity is not limited to big cities. Reported links include:

• 1998: Hate preacher Abu Hamza allegedly sent 10 extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons.  
• 2005: Two 7/7 bombers were photographed white‑water rafting in Bala.  
• 2010: Three Cardiff men met co‑conspirators in a Welsh country park to plan “Mumbai‑style” attacks.  
• Michael Adebowale, killer of Lee Rigby, studied Arabic at the European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder.

Jones urged local residents to share any intelligence with authorities.

A 5.68 m juvenile female Omura’s whale, a species only formally described in 2003 and once feared extinct, washed ashore on a remote beach near Exmouth, Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn. It is the first recorded sighting in WA and only the second in Australia. DNA profiling confirmed the identification, which is notable because the species is usually found in Indonesian, Philippine and Sea of Japan waters. Omura’s whales are distinguished by a sleek body, 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin. The carcass has been buried so the skeleton can later be recovered for study and possible museum display, providing scientists valuable data to improve identification guides and map the species’ range.

Texas marketing CEO Cheryl Rios posted on Facebook that Hillary Clinton—and any woman—shouldn’t be president because female hormones could trigger irrational decisions such as starting a war. The article rebuts her claim, noting:

• History and research show male leaders’ testosterone has fueled risk‑taking and scandals, while studies find female leaders take fewer unnecessary risks.  
• Rios’s view reflects a broader, well‑documented workplace bias: women are under‑represented on boards (there are more male directors named John, Robert, William or James than women in total) and are described more for likability than brilliance in student evaluations.  
• This bias, not biology, limits women’s advancement; it will make Clinton’s path to the White House harder.  
• Greater gender equality benefits everyone—companies perform better, children and marriages thrive, and diverse teams excel.  

Rios threatened to move to Canada if Clinton wins, seemingly unaware Canada already had a female prime minister, Kim Campbell, in 1993.

Actor Robert Hardy, 89, is downsizing and has placed his personal collection of 238 antiques and books—expected to realise about £100,000—into auction at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, this Saturday. The sale reflects his lifelong passion for military history and literature: highlights include a hand‑painted 3‑D diorama of the 1415 Battle of Agincourt (£4,000‑£6,000), a yew longbow with mother‑of‑pearl handle and a portrait of Hardy holding it (together up to £2,000), early‑Victorian cabinets by Gillows (to £4,000), along with swords, flintlock rifles, paintings, crystal chandeliers and 17th‑century books. Hardy—taught at Oxford by J. R. R. Tolkien and C. S. Lewis, author of two longbow histories, and consultant on the Mary Rose—says he is “sad” to part with the collection. Best known as Siegfried Farnon in “All Creatures Great and Small,” for repeated portrayals of Winston Churchill, and as Cornelius Fudge in the Harry Potter films, he retired from stage work after a fall in 2013 but intends to continue television acting.

Florida police are searching for Michael Scott Shemansky, who vanished Saturday and is the prime suspect in the killing of his mother, 57‑year‑old Sandra Shemansky, at their shared Winter Garden home. The body was discovered after a relative requested a welfare check. Michael missed a court‑ordered visit with his son that same day.  

Background:  
• Shemansky is on parole for battery on law enforcement, has bipolar disorder, a prior suicide attempt, and is in the midst of a contentious divorce; his estranged wife previously obtained a domestic‑violence injunction.  
• Neighbors say divorce stress and bad legal news may have triggered him, and that his mother had tried to keep him out of further trouble.  

Investigation:  
• Police have recovered the unidentified murder weapon but have not revealed the cause of death.  
• He was last seen on foot, without supplies or medication, after asking for water in the trailer‑park office.  

Authorities urge anyone with information to call 407‑656‑3636.

Eugene, Oregon has been chosen to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The IAAF Council bypassed the normal bidding process, calling it a unique strategic chance to stage the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had lost the 2019 bid to Doha, but a new presentation convinced the IAAF of its capability. IAAF President Lamine Diack cited strong backing from public authorities, private partners, the U.S. Olympic Committee and broadcaster NBC. The move mirrors the 2007 Osaka championships, which were also awarded without a formal bid.

Leonie Granger, 25, from Gillingham, Kent, befriended 56‑year‑old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan after seeing him with rolls of £50 notes in a West End casino. On 24 March 2014 she dined and gambled with him, then returned to his Islington flat, deliberately leaving the door unlocked for her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson, 28, and his friend Nicholas Chandler, 29. The two men bound Hassan with parcel tape, kicked him to death and ransacked the flat, escaping with about £3,000, his TV and phone; later they filmed themselves tossing the stolen cash around. Hassan—father of three and known for keeping large winnings at home—was found face‑down, with multiple broken bones and bound limbs.

At the Old Bailey Granger was convicted of manslaughter, robbery and conspiracy to falsely imprison and jailed for 16 years. Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder, robbery, firearms conspiracies and false imprisonment and received life sentences with minimum terms of 36 years. Judge William Kennedy called the attack “pitiless and wicked,” describing it as an act of ruthless greed.

Cesc Fàbregas began the season in superb form for Chelsea, racing to 15 Premier League assists by mid‑January and appearing certain to break Thierry Henry’s single‑season record of 20. Since Christmas, however, his output has collapsed: just one assist in his last five league games and four in 15 matches for club and country in 2015. Barcelona had warned of his traditional post‑Christmas dip, and that pattern resurfaced in Spain’s 2‑0 loss to Holland, where he captained the side but was rated four‑out‑of‑ten. Playing almost every minute for Chelsea seems to be taking a physical toll, raising José Mourinho’s concern as Fàbregas’ influence on the title run‑in wanes. Chelsea still need several wins from their final nine fixtures; facing six teams he has already unpicked this season offers a chance for the midfielder to revive his form and help clinch the league after February’s Capital One Cup triumph.

West Ham United are close to signing 17‑year‑old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford of Montego Bay United after a successful two‑week academy trial, though he also has interest from Belgian clubs. Regarded as one of the Caribbean’s top prospects, Beckford has attracted attention from several European sides. Separately, West Ham announced that season tickets at their 54,000‑seat Olympic Stadium will start at £289 when they relocate for the 2016‑17 Premier League season, giving them the league’s lowest prices.

Three months after huntsman Mike Lane, 40, was violently beaten by balaclava‑clad hunt saboteurs, Wiltshire Police have closed the case for “insufficient evidence.”  
• The assault occurred on 24 January near Everleigh, Wiltshire, while 30 riders followed an artificial scent. About 15 protesters arrived; five confronted Lane, spitting at, punching and then kicking him unconscious, stamping on his mouth with a steel‑toecapped boot and swinging an iron bar on a rope.  
• Lane, joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, suffered concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling, and continuing memory loss, spending £500 on dental work.  
• Supporters supplied police with a video showing the attacker’s uncovered face, names of suspected saboteurs and car registrations, and police later circulated the suspect’s photograph, yet no one was identified or charged.  
• Lane, witnesses and hunt organisations call the decision “pathetic” and “disgraceful,” arguing police could have done more; the Countryside Alliance is pressing for a ban on face coverings by saboteurs.  
• Police say the file is now marked “undetected” but will be reopened if new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn, 36, the U.S.–born English‑language propagandist for al Qaeda, was killed in a U.S. counter‑terrorism strike in January, the White House revealed. He was not the intended target; the same series of operations also killed U.S. al‑Qaeda member Ahmed Farouq and, in a separate strike, hostages Warren Weinstein (American) and Giovanni Lo Porto (Italian).

Known as “Azzam the American” and “Abu Suhayb,” Gadahn was born Adam Pearlman in 1978, raised on a rural California farm, converted to Islam in 1995, and moved to Pakistan in 1998. Rising to become al Qaeda’s chief English‑language spokesman, he appeared in mid‑2000s videos threatening Los Angeles and Melbourne, urging attacks on U.S., Western and Jewish targets, praising Fort Hood shooter Nidal Hasan, lauding the Benghazi assault, encouraging lone‑wolf violence, and tearing up his U.S. passport. A 2006 federal indictment charged him with treason and material support for terrorism, placing him on the FBI’s “Most Wanted Terrorists” list.

Documents from Osama bin Laden’s Abbottabad compound show he advised on al Qaeda media strategy, confirming his growing internal influence. Gadahn was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child; his last video, released September 2014, called for overthrowing the Saudi and Pakistani governments.

Chinese social media is abuzz with a video of five‑year‑old Mai Zizhuo, who began shooting hoops at two‑and‑a‑half and now performs advanced moves—sinking repeated shots and dribbling two balls without losing rhythm. The clip has earned him widespread admiration in basketball‑crazy China, drawing comparisons to national icon Yao Ming and prompting thousands of astonished online comments.

Tom O’Carroll, a former leading activist in the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) that campaigned in the 1970‑80s to legalise sex with children, attended a Hacked Off rally in Parliament on 25 February. Hacked Off seeks statutory press regulation following the phone‑hacking scandal and opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation. O’Carroll’s presence—at a meeting chaired by comedian John Cleese and open to the public—links the group to a notorious paedophile advocate, likely causing it embarrassment. PIE had allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties, which once urged reducing the age of consent to ten and legalising incest; O’Carroll was jailed in 1981 for “corrupting public morals.”

Bondi’s Icebergs Club emptied its famous ocean pool on Thursday to stage the Ten Pieces show for Mercedes‑Benz Fashion Week Australia. Models paraded through the drained pool and along the break wall, presenting a monochrome, unisex capsule of ten garments that can each be styled 20 ways for day‑to‑night wear. Ten Pieces is led by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss. Guests enjoyed 28 °C sunshine, Icebergs snacks and Santa Vittoria drinks, while beachgoers and passers‑by watched the striking seaside catwalk.

Boxer Amir Khan spent a day off at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom safari park in Northern California with his wife Faryal and daughter Lamysa, posing with giraffes and sea lions and feeding a rare white tiger. Earlier in the week he confirmed that his next bout will be a welterweight fight against former light‑welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, quashing talk of matches with Kell Brook, Adrien Broner or Keith Thurman.

• Sixteen‑year‑old Palestinian Mohammed Abu Khdeir was kidnapped, beaten and burned to death by three Israelis in July.  
• His name was recently added to Israel’s Mount Herzl memorial, which honors fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism.  
• Abu Khdeir’s family objected, saying they had not been consulted and did not want his name placed “between soldiers of the occupation.”  
• Israeli victims’ group Almagor also opposed the inclusion, arguing the murder was a “rogue” crime, not terrorism, and demanded the name’s removal.  
• Israel’s National Insurance Institute, which maintains the memorial, has now removed Abu Khdeir’s name from the wall and its website.  
• A court case against the three Israeli suspects is under way.

A California YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son in the garden repeatedly trying to use the family cat’s belly as a pillow. Each time the boy lies on the cat, the cat shifts to a new spot and finally retreats indoors. A follow‑up clip shows the pair reconciled, with the child giving the cat treats.

• Philadelphia is holding a federal police‑corruption trial against six former narcotics officers charged with racketeering, extortion, robbery, kidnapping and drug dealing.  
• Prosecution witness Robert Kushner, 32, a onetime marijuana dealer, testified that the officers stole $81,000 and seven pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest.  
• After his testimony, Kushner was dismissed from his varsity basketball coaching post at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, which had hired him in 2010 following a clean background check.  
• Kushner’s criminal record includes the expunged 2007 case, a 2008 DUI plea, and a 2011 arrest that led to four years’ probation; he maintains he is innocent of the 2011 charges.  
• Defense lawyers contend the case rests on testimony from “19 lying drug dealers and a rogue ex‑cop.”

An oil‑leak triggered explosion struck the paraxylene (PX) plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian, on Monday night. The blast ignited a large fire—now under control—fought by more than 600 firefighters. Six people were injured (mostly by flying glass); no toxic chemical spill has been reported. The plant, which makes the reportedly carcinogenic PX used for polyester, was previously rocked by a 2013 explosion and was relocated from Xiamen in 2007 after public protests against PX facilities.

Aston Villa teenager Jack Grealish, who wears children’s shinpads and keeps his socks unusually low as a long‑standing superstition, says he will ignore referees’ requests to pull them up. After making his first Premier League start in Villa’s 3‑3 draw with QPR, the Republic of Ireland U‑21 international was pleased with the manager’s faith in him and hopes for more starts despite the match’s disappointing result.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, 22‑year‑old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, is out of her medically induced coma but remains unresponsive and has “global and irreversible brain damage,” her grandmother Cissy Houston said after consulting doctors. A source confirms she shows no neurological improvement, does not react to voices or movement, and has a tracheostomy, meaning she could live indefinitely in this state. While Bobby Brown recently told a concert crowd that “Bobbi is awake,” the family’s attorney clarifies that although she has opened her eyes, left the ICU and begun what will be a long rehabilitation, the quality of her future life is still unknown.

Russia seized a 2‑0 advantage over Germany in their Fed Cup tie on Saturday.  
1. Svetlana Kuznetsova opened with a straight‑sets win over Julia Goerges.  
2. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova then edged Sabine Lisicki 4‑6, 7‑6(4), 6‑3, saving a match point; her 13 double faults were offset by Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors.  

With one more victory required from Sunday’s three remaining rubbers, Russia are poised to reach the Fed Cup final and pursue their first title since 2008.

• Meteorologists warn that another east‑coast low may strike New South Wales from Thursday to Saturday, bringing heavy rain and strong winds, especially to the state’s north‑east (Northern Rivers, Mid‑North Coast) and parts of south‑east Queensland.  
• While expected to be faster‑moving and positioned farther offshore than last week’s system, the new storm could still raise flood levels on already‑saturated ground.  
• The State Emergency Service (SES) still has about 4,000 outstanding jobs from the 24,196 calls it received during last week’s three‑day storm and fears the new weather will hamper clean‑up efforts, particularly in the hard‑hit Hunter region.  
• More than 1,000 SES personnel—200 from other states—are working to finish repairs and are urging residents to secure homes and make preparations before the next system arrives.

Model Nina Moric, 38, best known for appearing in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loca” video, has denied Italian press reports that she attempted suicide. Media stories—echoed by boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso—claimed her mother found her after a suicide attempt in the Milan apartment the couple share.  

Posting photos of arm bruises to her 40,000‑plus Instagram followers, Moric said she simply collapsed at home Saturday night from low blood pressure, struck her head, was treated in hospital, and is now recuperating. She insisted her boyfriend was in Naples at the time and called the suicide rumors “shocking.”  

Reports also resurfaced a 2009 overdose claim. Moric, Croatian‑born, was previously married to celebrity paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, 41—jailed for blackmail— with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria (born 2002).

A YouGov/Sunday Times poll of 2,200 Britons shows that:

• 25 % hope the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge have a girl; only 3 % prefer another boy.  
• If the baby is a girl, the most popular name choice is Diana (12 %), followed by Alice and Charlotte (9 % each).  
• If it is a boy, James leads with 13 % support, with Alexander in second place.  
• 68 % approve of Prince William’s plan to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

Social‑media commentary echoes the poll, with many users expressing a wish for the name Diana to honor William’s late mother.

A suicide bomber struck a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, around 10 a.m. Thursday, killing 17 people and injuring 64 (including MP Humayoon Humayoon). The protesters were en route to a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied involvement and no group has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves will leave Barcelona this summer. After seven trophy‑filled years (four La Liga titles, two Champions Leagues), the 31‑year‑old right‑back rejected the club’s final offer—a three‑year extension tied to him playing 60 % of matches. His agent and ex‑wife, Dinorah Santana, announced that negotiations are now finished and criticized Barcelona for waiting until April to address the renewal.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29‑year‑old on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and already with three goals in six matches, has told Corriere dello Sport he wants his former teammates Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo says their “South‑American style” would suit Boca perfectly and that La Bombonera’s fans would “go absolutely crazy” for the Italian legends.

Eighteen‑year‑old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, who rides out for Paul Nicholls, became an online sensation when a video of his double‑somersault fall from favourite Merrion Square in the 4.20 pm race at Wincanton was viewed hundreds of thousands of times. Despite the spectacular spill, he escaped with only a cut on his nose, was back mucking out and riding the next morning, and joked that the acrobatics might lead to a future in gymnastics while enjoying good‑natured banter and a jump in Twitter followers.

• Avengers: Age of Ultron opened this week, premiering at London’s Westfield, drawing large crowds for stars Robert Downey Jr., Chris Hemsworth and Scarlett Johansson.  
• To join the buzz, England rugby flanker and London Wasps captain James Haskell posted an Instagram photo in full Iron Man armour, captioned with Avengers hashtags.  
• Rugby career recap:  
  – Began with Wasps in 2002, earned first England cap in 2007.  
  – Left in 2009 for Stade Français (France), then Ricoh Black Rams (Japan), and the Highlanders (New Zealand).  
  – Returned to Wasps in 2012, has now exceeded 100 club appearances and holds 57 England caps.

Wide‑leg trousers are a key Spring/Summer 2015 trend, appearing in denim, cropped, printed and striped versions and offering a fresh alternative to long‑dominant skinny jeans. Reviving a 1970s silhouette, the style was highlighted on the Gucci, Céline and Stella McCartney runways, while high‑street options such as Topshop’s Miller jean and pieces from Finery London make it accessible. Styling is crucial: wear them high‑waisted and very long or cropped with high heels that reveal the top of the foot, and balance the volume with a simple knit, shirt or tee to avoid looking swamped. Denim remains the easiest entry point, and the look works in any weather.

• About 200 University of Michigan students petitioned to halt an upcoming UMix showing of the film “American Sniper,” arguing its Iraq‑war portrayal was offensive to Middle Eastern people, a sensitive issue in Detroit’s large Arab‑American community.

• After the university cancelled the screening, a backlash and counter‑petition ensued.

• Vice‑President for Student Life E. Royster Harper reversed the decision, calling the cancellation a mistake inconsistent with free‑expression values; the movie will now be shown, with the family film “Paddington” offered as an alternative.

• “American Sniper,” starring Oscar‑nominee Bradley Cooper as Navy SEAL Chris Kyle (killed in 2013), will proceed, a move applauded by football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24 and living in Cockburn Central, were evicted from Western Australia’s Rottnest Island after using a lighter and aerosol spray to create a flame that singed a quokka on 3 April. Detectives seized video of the incident; the quokka survived with minor burns. Both men have been charged with animal cruelty and will face Fremantle Magistrates Court on 17 April. Quokkas, cat‑sized marsupials, inhabit islands off the West Australian coast, especially Rottnest and Bald islands.

102‑year‑old Alice Barker, once a chorus‑line dancer at New York venues such as the Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar in the 1930s‑40s alongside stars like Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen the motion‑picture “soundies” made of her because all her memorabilia had been lost. Filmmakers recently located the footage, screened it for her in her nursing home, and the thrilled Barker called it “just fabulous.”

A survey of 1,100 UK adults by vehicle‑leasing firm OSV shows home car‑washing is fading as a Sunday habit.  

Key findings  
• 31 % of men and about 75 % of women have never washed their own car; only 12 % of male washers do so regularly.  
• Just 5 % of respondents have ever paid their children to wash the car.  
• Reasons for the decline include Sunday shopping, televised football, the convenience of hand or automated car washes, and the larger size of modern 4x4s.  
• An estimated 15 million cars were owner‑washed over Easter, though one‑quarter of owners said it was mainly to get out of the house.  

Geographical and vehicle patterns  
• Most frequent self‑washing cities: Birmingham, Chelmsford, Sheffield.  
• Least frequent: Oxford, Bath, Edinburgh.  
• Cars most often self‑washed: Audis, Toyotas, BMWs; least: Range Rovers, Peugeots, Mercedes.  

OSV spokesman Andrew Kirkley notes that shrinking free time, bigger cars, and cheap professional options have eroded what was once a national Sunday tradition.

• Martin Skrtel hails Steven Gerrard’s influence since 2008, calling him “still one of the best players in the world” and synonymous with Liverpool.  
• Gerrard will captain Liverpool in Sunday’s FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa; victory would give him a farewell final versus Arsenal on 30 May (his birthday) before he joins LA Galaxy.  
• Skrtel thanks Gerrard for helping him settle at Anfield but believes the club has players capable of filling the void next season.  
• Both Gerrard and Skrtel can return to the side against Villa after completing three‑match bans for violent conduct in March’s loss to Manchester United.

At Augusta National’s Par‑3 Contest, 75‑year‑old Jack Nicklaus made his first Augusta hole‑in‑one, spinning his tee shot on the 130‑yard 4th back into the cup while playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. The day produced a record‑tying five aces: Colombia’s Camilo Villegas holed out at the 4th and 8th but lost the contest in a playoff to world No. 74 Kevin Streelman. Nicklaus, six‑time Masters champion and the youngest green‑jacket winner in 1963, is one of five players to have completed the career Grand Slam—a feat current favorite Rory McIlroy can match with a Masters victory.

• Tornado sirens sounded across Kansas Wednesday night as multiple storms produced reported twisters.  
• A tornado was sighted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, moving northeast and sparing Wichita but threatening other areas; additional reports came from near Aetna in southwestern Kansas.
