• The National Weather Service also believes a tornado struck Potosi, Missouri (about 70 miles from St. Louis), where wind damage, flooding, fallen trees and roof damage were observed; baseball‑size hail was reported in nearby Farmington.  
• CNN meteorologist Chad Myers warned of deadly overnight storms, and the Weather Service forecast more severe weather Thursday for the Midwest, Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and the southern Great Lakes region.

• Tulsa County reserve deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second‑degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris during an April 2 weapons sting; he says he meant to fire his Taser but drew his gun by mistake.  
• A judge allowed Bates to take a family vacation in the Bahamas, a move the Harris family condemned as showing “apathy” toward the killing.  
• A preliminary hearing is set for July 2.  
• Harris’ relatives argue Bates was unqualified and kept on the force through donations and friendship with Sheriff Stanley Glanz; a Tulsa World report claims supervisors were told to forge Bates’ records, which the sheriff’s office denies.  
• Bates’ attorneys released his training records to counter the allegations.  
• Two other deputies at the arrest have been reassigned after receiving threats.

Conor McGregor, preparing for his July 11 featherweight‑title fight against champion José Aldo in Las Vegas, unveiled a new tiger‑face tattoo on his stomach (adding to his chest gorilla tattoo). Posting the image on Instagram, McGregor wrote, “If you see the tiger, it’s too late, you’re food.” He maintains that Aldo lacks his level of motivation, citing an earlier promotional stop in Dublin where McGregor grabbed Aldo’s belt before 5,000 fans. With about three months until the bout, their rivalry remains intense.

At an Australian Rules football function Prime Minister Tony Abbott accepted a challenge to “skol” a schooner of beer, finishing it in about six seconds as players chanted his name.  
The act drew strong criticism from anti‑drinking advocates and cultural‑studies academic Julie Robert, who said it glamorised binge drinking and reinforced the idea that masculinity requires heavy alcohol consumption. She argued such displays encourage drinking for speed and quantity rather than socialising.  
Media and political responses were mixed: opposition leader Bill Shorten mocked Abbott good‑naturedly, while Health Minister Sussan Ley defended him, citing his otherwise healthy lifestyle. Critics maintain the Prime Minister should model responsible behaviour and recognise changing public concern about excessive drinking, rather than perpetuating the “true‑blue Aussie bloke” stereotype.

Indiana’s HIV outbreak centered in Scott County continues to grow despite a 30‑day emergency needle‑exchange program launched March 26 by Governor Mike Pence. Confirmed cases have risen to 120, with 10 additional preliminary positives, up from 106 a week earlier. The infections are linked to intravenous users of the painkiller Opana. To date, 5,322 clean syringes have been distributed to 86 participants and 1,400 used needles returned; a mobile unit has recently boosted enrollment. Pence must decide next week whether to extend the exchange beyond its April 25 end date. Broader legislation that would let 23 other high‑risk counties start exchanges passed the House but faces uncertain Senate support amid concerns that such programs enable drug use. Funding is also unresolved: federal money is barred and Pence’s order provided none, raising doubts about long‑term sustainability.

An Arsenal‑obsessed boyfriend set his girlfriend Saskia a mock “school exam” about his club, complete with multiple‑choice, tables and an “in‑your‑own‑words” section.  
• She posted photos of the test on Twitter (@saskiaisabxlla) saying “boyfriend made me take an @Arsenal exam!”  
• Scored 43.5/50 (87%) – enough for an A grade and the tongue‑in‑cheek promise “I will not be dumping you!”  
• Questions covered facts such as the 2014 FA Cup score v Hull, the winning goalscorer (Aaron Ramsey), current manager, starting XI positions, why Alexis Sánchez is better than Eden Hazard, and why Tottenham are “scum.”  
• The examiner marked in red, wrote corrections in capitals, drew angry faces for errors, and noted she “could have performed better on Q17” and should “learn all player positions.”  
• Her creative answer “Hazard is a p***k” earned double marks; mistakes included misplacing Özil and Welbeck and forgetting Koscielny.  
• Twitter reaction ranged from praising the boyfriend as a “legend” and Saskia as “proper GF material” to calling him a “biff‑head” who went too far, though most assumed it was light‑hearted fun.

Carlos Toro, 66, is a former Medellín cartel member who spent 27 years working as an unpaid undercover informant for the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration. In return he was repeatedly promised U.S. citizenship, but after retiring for health reasons he never received it; his last visa expired January 1, leaving him in the country illegally and unable to collect Social Security. Toro’s intelligence helped bring down major figures such as cartel boss Carlos Lehder and Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, yet the DEA has refused to assist him since he publicized his situation. Facing possible deportation to Colombia—where he believes he would be killed within hours—Toro says he may go into hiding while he continues to seek a green card or passport.

A 14‑year‑old girl from Kosi Kalan in Uttar Pradesh was allegedly gang‑raped by five local men while she was outside her home to relieve herself. After relatives reportedly urged silence, she doused herself with kerosene and set herself on fire on Tuesday; her brother extinguished the flames, and she is now in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with 70 percent burns. Police have arrested the five accused. The case unfolds amid intense national focus on sexual violence: officials recently banned the documentary “India’s Daughter” about the 2012 Delhi bus rape‑murder of Jyoti Singh, and separate incidents of mob justice have seen suspected rapists publicly beaten to death in Nagaland. The recurring attacks and public backlash continue to fuel protests and demands for greater protection of women in India.

Louis van Gaal says he is “dreaming” of a victory over Manchester City in Sunday’s Old Trafford derby, a result that could lift Manchester United to third place and virtually secure direct Champions League qualification. Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw remain sidelined because the manager does not yet consider them match‑fit, although the rest of the squad trained on Friday, with Wayne Rooney, David de Gea, Ángel Di María, Radamel Falcao and others involved. Van Gaal, who lost 1‑0 at City earlier in the season, warns his team must control their aggression but downplays any notion of revenge. He is eager to experience the derby atmosphere with United’s home support behind him.

Before Arsenal’s lunchtime Premier League match with Liverpool at the Emirates, sections of supporters from both clubs left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes to protest “extortionate” ticket prices.  
Key points:

• Cheapest seats for the sold‑out 12:45 pm kick‑off cost £64—among the league’s highest.  
• Fans displayed banners reading “£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket” and “Football without fans is nothing,” referencing the Premier League’s recent £5.14 billion TV‑rights deal.  
• The protest was organised by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement with Liverpool groups Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, who argue that rising prices threaten to price out working‑class supporters and “sell football’s soul.”  
• Organisers warn more demonstrations will follow unless ticket costs are reduced.

Newborn Star Reader from Barnsley, West Yorkshire was diagnosed with the rare, life‑threatening liver disease biliary atresia soon after birth, signalled by persistent jaundice. An initial operation to unblock her bile ducts failed and doctors said only a liver transplant could save her. Neither parent, Jade Reader nor Matthew Bygrave, was a suitable donor, but Jade’s identical twin, Shanell Reader, was a perfect match and immediately offered part of her liver. The transplant was performed in November; Star spent six weeks in hospital and is now recovering well, though she will need lifelong anti‑rejection medication and regular liver‑function tests. Biliary atresia affects roughly 1 in 16,000 babies and can be fatal without treatment. Shanell has also recovered, and the family credits her donation with giving Star the chance of a normal life.

Chelsea stars Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy and Willian took part in Audi’s football challenge.  
• Round 1: players aimed balls into a car boot; Hazard and Ake won 5‑3.  
• Round 2: on a tennis‑style court with a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus as the “net,” Hazard and Ake won again, going 6‑0 up overall.  
• Round 3: long‑range shots into a convertible; Remy and Willian triumphed but Willian accidentally knocked a wing mirror off one of the Audis.

Former Fortune 500 executive Robert Dellinger, 54, drove his pickup across a Lebanon, New Hampshire highway median at more than 100 mph on December 7, 2013, striking an SUV and instantly killing Vermont couple Amanda Murphy, 24, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons, 29; their unborn daughter also died.  

Prosecutors say Dellinger told police he was attempting suicide, but during the first day of a two‑day sentencing hearing he insisted he has “never been suicidal.” He pleaded guilty in February to two counts of negligent homicide and one count of assault for the fetus’s death and now faces 12–24 years in prison; a wrongful‑death civil suit is also pending.  

The defense attributes his actions to Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric‑drug overdose, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis; prosecutors cite an argument with his wife over medication that morning. Dellinger’s wife testified to his character and offered condolences to the victims’ families.  

Dellinger, formerly of PPG Industries, Sprint, Delphi, and GE, left PPG in 2011 with a severance exceeding $1 million and his family trust owns about $3 million in Sunapee, NH property.

Lacey Spears, a mother from Scottsville, Kentucky, was found guilty of second‑degree murder for fatally poisoning her 5‑year‑old son, Garnett‑Paul Spears, by putting a lethal amount of salt into his feeding tube while he was hospitalized in suburban New York. On Wednesday she received 20 years to life in prison—less than the 25‑years‑to‑life maximum sought by prosecutors, who said she made the boy ill to gain attention and kept blogging during his repeated, unnecessary hospitalizations. The judge called the crime “unfathomable in its cruelty” and noted Spears suffers from mental illness. Defense counsel portrayed her as a devoted single mother, blamed hospital negligence, and plans an appeal. Meanwhile, the child’s father, Chris Hill, vented on Facebook, urging that Spears be placed in the general prison population so she would “not make it,” and condemning her emotionless demeanor at sentencing. Spears is currently held in Westchester County Jail pending transfer to state prison.

• Australia’s flu‑shot supply will arrive about a month late because the vaccine has been reformulated.  
• The new formulation now protects against three strains: influenza A H3N2, influenza B B/Phuket, and influenza A H1N1.  
• H3N2 and B/Phuket were linked to a surge in flu deaths in Europe and the United States last winter, where the earlier vaccine was a poor match; global health authorities therefore updated the recipe for the southern‑hemisphere season.  
• Free, government‑funded shots for high‑risk groups (the very young, the very old, and most Indigenous Australians) start 20 April; experts urge everyone to book vaccinations promptly.  
• The same upgraded vaccine will also be used in the next northern‑hemisphere winter.

Abraham Lincoln’s Springfield, Illinois tomb is under simultaneous public and financial pressure.  
1. National Geographic’s April article called the interior “a disappointment” with “all the historical character of an office lobby,” criticizing its 1930 Art‑Deco reconstruction.  
2. Site managers, volunteers, and some visitors reject the assessment, noting more than $2.5 million in recent repairs—plaster, paint, bronze, marble, new lighting, and ongoing vault waterproofing.  
3. Illinois’ budget crisis adds risk: Governor Bruce Rauner proposes abolishing the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency (which runs the tomb) and merging it into another department; lawmakers last year had already cut $1.1 million, reducing staff and open hours.  
4. The debate coincides with events marking the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s 1865 assassination.  
5. Designed by sculptor Larkin Mead, dedicated in 1874 by President Grant, and rebuilt in 1899 and 1930, the granite obelisk houses Lincoln beneath the inscription “Now he belongs to the ages.”

1990s and early‑2000s fashion is being revived—chokers, berry lips and Calvin Klein tees are already back, and even JNCO’s ultra‑wide “rave” jeans may return. The article lists nine other once‑popular but widely ridiculed trends that are re‑appearing:

1. Bucket hats – once worn by Christina Aguilera; now by Rihanna.  
2. Camouflage print – from Destiny’s Child to model Jourdan Dunn.  
3. “Maxed‑out” looks like double denim and all‑over designer prints – then Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears, Justin Timberlake; now Kylie Jenner.  
4. Ugg boots – Paris Hilton then; Kristen Bell now.  
5. “Daisy Duke” ultra‑short denim shorts – revived by Jessica Simpson; still favored by Miley Cyrus.  
6. Juicy Couture velour tracksuits – Britney Spears and Paris Hilton then; Nicki Minaj now.  
7. Brightly coloured / mirrored sunglasses – *NSYNC and Britney then; Cara Delevingne and Kylie Jenner now.  
8. Corsets worn as outerwear – Victoria Beckham then; Selena Gomez now.  
9. Harem trousers – Kim Kardashian then; Elle Macpherson now.

The piece argues these impractical or unflattering items are best left in the past despite their current celebrity endorsements.

Highlights of the week’s most‑shared stories:

• A rare “quadruple” rainbow appeared over the New York area and was photographed by fashion‑company CEO Amanda Curtis.  
• China is cracking down on the growing rural practice of hiring exotic dancers to perform at funerals.  
• Robert Downey Jr. abruptly ended a UK Channel 4 interview when questions turned personal.  
• The #KylieJennerChallenge—people suctioning their lips in jars to mimic Kylie Jenner—went viral.  
• Filmmakers showed 102‑year‑old former dancer Alice Barker vintage footage of herself performing.  
• A student’s bomb‑themed “prom‑posal” was rejected by his school; he claims the decision was racist.  
• Ewan McGregor will voice Lumiere in Disney’s live‑action “Beauty and the Beast.”  
• Johnny Depp is almost unrecognizable as gangster Whitey Bulger in the “Black Mass” trailer.  
• A couple announced their pregnancy with a “Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air” parody video.  
• A deployed serviceman surprised his son by photobombing the boy’s picture.

At the Miami Open Serena Williams recorded her 700th career victory, overcoming Sabine Lisicki 7‑6, 1‑6, 6‑3 in the quarter‑finals and celebrating with a giant cake similar to the one Andy Murray received for his 500th win the previous day. Venus Williams’s defeat to Carla Suárez Navarro ended hopes of a sister showdown, and Serena will instead face third seed Simona Halep—who beat Sloane Stephens 6‑1, 7‑5—for a place in the final.

Sabeen Mahmud, a prominent Pakistani human‑rights activist and founder of the Karachi café‑cultural space “The Second Floor” (T2F), was known for hosting open discussions on technology, politics, women’s enterprise and other progressive topics. After leading a talk on enforced disappearances in Baluchistan—an issue often suppressed in Pakistan—she was shot five times and killed late Friday by two gunmen as she closed the café; her mother was wounded but is expected to recover. No group has claimed responsibility and police have not stated a motive. Mahmud, previously threatened for her outspoken views, had become a national symbol of free speech, humanism and tolerance; her death has sparked widespread grief and tributes across social media and among friends who laud her bravery and commitment to open dialogue.

• About 100,000 West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) ‒ Hindu families who fled to Indian‑administered Jammu & Kashmir during the 1947 Partition ‒ have never been granted “state‑subject” status.  
• Because Kashmir’s pre‑independence citizenship law recognizes only people descended from the former princely state, WPRs cannot own land, vote in state elections, enter state training colleges or hold state‑government jobs, leaving three generations in slum‑level poverty.  
• Successive Kashmiri governments, anxious not to alter the Muslim‑majority state’s demographic balance, have maintained the restrictions even though some 35,000 Hindus from Pakistan‑controlled Kashmir do receive full rights.  
• The recent entry of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu‑nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party into Kashmir’s governing coalition has raised hopes among refugees such as 82‑year‑old healer Mangu Ram that their status will finally be normalized.  
• WPR activists say they will stage large‑scale protests if reforms stall, while armed violence between militants and security forces continues to underscore Kashmir’s long‑running political volatility.

• Chelsea have made an offer of about £4 million for 22‑year‑old FC Tokyo striker Yoshinori Muto.  
• Chelsea would loan him to partner club Vitesse next season, but Muto says he will only move if he can “play and develop” regularly.  
• Former FC Tokyo coach Ranko Popovic lauds Muto’s intelligence, speed and confidence, believing he could succeed at Stamford Bridge.  
• Jose Mourinho confirms he knows the player and acknowledges that commercial considerations—such as Chelsea’s recent £200 million Yokohama Rubber sponsorship—can influence transfers, though sporting quality remains essential.  
• Muto is still weighing his options and has yet to decide on the switch.

Australia have scrapped their ban on picking overseas–based players, meaning stars such as Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell (Toulon) can play at the World Cup. The writer says England now look outdated: coach Stuart Lancaster must also be free to choose expatriate talent. Cases cited include Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon and Jonny Wilkinson, all of whom improved after moving to France. Restricting selection to Premiership clubs, the piece argues, undermines England’s World‑Cup chances, places unfair doubt in current players’ minds and lets administrators, not coaches, decide teams. Other nations (e.g. South Africa with Bryan Habana, Wales with Leigh Halfpenny) already follow this open policy.

FireChat, created by Open Garden, is a free iOS/Android messaging app that works without the internet or a phone signal. It relies on Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and Android Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi Direct) to form a short‑range wireless mesh network in which every nearby handset (a “node”) relays data. Users can chat with people within Bluetooth/Wi‑Fi range (“Nearby”) or with anyone the message can hop to across linked nodes (“Everyone”). Messages travel up to roughly 200 ft, are sent under screen names (not phone numbers), and never pass through the internet, so they remain anonymous and difficult to hack. Since launching last year the app has been downloaded more than five million times and is useful in planes, subways, and other places with weak coverage.

To extend the mesh, Open Garden has built GreenStone, a small egg‑shaped beacon/booster. GreenStone:  
• Adds an extra relay point, filling gaps between phones.  
• Currently works only with FireChat, storing up to 1,000 recent messages that forward when another user comes within about 20 ft.  
• Runs on a battery expected to last a year.  

The company envisions placing several units at festivals, protests, hospitals, neighborhoods, or anywhere conventional networks are overloaded or absent, giving communities resilient “off‑the‑grid” communication. GreenStone is still in development while Open Garden seeks manufacturing partners.

Burlesque artist Lillian Bustle of New Jersey uses the word “fat” as a neutral, body‑positive description of herself—just like “short” (she is 5'3") or “wife.”  
In a 2014 TED Talk (recently posted to YouTube), she argues that “fat” need not mean “ugly,” citing:

• Social bias: workplace size discrimination has climbed 66 % in 30 years; girls 11–17 most often “wish” to be thinner.  
• Research: the more people see varied body types, the more they accept—even prefer—them.

Bustle, who weighs 240 lbs, began burlesque in 2012 after seeing her first show. Performing lets her present a “fat” body as glamorous, echoing fellow performer Beelzebabe’s view that burlesque broadens ideas of desirability. Her first routine—despite worries about “jiggly” arms—felt empowering and now serves as a “courage reference” she recommends to others.

Since the talk’s online release it has drawn about 38,000 views, mostly supportive comments, emails and personal stories; only a few online “trolls” were negative. Bustle says this response shows that body‑positivity is “winning.”

Arsenal winger Theo Walcott, 26, has spent much of the season as a substitute—named on the bench for 17 of the club’s 33 Premier League matches and playing only the last six minutes of Sunday’s 0‑0 draw with Chelsea. He and team‑mates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini and Mesut Özil posed with model Olga Sherer for an official Lanvin photoshoot; the fashion house has been Arsenal’s tailor since 2013, and the squad will wear similar outfits en route to the FA Cup final against Aston Villa on 30 May. Walcott hopes to make his first start since 14 March when Arsenal meet Hull on Monday.

A 417‑piece collection of movie props and creature effects created by Oscar‑winning make‑up artist Rick Baker will be sold with no reserve on 29 May at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and via Propstore.com. Valued in total at about $746,100, the lots span more than 50 productions from Baker’s 30‑year career, including Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, Gremlins 2, Harry and the Hendersons, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, Mighty Joe Young, and Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker and Thriller. Highlight estimates include the Edgar Bug alien from Men in Black ($40,000), a Mikey suit from the same film ($30,000), the Grinch costume ($8,000), Two‑Face’s mask ($1,500), the Harry suit ($6,000), various Gremlins puppets ($6,000–$8,000), and other notable pieces.

Seven‑year‑old Carwyn Scott‑Howell from Talybont‑on‑Usk, Wales, died while skiing with his family at Flaine in the French Alps. During the final run of their holiday his sister lost a ski; while his mother stopped to help, Carwyn skied on, left the marked piste, removed his skis in woodland, and apparently tried to reach the resort he could see below. Police followed his footprints and slide marks and found he had fallen about 164 ft to his death. A capable skier since age three who admired TV adventurer Bear Grylls, Carwyn was described by relatives as daring, outgoing and loving. His family and the local community are devastated; tributes and condolences are being placed in Brecon, and arrangements are being made to repatriate his body.

Laura Scurr, now 15 and living in Whitley Bay, developed anorexia at 13 after bullying and constant “size‑zero” imagery made her desperately want to slim down. She cut her intake to about 100 calories a day—often just one piece of fruit—hid food to fool her parents and rapidly lost weight. Eventually her heart rate slowed, she collapsed and spent a week on a cardiac monitor; doctors said her body was beginning to shut down. With help from specialist NHS eating‑disorder teams (EDICT and CAMHS) she began recovery, has rebuilt a healthier body image and is now a Miss Teen GB semi‑finalist, a contest that promotes confidence rather than extreme thinness. The story highlights the widespread pressure on teenage girls to be extremely thin and echoes NHS data that anorexia—one of several eating disorders affecting an estimated 725,000 people in the UK—is a serious, potentially life‑threatening mental‑health condition that often begins in mid‑teens.

Liverpool unveiled their 2015‑16 home strip at Anfield on Friday.

Key points:
1. Kit launch  
   • First Liverpool design from U.S. brand New Balance after a record £300 million, four‑year deal replacing sister firm Warrior.  
   • Red gingham shirt with all‑white branding, new collar, Hillsborough 96 memorial flame; separate goalkeeper jersey also shown.  
   • Slogan for the range: “Hold Nothing Back.”

2. Players and guests  
   • Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, Simon Mignolet, Jordan Henderson, Philippe Coutinho, Adam Lallana and Emre Can modelled the strip; club legends Robbie Fowler and Ian Rush attended.  
   • Supporters loudly urged Sterling to “make sure we see you in that next season.”

3. Sterling contract backdrop  
   • The 20‑year‑old recently rejected a £100,000‑a‑week offer and admitted Arsenal interest, but Liverpool insist he will not be sold this summer.

4. On‑field focus  
   • Players stressed the importance of the fans and looked ahead to the FA Cup semi‑final with Aston Villa at Wembley, hoping a cup win sparks future success; Steven Gerrard’s dream farewell in the final remains possible.

Overall: new kit reveal doubled as a public show of faith that key players—especially Raheem Sterling—will remain at Anfield while Liverpool chase FA Cup glory.

Scientists on the Dark Energy Survey have unveiled the biggest‑ever high‑definition map of dark matter.  

Key facts:  
• Made by a University of Manchester team led by Dr Sarah Bridle, the map spans 0.4 % of the sky (≈150 lunar areas) and was presented at the American Physical Society meeting in Baltimore.  
• It was built from 130 million galaxy images taken with the 570‑megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 4 m Blanco telescope in Chile.  
• By measuring the tiny gravitational‑lensing distortions in each galaxy’s shape, researchers inferred where dark matter is dense (red) or sparse (blue).  
• The map is the first instalment of a five‑year project that will finish in 2018, ultimately covering 12.5 % of the sky and providing a 3‑D view of dark matter and dark energy.  
• Early results show galaxies lying along thick filaments of dark matter, supporting models in which galaxy formation follows dark‑matter concentrations.  
• Analysing how the “clumpiness” of dark matter evolves will give new insight into the nature of dark energy, believed to drive the accelerating expansion of the Universe.

• Manchester United have formally approached PSV Eindhoven to sign 21‑year‑old winger Memphis Depay, a player Louis van Gaal knows well from the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup squad.  
• PSV confirm United’s move and say Paris Saint‑Germain and another major European club are also in contact; last summer’s £15 m Tottenham bid was rejected and the fee is now “much higher.”  
• Depay is in prolific form: 20 goals in 26 league games and a free‑kick in Saturday’s 4‑1 win over Heerenveen that clinched PSV’s first Eredivisie title in seven years (their 22nd overall).  
• Profile: born 1994 to a Ghanaian father and Dutch mother; youth at VV Moordrecht and Sparta Rotterdam; joined PSV at 12, debuted 2011, 100+ senior games. Fast, powerful left‑winger who dribbles, cuts inside and shoots from range, though still learning decision‑making.  
• Praise and potential: scout Ed van Steijn says he was ahead of Cristiano Ronaldo at the same age; PSV coach Phillip Cocu likens his ceiling to Arjen Robben; team‑mate Stijn Schaars hails his athleticism and drive.  
• Internationally, Depay scored against Australia and Chile at the World Cup and was nominated for Best Young Player.

In the FA Youth Cup final first‑leg at Manchester City’s Academy Stadium, Chelsea’s youngsters earned a 3‑1 advantage to take back to West London.

Key match events  
1. Tammy Abraham struck twice in the first half (his 35th and 36th goals of the season) to put Chelsea 2‑1 up, having earlier been briefly pegged back by City striker Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts.  
2. Dominic Solanke added a late third to “kill” the tie.  
3. Abraham went off injured after 67 minutes.

Individual highlights  
• Chelsea – GK Bradley Collins dependable; centre‑backs Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke‑Salter dominant; full‑back Ola Aina repeatedly dangerous; Ruben Sammut shielded defence; captain Charlie Colkett controlled midfield; Isaiah Brown lively despite an early miss; Solanke powerful alongside the prolific Abraham.  
• City – Keeper Kjetil Haug uncertain under high balls; captain Tosin Adarabioyo solid in defence; Brandon Barker City’s main threat but lacked end product; Kean Bryan limped on after injury and squandered a key chance.

Outcome  
Chelsea’s clinical finishing and stronger all‑round display leave them firmly in control of the tie going into the second leg.

• In a CBS “Face the Nation” interview, Republican presidential hopeful Marco Rubio said he believes people are born with their sexual preference.  
• Despite that view, he maintains that marriage should be defined as “between one man and one woman,” opposes recognizing same‑sex marriage as a constitutional right, and says the issue should be decided by individual state legislatures, not the courts.  
• Rubio added that he would still attend the same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of personal respect, similar to how he supports loved ones who divorce, though his Catholic faith opposes both.  
• The Florida senator formally entered the 2016 presidential race last week and, according to donors, has already secured commitments exceeding the roughly $51 million needed for the primary campaign.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian cyclist Ilze Zebolde (31) left their restaurant jobs in Manchester to pursue an open‑ended dream of “discovering the planet a pedal at a time.”  

After 356 days on the road they have:  
• Ridden almost 7,000 mi (11,131 km) through 16 countries.  
  Route so far: London → France (west & south coasts) → Spain → Portugal → back to France → northern Italy → Slovenia → Croatia → Bosnia‑Herzegovina → Montenegro → Albania → Macedonia → Greece → Turkey’s north coast → Georgia → Armenia.  
• Crossed from Europe into Asia and intend to keep cycling across Asia, over the Pacific and the length of the Americas, staying on the road “for the following years.”  

How they manage it:  
• Average spend: under €3 each per day (≈€0.10 per km); food accounts for €2.74.  
• Diet: pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal fruit/veg, occasional invitations, foraging and dumpster‑diving.  
• Accommodation: 161 nights camping, 66 via Couchsurfing, 44 via Warmshowers, plus offers from strangers; showers “sometimes daily, sometimes weekly.”  
• Carry about 130 kg of gear (including bikes).  

With no strict plans or timetable, the pair pause for scenery, rely on their legs for transport, and expect their minimalist, slow‑travel adventure to last for years.

In 2012, a Texas couple rented a photo booth from Premiere Photos for their wedding at the Bell Tower in northwest Houston. Months later the bride’s sister revealed that some booth prints carried the caption “poor n***** party.” Represented by attorney Cathy Hale, the couple say owner James Evans refused to apologize, telling them to “sue me.” They have filed suit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act for negligence and breach of contract, seeking at least an apology. Evans denies any involvement, noting the 103‑guest event shows no proof of company responsibility or the couple’s “mental anguish.” Mediation is set for tomorrow; if unresolved, trial is scheduled for July.

England and Harlequins full‑back Mike Brown is still experiencing post‑concussion symptoms and does not know when he will return. After feeling unwell following England’s recent match against France, he withdrew from Harlequins’ game with Saracens and is progressing cautiously through the graduated return‑to‑play stages (e.g., short bike sessions). Brown was previously knocked out against Italy in February and pulled out of England’s Ireland fixture when symptoms persisted. Citing serious cases such as George North, Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling, he says greater awareness gained from World Rugby’s online concussion modules has convinced him not to rush back and to urge teammates to do the same. He spoke while promoting Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” Rugby World Cup 2023 campaign.

British couples are having sex less often—about three times a month today versus four times in 2000 and five in 1990—according to Cambridge statistician Prof. David Spiegelhalter. He and other researchers link the decline to the rise of the internet and smartphones: constant email‑checking and blurred work‑home boundaries leave less “quiet” time for partners. Living alone more often may also contribute. As researcher Catherine Mercer notes, growing demands on time push sex further down people’s priority lists, with late‑night work emails leaving partners too “connected” to focus on each other.

Once prized as million‑pound status symbols, Tibetan mastiffs in China have rapidly fallen out of favor. Record prices reached £1.2 million for a pup only a year ago, but today many of the dogs—up to 80 kg in weight—are being stolen or sold to slaughterhouses, their meat used in cheap hotpots and their skins made into leather. 

Reasons for the crash:
• Beijing’s anti‑corruption drive: wealthy donors no longer give the dogs to officials as gifts.  
• City regulations banning dogs over 50 kg in Beijing, Shanghai, Tianjin, Zhengzhou, etc.  
• Mass cross‑breeding for profit that lowered the breed’s quality.  
• Urbanization, which has shown the breed is ill‑suited to city life.

Animal‑welfare workers recently intercepted 20 mastiffs bound for an abattoir; a third were already dead, many injured and unfed. Charities fear hundreds more suffer the same fate as breeders and thieves offload unwanted or “imperfect” animals amid the collapsed market.

A survey of 600 women in the Paris region found that every respondent has experienced sexual harassment on the city’s public transport, with half first targeted before age 18. Incidents range from verbal insults, persistent flirting and whistling to sexual assault and rape. Sixty percent of women, compared with 30 percent of men, now fear attack while travelling, prompting many women to alter routes, schedules or clothing and effectively limiting their freedom in public spaces. The High Council for Gender Equality, which produced the report, is urging an awareness campaign, stressing that such behaviour is punishable (e.g., touching is a sexual assault carrying up to five years’ imprisonment and a €75,000 fine).

Direct Line’s #everydayfix contest asked 2,000 people to name everyday “emergencies” and then challenged London design teams from Makerversity to invent quick‑fix products. Three prototypes were shortlisted and are competing on Twitter (most #everydayfix retweets by 46 April wins a Kickstarter launch):

1. Snooze (Instruments) – an alarm clock that links to your phone and mutes notifications so you can sleep.  
2. Forget Me Lock (ONN Studio) – a key‑mounted device that turns green for unlocked, red for locked, letting users check the door’s status even when away.  
3. Nipper (Impulse) – billed as the world’s smallest phone charger; it clips onto any household battery to give a mobile a power boost.

Other ideas that didn’t make the final cut included: a cycling helmet with bone‑conduction navigation, a space‑saving “Parking Pin,” and Relay, an app that forwards messages when your phone dies. The winning prototype will be built and funded via Kickstarter.

Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird has allocated more than £500,000 of Ministry of Justice victim‑support funding to Victims First Northumbria, a newly formed charity that she directs jointly with Northumbria Chief Constable Sue Sim. Because the two senior officers sit on the charity’s board, critics such as Home Affairs Committee chairman Keith Vaz call the arrangement a conflict of interest and “inappropriate,” arguing PCCs should not channel public money into bodies in which they hold roles. The Ministry of Justice has opened an investigation and can halt the funding if conflict‑of‑interest rules are found to be breached. Baird insists all MoJ protocols were followed; Sim, who gained prominence during the 2010 Raoul Moat manhunt and has faced past bullying allegations, is due to retire in June. Victims First was set up after usage of its predecessor, Victim Support, declined.

• Victim: 53‑year‑old Greg Valecce, an unemployed drug addict living in a Mayfair (N.E. Philadelphia) basement, was beaten, tied to a chair and tattooed for roughly 42 hours in late March 2014 after Corry “Corey” Campbell became convinced Valecce had broken Campbell’s cat’s leg and stolen money and marijuana.  
• Abuse: Campbell, girlfriend Sandra Ng (19) and friend Carl Halin (18) punched, spat on and filmed Valecce, then tattooed “RIP Pebbles,” swastikas, Stars of David, racial slurs and explicit images on him. Valecce suffered broken ribs, wrists and facial bones but escaped on 1 April and alerted police; the tattoos have since been removed.  
• Evidence seized: tattoo equipment, 155 g marijuana, prescription drugs, Valecce’s debit card.  
• Charges/pleas: all faced aggravated assault, conspiracy and false‑imprisonment counts and pleaded guilty.  
• Sentences: Campbell – 20 years’ state prison; Halin – 20 years; Ng – 23 months.  
• Awaiting court action: David Thomas (28) awaits sentencing; Jennifer Pratt (40) awaits trial.  
• After‑effects: Valecce reports lasting fear, nightmares and insomnia.

• PSV confirm Manchester United have formally approached them for 21‑year‑old winger Memphis Depay, a player Louis van Gaal knows well from selecting him for the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup squad.  
• United lead the race ahead of PSG and another major European club; Tottenham’s rejected £15 m bid last summer shows his fee has since risen.  
• Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV clinch their first Eredivisie title in seven years (22nd overall) with a 4‑1 win over Heerenveen, in which he struck a stunning free‑kick.  
• Career path: VV Moordrecht → Sparta Rotterdam → PSV youth at 12; first‑team debut 2011; over 100 PSV appearances.  
• Attributes: explosive pace, powerful right‑foot, prolific dribbler, usually left‑wing cutting inside; still learning decision‑making.  
• Comparisons: tipped by PSV coach Phillip Cocu to reach Arjen Robben’s level; United scout Ed van Steijn says he had more to his game at 21 than a young Cristiano Ronaldo.  
• International: 2 goals at the 2014 World Cup, nominated for tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea’s youngsters beat Manchester City’s academy side 3‑1 at the Academy Stadium, giving the London club a strong advantage to take into the return leg.  
– Tammy Abraham struck two first‑half volleys (his 35th and 36th goals of the season); Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts briefly levelled for City before the break.  
– Dominic Solanke finished the scoring late on, capping a powerful forward display.  
– Chelsea’s back line of Tomori, Clarke‑Salter, Aina and 16‑year‑old Dasilva coped well with City’s main threats Brandon Barker and Buckley‑Ricketts, while midfielder Charlie Colkett and holding man Ruben Sammut controlled central areas.  
– For City, captain Tosin Adarabioyo impressed in defence and Barker provided their main creative spark, but goalkeeper Kjetil Haug and several teammates struggled under Chelsea’s pressure. The result leaves Chelsea firmly in control of the tie.

Sen. Marco Rubio, newly declared 2016 presidential candidate, told CBS’s “Face the Nation” that:

• He believes most people are “born with” their sexual preference.  
• Despite that view, he says marriage should be defined as between one man and one woman and that same‑sex marriage is not a constitutional right; individual states, not the courts, should decide the issue.  
• Rubio stated he would still attend a same‑sex wedding of a relative or staff member, comparing his stance to loving a divorced person despite his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong.  

Rubio’s supporters have already pledged more than the roughly $47 million he is expected to need for the Republican primary campaign.

Spanish cyclist Pablo Mandado (27) and Latvian cyclist Ilze Zebolde (31) quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to fulfil a dream of seeing the world “a pedal at a time.”  

• Time on the road: 356 days so far, open‑ended trip.  
• Distance/route: ≈7,000 miles through 16 European countries—London → France → Spain/Portugal loop → Italy → Balkans → Greece → entire N. coast of Turkey → Georgia → Armenia; next: deeper into Asia, the Pacific, and the Americas.  
• Budget: under €3 per person per day (≈€0.10 per km).  
  – Accommodation: 161 nights wild‑camping, 66 via Couchsurfing, 44 via Warmshowers, plus occasional invitations.  
  – Major cost is food (pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, foraged food, “dumpster‑diving” in Western Europe).  
• Gear: about 130 kg carried on their bicycles.  
• Purpose: no agenda, simply to travel slowly, enjoy landscapes, and remain on the road “for the following years.”

England and Harlequins full‑back Mike Brown is still sidelined by concussion and says he will return only when he completes each stage of the recovery protocol without symptoms. Brown developed headaches after the recent France match, having already been knocked unconscious against Italy in February, and withdrew from fixtures against Ireland and Saracens. Citing the long lay‑offs of George North and Johnny Sexton, he refuses to risk a similar extended absence. Brown credits World Rugby’s online concussion modules for helping him recognise and report symptoms, and says he now urges team‑mates to do the same. He spoke while launching Land Rover’s “We Deal in Real” grassroots‑rugby campaign.

British couples are having sex less often—about three times a month today versus four times in 2000 and five in 1990—according to Cambridge statistician Prof. David Spiegelhalter’s book “Sex by Numbers.” He links the decline largely to smartphones and constant internet connectivity, which blur work‑home boundaries and fill time once spent with partners. Additional factors include more people living alone. Researcher Catherine Mercer adds that late‑night work emails and other digital demands push sex down the priority list.

Until recently Tibetan mastiffs were status‑symbol pets in China, fetching up to £1.2 million apiece, but the market has collapsed.  

Key points:  
• Prices soared after a 2005 boom; one gold‑maned pup sold for £1.2 m just 13 months ago.  
• Today the dogs are so unwanted that many are sold or stolen for slaughter; their meat goes into cheap hotpots and their skins become leather belts.  
• An animal‑welfare raid found 20 mastiffs crammed in cages en route to an abattoir; a third were already dead, others had broken bones. Hundreds more are believed to meet the same fate nationwide.  
• Causes of the crash:  
  – Xi Jinping’s anti‑corruption campaign; rich businessmen no longer dare give the dogs as gifts, nor do officials accept them (Luo Yi).  
  – City regulations banning dogs over 50 kg in places such as Beijing, Shanghai, Tianjin and Zhengzhou.  
  – Rapid urbanisation, which has shown owners that the 80 kg working breed is ill‑suited to city life (Chen Youjun).  
  – Profit‑driven cross‑breeding has produced many “imperfect” animals, creating a glut of poor‑quality dogs that cannot be sold (Luo Yi).  
• Ruthless breeders and street thieves supply slaughterhouses to recoup losses.  

Thus, a dog once viewed as a luxury “with lion’s blood” has become so devalued in China that it is now commonly butchered for food and leather.

Direct Line’s “#EverydayFix” competition asked Makerversity designers to create gadgets that ease common “everyday emergencies” identified in a survey of 2,000 people (top worries: can’t sleep 46 %, lost keys 37 %, late‑traffic 35 %, etc.). Three prototypes made the shortlist and are now in a public Twitter vote; the most‑retweeted by “40 April” will go to Kickstarter and full production.

1. Snooze – an alarm clock that links to your phone and silences notifications to help you sleep.  
2. Forget Me Lock – a key‑mounted indicator that turns red (locked) or green (open), letting you check remotely whether you shut the door.  
3. Nipper – billed as the world’s smallest phone charger; clips to any household battery to give your mobile a quick boost.

Other concepts that missed the cut include a bone‑conduction “Hat Nav” cycling helmet, a parking‑space sensor “Parking Pin,” and “Relay,” an app that forwards your messages if your phone dies.
